caregiver_solution_for_midwives.description:
The solution could help midwives/HCW monitor expecting mothers, identify risk pregnancies and involve a doctor when required.
I suggest a hybrid between Nokia Data Gathering tool or similar, like MoTeCH, and Medica Application from Nokia. Nokia Data Gathering tool allows creating of questionnaires and sending them to the midwives/HCW. Midwives gather data from the expecting moms they visit.
Medica Application provides reminders, alerts, plays recorded messages, etc on the mobile phones of the midwives.
caregiver_solution_for_midwives.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: I think this idea makes a lot of sense. Front-line workers, whether it be midwives or community health workers need to be equipped with the proper tools - mobile phones increasingly being one of them. I would suggest not being solution agnostic, and rather committing a needs assessment in each country of interest - to develop a program that a) uses a solution that integrates into the countries broader health information system strategy (if applicable) and b) considers how data will flow through this system from the district to national level. In this case, the focus of the project might be on defining the expanded role of the midwife, defining what is the most important data to collect, and how the data will be used and shared amongst relevant stakeholders (i.e. doctors, MOH), to ensure optimal patient care and broader health system strengthening.

Hima, you're spot on! The care giver solution shall be created in such a way that it easily integrates with the countries' broader health information system. On the other hand, for such a solution to scale, it has to be kept as standard as possible (which I believe is not difficult to do, as the structure of the data gathering questionnaire shall be pretty standard).

I aslo removed the suggestion for the route plan; as like Sarah says, in many countries, especially in the rural areas traffic is unpredictable and the locals know best how to navigate and play their week/day.

Sarah, thanks a lot for the feedback and the brilliant ideas! I adjusted the concept as follows: 1) added MoTeCH software as a possible option for data collection and record keeping. 2) deleted the GPS part of the concept (as you say, the much higher price of the Nokia phones might not justify the added value of the GPS functionality in our context). 3) using predoaded content to show videos. 4) work with a network of taxies that accept the transportation vouchers.

Hi Krassimira,At the moment, openXdata is best use as an information one-way tool -> think fill out a form and mail it in.  However, the MoTeCH software has many of the components of what your describing.  MoTeCH took the mobile piece of openXdata and coupled it with the Electronic Medical Record (EMR) capabilities of openMRS. This allows for centralized record keeping, and as you were asking, longtitudinal record keeping. That is, all entries are linked to a particular patient.So, with MoTeCH you can design forms on the web, register new patients, add further information about each patient and schedule additional reminders.MoTECH is basically an openMRS module (openMRS uses a module system so you can plug in the functionality you need.) www.openmrs.orgMoTeCH was also designed for maternal mortality so it's current version is centered around pregnancy etc.MoTeCH and openXdata run on much cheaper phones than what you've identified above. The current implementation of MoTeCH in Ghana is using Nokia 1680s I believe which cost about $35 (in Ghana).  If you want GPS, that's going to take you up to Nokia 2710NE minimum which is ~$150 - it would be interesting to know how much added value the GPS co-ordinates bring. There may be other ways to do the geolocation e.g. pre-map the area and codify all the villages or something.In terms of the other functionality that you would need to build out the full system you've described above: * Doctors identifying at-risk groups - I think would be a very easy addon to existing technology- you just queue-up a list of forms and have doctors log in and review - I think this would be just a couple of weeks of work to implement - really nice idea!  It may be worth talking to the MoTeCH team as I'm pretty sure there system auto-categorizes at-risk pregnancies based on form responses - but I'm not 100%* Integrating with calendar - nice idea - no idea how feasible this is to do completely automatically but could be a separate app that talks to server but Asha would have to initiate probably.  Maybe Nokia could design some extra features into the builtin calendar program.* Route plan - just my 2 cents on this one, whilst I think it would be good to monitor this, I think there's a lot of good research that shows that giving people autonomy over their work leads to greater satisfaction and productivity. You definitely want to check that all visits have been done - say for a particular week. But if it were me, I would let the Asha choose how to run her week - she probably knows crazy things that can never be codified - like on the 3rd tuesday of every month, raghu always leaves his herd of cows on the road to the village and the traffic always sucks - or something :D* Videos with visual instructions - great idea and easy. Starting to look at slightly higher phones - I would say ~$100 to do that. Also, transmitting video over the air is going to be really expensive in terms of bandwidth costs so I would suggest distributing mini sd cards with those on OR having them loaded onto phone during training.* Ring tone reminders - you know I love ringtones :D* Vouchers - made me think of the concept which was all about SMS printers, but to be honest a little book of vouchers is probably much cheaper. However, I think this bit needs thinking through a bit for transportation - I'm guessing a random bus driver is not going to accept a voucher that he doesn't know if he'll get reimbursed for. I wonder how lifespring do transportation.Anyway, hope this is useful.Feel free to ask more questions.Bird

Hi Krassimira, don't want to over-complicate your concept, but just wanted to point out the possible integration of other important mobile measurement devices (disease testing, ultrasound, etc.) down the line, especially as these devices continue to become cheaper and more portable as evidenced by various posts during the inspiration phase.

Sarah, thanks for the great comments. I really like openXdata and especially the fact that there is a geo locator and the system knows where the field worker is located; thanks for sharing this info. I was wondering: 1) assume a HCW collects data from pregnant women using this technology and uploads it real time. A few moths later, as the pregnancy develops, the HCW has to add a few more things about the mom or enter some comments about certain pain the expecting mom experiences. Is there a chance to edit and update data with openXdata? 2) I saw in the case study from Pakistan that the data is stored in a database. Now, I can imagine that based on some logic, the system generates alerts for the risk pregnancies and send them back to the midwife/HCW- do you think something like this is possible with openXdata?

Love this idea! Just some additional info as a comment - some other open-source technologies out there which might fit your bill.* MoTeCH - http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/mobile-technology-for-community-health-motech/ - an openMRS module that can handle the alerts and adding patients but I believe* openXdata - for collecting data on low-cost mobile phones - www.openxdata.org  Very similar to Nokia Data Gathering, has been widely used in a number of developing countries for CHWs collecting data (Disclaimer: I am paid to work on openXdata, but I started working on it because it's great - just wanted to be transparent)
Albert, thanks for the feedback! I would love to see this concept working!:-)

Krassmira, I think this is a great idea! Well done. Again relating to my comments on other posts, we found some of our biggest frustrations in clinics being bad administration, and horrendous record-keeping. I think moving the record-taking process into the community, whilst at the same time keeping the records central and digital, will definitely streamline the sifting process for at-risk pregnancies.Well done!
Excellent concept Krassimira! I really like the "proactive" approach, and the visuals idea too.

Avi, thanks for posting the research paper! Great find! I found these two findings from the research quite important: 1) the dialogue videos on a mobile phone might be much more "easy to consume" compared to lecture videos. 2) importance of training- might not necessarily know what to ask, how to engage the family of the expecting mother.
Nice one Krassimira: A Tricorder for midwives!Check out Divya Ramachandran's research on appropriate visual tutorials:http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~divya/research/firstdays/overview.html
Great mash-up, Krassimira!

cellphones_as_incentive_and_compliance_m.description: A cell phone with SMS and location technology will provide sustainable buy-in and compliance monitoring for the key stakeholders in maternal health: mother and father. This program offers free cellular service for both mother and father, leveraging SMS messaging as an education and compliance tool for key health outcomes and employing free voice service as an incentive for active participation.
cellphones_as_incentive_and_compliance_m.creator: 2c9b202e91e5d4aef00eff984a975004

comments.text: Great system thinking! I was wondering what could be in it for the mobile operators to encourage them to give discounted/free time away? Could it simply be that, since the mobiles locations are monitored anyway, could the operators be allowed access this data which they could use to understand how to best create the coverage structure - where to place transmitter masts etc? Maybe they don't need an incentive, but it was the only maybe gap I could see in the concept, you've really successfully thought through all the other facets, nice one!

Hi, don't know whether you've seen this but JPAL have done a pretty rigorous study   on incentives, showing "Study results indicate that offering families in resource-poor settings small, non-financial incentives in addition to reliable services and education is more effective than providing services and education alone." Source: http://www.povertyactionlab.org/evaluation/improving-immunization-rates-through-regular-camps-and-incentives-indiaThey have other studies on incentives, but haven't had time to read them yet.
I might be being a bit thick what are they being incentivised to participate in?
Hi Matt, how about an add-on like this to increase incentive, engagement, and education, and behavior change: http://texttochange.org/sites/default/files/Picture%203.png , http://texttochange.org/
I really like the built in incentive structures here to ensure use of the system!
Wow Matt! Great to have an OpenIDEATOR on board who develops management systems for a clinic that provides free healthcare in rural Haiti. Great consideration on incentives and motivators here.

cellphones_as_incentive_and_compliance_m.title: Cellphones as incentive and compliance mechanism for maternal health

what_if_we_empowered_the_dads_to_get_inv.description: What if we approached maternal outcomes by learning from and empowering the dads?  Here is a short video we did at IDEO in Munich to get inspired about childbirth.  But instead of talking to the mothers, we talked to the dads to get their take on it.
what_if_we_empowered_the_dads_to_get_inv.creator: 1c42f9c1ca2f65441465b43cd9339d6c

comments.text: Thank you for making this video.  It is a really great perspective to have.  It is interesting that a common thread through the Dad's experience was a feeling of being out of place and unsure of what to do, both in the months leading up to delivery and while at the hospital.  My friends who have gone through this experience shared a similar story of having their energy, anticipation and emotion build up and not having a specific role to play to contribute.  It makes sense that this process would leave you feeling either numb or distracted because the closer they got to the big moment, the less and less they knew about exactly what they could do serve the maternal health and wellbeing of their partner.  While it is completely natural that the majority of the specific directions are directed to the mother so that she can prepare for pregnancy and birth, it seems like there are really incredible opportunities to be had in giving fathers similarly specific instructions on how they can serve their wives in ways that go beyond the types of preparations that the individuals in this video describe as being less than useful.  What specific, practical instructions could be given to fathers that could allow them to channel their emotion and energy into meaningfully improving the maternal health of their partner before, durring, and immediately following birth?   Perhaps hospitals could register the father's cell phone on file and send time-appropriate tasks, checklists, or reminders to him via text message that could serve  as a reminder to him about what he should do to help his wife (buy certain foods, pick up medications, prepare a clean space for the baby in the house, etc).  It could even be interactive where he has to confirm he has done certain crucial tasks by responding to the text.  If the country does not have strong gender equality, then this program and the importance of the instructions might be best explained to the father by male doctors or respected community leaders.At this stage in any fathers life, it seems as though he might gladly welcome (and perhaps even be desperate for) a steady stream of actionable tasks.

Thank you for making this video.  It is a really great perspective to have.  It is interesting that a common thread through the Dad's experience was a feeling of being out of place and unsure of what to do, both in the months leading up to delivery and while at the hospital.  My friends who have gone through this experience shared a similar story of having their energy, anticipation and emotion build up and not having a specific role to play to contribute.  It makes sense that this process would leave you feeling either numb or distracted because the closer they got to the big moment, the less and less they knew about exactly what they could do serve the maternal health and wellbeing of their partner.  While it is completely natural that the majority of the specific directions are directed to the mother so that she can prepare for pregnancy and birth, it seems like there are really incredible opportunities to be had in giving fathers similarly specific instructions on how they can serve their wives in ways that go beyond the types of preparations that the individuals in this video describe as being less than useful.  What specific, practical instructions could be given to fathers that could allow them to channel their emotion and energy into meaningfully improving the maternal health of their partner before, durring, and immediately following birth?   Perhaps hospitals could register the father's cell phone on file and send time-appropriate tasks, checklists, or reminders to him via text message that could serve  as a reminder to him about what he should do to help his wife (buy certain foods, pick up medications, prepare a clean space for the baby in the house, etc).  It could even be interactive where he has to confirm he has done certain crucial tasks by responding to the text.  If the country does not have strong gender equality, then this program and the importance of the instructions might be best explained to the father by male doctors or respected community leaders.At this stage in any fathers life, it seems as though he might gladly welcome (and perhaps even be desperate for) a steady stream of actionable tasks.
Interesting comments!  nice to get the other perspective.. Thanks for sharing!!
Wow. Thanks for creating this Andra and thanks to the IDEO dads for sharing such a personal experience.

text4baby_a_us_based_mobile_service_for_.description: If you are pregnant or a new mom, text4baby can help keep you and your baby healthy. The service sends free SMS text messages each week, with health info, timed to the due date or the baby's date of birth.
text4baby_a_us_based_mobile_service_for_.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: great idea!  several friends have subscribed to a site that notifies them what size fruit or vegetable their baby is during the course of their pregnancy.  Maybe there's an easy way to turn this into an MMS (multimedia message service) to help the mother understand how their baby is developing, and let them share that with friends and family more easily.

@Vincent, check out the concept I just posted called SMS Pregnancy Journal. Could this be the communication coming from the mum to the service?http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/sms-pregnancy-journal/
Also featured in the New York Times yesterday  http://nyti.ms/gd96QU

When I saw this new challenge, this is one of the first inspirations I thought of too. I think it's a great example of using a low-cost way to communicate to expecting mothers, since in developing countries, many people already have cell phones. Plus texting is easier to implement (vs. smart phone applications). I think the discussion about exploring the options of providing this service is different languages would make this even more beneficial too.
Very cool Haiyan. Although 2-way interaction is ideal, I must say that this is a great baseline for providing knowledge and behavioral nudges at the most relevant times.

Great idea! Literacy, one way communication and different languages. In South Africa we have 11 offical languages. Maybe a toll free number funded by a service provider in conjunction with private and goverenment partnerships?
It's too bad this is one-way and does not answer questions. Also, I wonder if literacy would be a big issue in low-income countries, perhaps these would need to come with pictures/diagrams.
That's a great example. I think text messaging is a good way of communicating in developing countries. More people have access to that, than to mobile internet.

text4baby_a_us_based_mobile_service_for_.title: Text4Baby - A US-based mobile service for pregnancy information

comments.text: Important insight regarding literacy rate. Voice...as well as video...could help overcome this limitation. (I realize that I'm disregarding the network capabilities)

Thanks for posting Avi. Helped bring home to me how SMS is not appropriate in some areas due to not only low illiteracy, but also because of lack of data network coverage (even though the voice signal may still be pervasive).
The potential of this service is very interesting, Avi, was a great find!

your_fetus_just_texted_you_14_weeks_bone.description: Might we bolster maternal awareness of prenatal development with weekly text messages that provide updates on typical fetal progress and needs. A deeper sense of connection? Would we want to even include representative ultrasound photos and coach with regard to nutrition, etc.? What does a mother need to know and would she make better choices if she felt even more connected to the status of her unborn child?? Did I just say "status update" from your fetus? Tone would need to be right and humor probably isn't ideal. Perhaps this rant will inspire something better...?
your_fetus_just_texted_you_14_weeks_bone.creator: 68c03a76152dc53fdd2c7c7ab07f2721

comments.text: I totally heart this idea.  Combined with what I just read about the folks in Bangladesh, I think its brilliant!

I like this idea - couple of questions: would it be designed to educate about foetal development for it's own sake (is that important)? would it be to encourage nutrition of mothers (how do we adapt ithat for areas and amount of money people have?)?
That's great! I think every parent-to-be would love to have something like this ;)

your_fetus_just_texted_you_14_weeks_bone.title: YOUR FETUS JUST TEXTED YOU: 14 weeks, bones hardening, may start sucking my thumb.

free_maternal_health_care_clinics_3_in_1.description: Here in South Africa rural villages are far between each other and spread out. So free mobile and stationary clinics are impreative to ensuring healthy families and communities. This also drives the HIV awareness and distribution of condoms which is a huge concern for South Africa. Lastly it allows for the creation of employment from the drivers, hostel managers and nurses. A large percentage of South Africans cannot read and write, however that same percent own cell phones!
free_maternal_health_care_clinics_3_in_1.creator: b0f109937184d90545a927ea69a41951

comments.text: Yes, sounds like a option! The communities are scattered and regional meetings could be held like church, where a community "mothers" or "Phone lady" could be waiting along with other basic serives. Maternal health and health in general can be dealt with in this manner?

On the issue of literacy, I am thinking that communities could come up with the same street-up role they created with mobile phone services: the "Phone Lady" model. What if every single community had a person whose role would be to read and deliver messages, alerts or diagnostics received via mobile phones?

free_maternal_health_care_clinics_3_in_1.title: FREE maternal health care clinics - 3-in-1 approach

phone_pool.description: A pool of pre-loaded phones for women to use within each village.
phone_pool.creator: 49d75f861bdf99e6736c5f3f85e41b62

comments.text: What a nice idea. In line with Sarah's comment it could have a kind of what to expect when your'e expecting app that pops up to let you know what you may be experiencing at different points of the pregnancy and symptoms that should cause concern.

I think it would be great to incorporate some simple things like a text service where you text a question, and someone calls you back with advice. And some sort of calendar app that reassures you what should be happening at the moment.

Nice idea! To get to scale quickly, I think you could tap into existing micro-finance / micro-insurance networks where the **structure** of handling shared/pooled resources already exists.Maternity coverage is often a problem for micro-health insurance providers. Perhaps this intervention could help them address the challenges of early warnings & high-risk pregnancies and thereby enable them to provide better coverage.

i like this a lot. i think this could work with non-smart phones too. i like the idea of using pre-owned phones too. it's like tom's shoe idea, but for cell phones. very simple idea Jessie but really good!
This also could be linked to the idea of donating second-hand smartphones...I like your build Halyan, how about starting a wave of pro-bono work for app developers?

Jessie, this is a great idea! I love how this could be a pool of phones that circulate within a community or within a region. We can get around issues of catering to mobile technologies around on the ground as we would be providing our own.I think there's also a service component to this - what is needed to run this Phone Pool service? And also, what are the apps that these phones could be pre-loaded with in order to support maternal health? (Maybe we could ask for app-providers to donate their apps)

phone_pool.title: Phone Pool

performance_based_pay_for_health_care_pr.description: Performance-based pay provides monetary incentives to health care workers who deliver on set targets. For instance, mobiles could be applied to similar programs like Rwanda’s performance-based initiative for traditional birth attendants. In the national program, attendants who bring pregnant women to hospitals for delivery or accurately refer emergency cases to hospitals receive cash payments as reward.
performance_based_pay_for_health_care_pr.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: I just came across a real-life example of this idea: http://t.co/xtrznrpThe Grameen Foundation incentivizes its Community Knowledge Workers with supplemental performance based income in Uganda.
Yes Meena! I was also thinking maybe airtime (this could be implemented in collaboration with mobile operators)?

And I wonder if there could be further soft incentives  kind of like DQ points on OpenIDEO? Some kind of badge of honour for HCW based on performance? Maybe SMS announcements to the whole team of the current highest performer?

performance_based_pay_for_health_care_pr.title: Performance-Based Pay For Health Care Providers

battery_packs_to_charge_ahead.description: Develop sustainable (battery) pack mobile phone charger program to offset tiny villages / homes with no to limited electricity.
battery_packs_to_charge_ahead.creator: b83a4fb93e64e6e58d4f5c7786aec381

comments.text: A power bike wheel developed by MIT:  http://smrt.io/hSQ1FX

Just spotted my bike in the garage.  What's incidence of bikes in emerging markets?  Translating the flashlight power crank idea to charging a phone - make a connect to bike and pedal the charge.What are essential items found in village homes.  What cooking utensils, appliances?  Would be great to identify basic items and do a MacGyver innovation.  That would start with what's in a village, living space.  While want to develop total new technologies, maybe look back before moving forward?

Charging seems to be the big issue.  Some thoughts:  Phones sold w large battery packs -- like community DieHard battery - boat battery thinking.  Reconfigured to hold multiple phones -- guess that's like a charging station - but more flexible and ownable.  The second picture shows a no battery, hand crank flashlight.  Wonder if this crank low tech can be applied to phone?  I would think that personal ownership of charging would be important and wonder if a more community driven ATM like charging station not the best?  Bigger Q - how many hours can you build into a phone - longer charge than current US models?  If can build 50 hrs - maybe the phone becomes a throw-away - or provides exchange with recharge -- a 2 phone home.  Something to thing about -- that's why should 1 phone be the only solution - make it a 2-for with 1 being recharged while access to another.  If phones cheap enough and can last longer w charge - etc.  Didn't a camera brand do similar promo years back?  Might be too odd a thought?

Further inspiration could be taken from the low-cost solar lighting domain  currently a lot of folks developing business models for this in India and beyond. One example is d.light: http://www.dlightdesign.com/ Distribution, maintenance, micro-finance models are frequent considerations for these enterprises. Also some thoughts over on this earlier inspiration: http://bit.ly/hyPCSh I like your idea around availability through accessible channels. In India free charging stations are quite prevalent in urban centers  frequently sponsored by telcos  though this is less likely in rural locations where power supply can be scarce/intermittent.
Second picture = crank flashlight. Wind-up to power light.  Same for phone charger?

The PH-5 lamp was designed in 1925 for the Paris World Expo. The shades were designed to cover the ugly bulb w/o seeing it and the inside of the fittings were colored in shades of red and blue so the bulb/light could absorb the natural colors of the sun - making people feel good under a manufactured bulb.  The inspiration of this lamp reflects upon the inspiration for reusable  phones - charged by the sun (solar) or other means (unknown).  The simple wires keep the shades together as the 'wires' of communication (phone) link/connect people.  The design and shades have passed the test of time - being over 95 yrs old and still popular design.  Simple and beautiful.

Interesting thoughts Lisa! We look forward to hearing more during our Concepting Phase. In the Inspiration Phase we aim to collect examples of existing products, services, systems etc. Some have mentioned solar power. Perhaps you have an example of existing power generating devices which will inspire folks in the next phase?

comments.text: Thanks Meena. I like your comments! Trying to keep it simple at a first glance...
Great stuff Kirk! I like how you've simplified things into Connection + Knowledge then built up form there into a comprehensive concept.

Thanks Sarah for the comment...I've been thinking about how to target the areas of most critical need, in the simplest possible way...using the less is more approach. I like how you're thinking about the other half (or 2/3's, to be exact!) of HWC's and midwives.Most of the deaths fall into only a few categories: improper delivery practices, infection etc. Although we can program devices to do pretty much anything, it seems that we would want such an emergency device to focus solely on saving lives. Addressing the network capabilities and battery life is still important...I didn't really discuss it much here...

Nice concept Kirk! I am also imagining a similar interface for HCWs and midwives, with, on the left side, kind of a 'crowdsourced' map of surrounding patients (and maybe emergency situations), and, on the right side, the same access to information with a focus on symptoms, and how to address them (1. knowing the possible causes, 2. linking them to potential treatments).

the_art_of_storytelling_has_been_an_enga.description:
Education plays a key role in improving maternal health in childbirth and neonatal care.

How can we educate the socially and economically disadvantaged sections of society who do not have the privilege of literacy?

Instead of designing a "top down" technology-centered educational program, can we use technology to provide engaging and motivational content that leverages existing cultural and ritualistic practices that are more innate to that social segment?

comments.text: amazing comments!Krassimira, It's a very good approach! Incentives in cash is good, but if we try others then this. I don't know, as a competition for points. Each people who indicates a pregnant women gain points, the women earn points if she come all pre-natal sections. And in the end with the points she can change by some electronic for home or cloths for the baby.

I was thinking along this lines: what if we give the mom small monetary incentives to deliver her first child in a hospital- let's say, for example, 20 USD. Once she sees that giving birth in the hospital is safe and clean, she will be encouraged to give birth to her next kids in the hospital as well and see a doctor for pre-natal and post-natal care; in this case she will be charged a small fee of let's day 10USD for every next child...A schema like this will overcome the initial barrier to spend moneyn and the woman will "experience for herself". Thoughts on this?

Good Point Diogo! Also, one point that is really interesting in the microfinance concept is not just the fact to lend money, but it's possible to lend any service/tool that can help people in their activity. So,instead of lend hammers or hoes, maybe "teach" basic medical process to a specific villagers by cellphones and they could take lent any specific medical tool and use that on the his/her village. Maybe, also, like a job.

comments.text: Mokeira...nice idea with the Bonga points! I live in Kenya and I'm very familiar with them... However, even if you save points for years and are a busy caller, you generally don't get much value for them. However, its a great idea and could be incorporated in the concept. Thanks

Sounds good. I have actually conducted extensive studies on informal groups and how they save together.  They are a huge phenomenon in Africa and so why not leverage such groups like this concept is proposing to do something towards maternal healthcare? I think this has good potential because the group members already contribute some money regularly towards social welfare of their members and also some groups are doing projects in healthcare.  Consider also pooling contributions from loyalty schemes? For example in Kenya there is Bonga points which people accumulate from usage of airtime and can redeem for all manner of prizes such as airtime, phones, etc. Maybe people can now redeem for the healthcare insurance certificate? And anyone can contribute their own points towards members of the community who cannot afford the healthcare?

Anna  liking how this builds on how many people in low-income contexts globally use informal community savings schemes already. We looked at this during our research at Mumbai slums a few years back. Great thought to introduce insurance and mobile technology to the mix!
Nice idea, other than financial concerns do you have any data on what the other sources of stress are in this context?

fcaebook.description: Facebook has been a form of communication for years and probably will be for many more, What we are overlooking is that it isn't just at gateway for communication. comments.text: True that Facebook can be a good place to get the word out on this topic.  But instead of a promoting just this topic on FB, how about a fanpage for openIDEO.  That way we are more apt to reach critical mass on a variety of issues.Relative to this particular project, though, I think social networking is a good way to go to get these mothers the right health information, support, etc.  But FB is web a and APP driven which would require computers of smartphones.  For an issue that is wide spread in the third world, I think social networking through SMS is a more practical way to go.

Hey Kirk  that's a great idea  your offer to share image files for others to use. Might be nice if you post them to the Community Forum: http://bit.ly/hoNJ4s You'll be the first! You can attach the file and give a brief description that they are images which can be used on the Maternal Health + Mobile Technology Challenge. We love this kind of community spirit and I'd be happy to promote the post for you!
Intriguing concept Kirk! Very interested as to what sensing (as Albert pointed out) and energy supply technologies (solar?) could be utilized for this.

Thanks for the comments.@Albert. I'm glad that you recognized that nuance...I was attempting to put myself into their shoes. The midwives are stretched thin and could leverage a tool like this to maximize their effectiveness, particularly in managing the limited asset of time.And you're right about the monitor...as long as the device collects and displays the information for the midwife (it could be a phone, iPad-like screen like device etc.).@Krassimira: Thanks for connecting the dots. I think the idea of combining the two is excellent; it fits together like a puzzle. The bracelet elegantly addresses several of the most critical issues-- literacy, data / tracking, identification -- in a simple manner. I still wonder if and how simple devices could regularly monitor the patients' vital signs? It seems that a bracelet could measure pulse and temperature, which may be enough.I need to tag this concept to the one you suggested, as well other ideas that were inspiring, particularly Sarah's. (I posted it yesterday before rushing to class!)@Meena & Bernie: Thanks for the nod of encouragement...visualizations definitely help us communicate. I like to draw stuff! (I can make the files available if folks want to copy and paste the images into their new ideas / concepts)
Really Nice Kirk, the visualization is delightful.

Kirk, there was a great inspiration posted in the community that could be leveraged for your concept: http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/using-cellphones-to-improve-healthcare-delivery-/What do you think?
Great stuff Kirk! Loving the visualisation too  get's so much across in a quick glance which engages folks to read further.
Kirk, I think this is a great concept. In the inspiration phase there were a lot of ideas pointing out the importance of the midwives in the remote communities.

Great idea! I like the idea that monitoring and assessment that can be performed by an automated system is done, with only abnormalities  reported to a midwife. A common misconception is that we merely need more trained personnel in rural communities, but often personnel are preoccupied with what are essential normal pregnancies, or healthy patients. If an automated system can sift these, the workload will surely be diminished on actual personnel, who can attend to those who need their care more.Good idea! It would be interesting to think around monitors that will be needed to do the assessment. CTGs, Fetal heart rate monitors, blood-pressure monitors, and the maintenance of these.

comments.text: Great idea... but I'm not sure I see the clear link to cell phones.I have a concept up that would probably work well with this that is call about cell phones but not about this form of infrastructure. Whether it's mine or not, I think it's worth combining this idea with mobiles to both arrange appointments and, following an appointment, continue tips and continuity of care.

I see your point, and i was reading about for some inspiration, and I found this project. http://www.netsquared.org/projects/safe-motherhood-project-senegal You might found this inspiring, it might help you to refine the concept

Hi! Nice concept. What about a bigger tent for a time of consultation? Like the one that you can unfold and actually go into? What about the equipment to save a new-born child, like a basic incubator or a CPAP? I think it is quite important to choose the standard equipment carefully.

I really like this concept Alessandro, and the level of details you have gone into. I like the tent idea for privacy, and I think the power issue is definitely worth looking into.  One question maybe: why 2 HCWs for 1 patient?

cellphone_games_for_education_on_healthc.description:
There is a lot of on going projects for games to improve health education. A game is a funny way to learn and to simulate problems.
All games and simulators are very good ways to train people in some kind of situation. For example a Flying simulator can train the pilot to emergency problems without putting his life in risk.
A game that put a person in a health problem situation can train that person to react correctly in a real case. Moreover, the person will do that just without knowing that! In a first view is just a funny game.
cellphone_games_for_education_on_healthc.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751

comments.text: I think games are a great way to educate. I was also wondering if there was a way to incorporate earning points/money towards paying a midwife when playing the "educational game." Free Rice (http://freerice.com) donates 10 grains of rice through the World Food Programme for each right answer on their site. While 10 grains isn't much, with lots of people playing it can really add up. They currently have 6 subjects you can play (art, geography, language learning, math, chemistry, and english). What if there was a healthcare category?

Thanks for the comment Miguel! I think games is a good way to teach people! If we have good ways to product more interactiveness using simple tools, it will be amazing!By the way, very nice project this Playpower!

Good Inspiration Diogo! This is kind of interesting, because I had the opportunity to know personally a project in US called Playpower.org ( http://playpower.org/ ). After the expired patent of Nintendo Video Game, 8bits Chips started to be put in keyboard and simulate computers. This keyboard in China cost 10 box. So, Playpower started to develop aid education games to help children to learn while they are playing. Maybe, this idea could use for cellphones...Nice!

comments.text: Hey Alessandro, I came across this article today that shows how the iron deficiency has been solved in Cambodia- a minimal solution with a huge impact- http://www.therecord.com/news/local/article/624229--canadian-s-lucky-iron-fish-saves-lives-in-cambodia. I thought of you immediately as I remember you were very passionate about solving the iron deficiency problem in low income communities...

Thank you, Krassimira. I intended at the time of the challenge, add a new concept: it would be a iron mobile phone, that follow in the same box, with a real phone, and was similar to this. But how this concept (iron pot) has not had much impact, I gave up on the other.
Having fun with and adding to your idea, I thought an iron insert for pots/pans would be useful.
Ok, thanks for the hint;) I will think of a new concept.

Krassimira, i like the idea of cell phone rental. Why do not you develop a new concept? Think of something like the new models of mobile phones for the elderly and children available in the market!As for the pot, I think it would be possible to rent them, but I find it a bit unfair ... the best would be if families could really stay with them, and continue to benefit their health.

Alessandro, thanks for the elaboration! What if we make the pan+ the phone not for purchase, but for "rent". In this case, women in the community can borrow from the health center the pan and the phone. The phone could be used by the expecting mom, she can view educational videos, call another mom in the vicinity from a list of up-to-date numbers, etc and when she gets her baby, she returns the pan + the phone to the health center. The phone will be equipped with an emergency number  + taxi number, that are free of charge. As far as the pan is concerned, it would be used by different families, but very often families cook and eat together, so I don't think there will be a hygiene problem with that. What do you think?

No... I did. I think this is a roasting pan, Avi. A pot is more interesting because the daily use increased the release of nutrients. We must also consider the friction of the spoon to the bottom of the pan during cooking. But I liked the format. I had thought of something close to it. Thanks!
I think something went wrong ... put the link here, please, Avi.
Alessandro, Google "Lodge Tableware Oval Mini-Server" an there you have your packaging:)

My idea, if this concept is that pot should reach women as a bonus for purchasing a mobile phone. The phone may have been purchased by her husband, a neighbor, a distant parent.My idea is to make affordable, first, the pot and information about their benefits, even if indirectly. In some places, it is very difficult to find an iron pot. Here in Brazil, is common in some states and rare in others.It is a concept to generate assessibilidade the product. The mother may say, "I do not have an iron pot, because I have no money to buy the phone, but I know who bought it and could lend me one in the pregnancy period."In this concept, the pot is literally the packing. Of course, if you have a better idea, do not hesitate to add it! :)

Alessandro, my question was not well formulated, sorry;): the idea is to sellthe iron pots, right? In this case, we have to sell them to the husband/ mother/father in law, as women rarely have their own money and need to ask for permission to buy.... and I was wondering how we can do this?

I do not know if I understand Krassimira ... who wins a pot, if it really is a low income family will probably use it. No matter if it's made of iron, aluminum or other material. The iron pot, however, requires some care, so that, for example, do not get rusty. And that should be taught.So, I think, in most cases, the usage is, of course, by necessity.In other cases, the conviction must coming from the explanation of the risks of anemia, etc.. Do not know if I answered, if not, please rephrase that question, ok? Sorry... my english is bad...Thank you!
Alessandro, I'm thinking what message could we send to the decision makers in the family to convince them- typically the husbands/ mothers in law? Thoughts?

natural_childbirth_two_projects_primal_h.description: Michel Odent is a french obstetrician, graduated from the University of Paris; in the mid 80's he moved to London where he launched the water birth and founded the Primal Health Research Center. He was the first to submit a paper on the initiation of breastfeeding within the first hour after birth, there exposes the need for colostrum, which is the first milk and contains antibodies to protect the newborn against disease, as well as being lower in fat and higher in protein than ordinary milk.! The Primal Health Research Center is now part of a biggest association called Birthworks. Another organization called CIMS (Coalition For Improving Maternity Services) and their mission is “ to promote a wellness model of maternity care that will improve birth outcomes and substantially reduce costs. This evidence-basedmother, baby, and family-friendly model focuses on prevention and wellness as the alternatives to high-cost screening, diagnosis, and treatment programs.”

comments.text: I really like this idea. It's not really a full concept on it's own - you need to show how the connection to the outside world through that woman would work. However, you have identified a massive constraint that I think is important.  Our core target isn't people who can be slung an ipad.  Worth an applause from me.Maybe you should check out my concept:http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/mother-mati-2019-s-phone-and-flipbook/I've tried to stay low fi and seems that you could pretty easily link our together.

Hi, building on this further, there are still many places in the world that don't have cellphone coverage. Perhaps you could work with this, providing the cell-phone stationed in the village as you describe, and then, providing coverage with a solution like FirstMileSolutions http://www.firstmilesolutions.com/products.php where a van comes round periodically and provides temporary connectivity (I'm not sure whether you can do this with a mobile gsm base station as opposed to a mobile internet). This wouldn't help in the case of an emergency, but perhaps it would be sufficient to get people fresh information periodically and to alert of an at risk pregnancy.
Interesting build, Hannah!

I love this idea because it works through existing social structures. Trust in the source of information plays a huge role in people's willingness to adopt new behaviors, so it makes sense to use neighbors and community leaders as the conduits for this knowledge. I have a thought to add on the question of adapting this and other ideas for low-literacy contexts: voice mail! Health messages or instructions for procedures sent via voice mail have two main advantages. First, you don't need to be able to read to understand them. Second, they can be replayed for memorization or to spread the word directly to multiple groups. I know one disadvantage of voice mail compared to text is the cost or perceived cost. I would love to hear of some innovative ideas for cost-sharing arrangements for these services.

a_woman_per_village_to_spread_the_word.title: A woman per village to spread the word

text4baby_model_provides_important_infor.description: An inspiring model is text4baby, a service that sends free text messages to pregnant women or whose mothers with babies that are less than a year old. The messages are tailored to the woman's stage of pregnancy or the age of the baby, and include important information and reminders related to health topics, such as useful phone numbers, tips about nutrition, and advice.
text4baby_model_provides_important_infor.creator: f0f73b6f8ceb734043ccc6fb0215fd20

comments.text: Perhaps in a low-literacy context, the text messages could consist of a phone number that, when the user calls it, is a hotline that reads off useful information about nutrition and medical emergencies. As to low-income, the mobile carrier should ensure that text messaging is free or low-cost, so that users can take advantage of the service without concern for their budgets.

Indeed Rachel  text4baby featured prominently in our Inspiration Phase. We're keen to see what this will provoke in the form of new ideas or mash-ups of existing ones during this Concepting Phase. How might you adapt this idea to the low-income, low literacy context?

text4baby_model_provides_important_infor.title: text4baby model provides important information to mothers

comments.text: Like that idea, Nicholas. The other great thing about these laptops is they have built in rechargeable solar and a hand crank for power. A computer free from the grid is mobile indeed! I saw one picture at a conference showing a village where cows were tied up to a contraption that turned the crank as the cows walked in a circle.  Ingenious.

language_free_storybook_of_a_woman_s_pre.description: Using a combination of savvy cartooning and characterization, create a storyline for pregnancy that at the very least covers what can normally be expected through the entire pregnancy process. The story would be created without words so that anyone can understand it, and would be focused on simple, yet memorable, concepts that instruct a woman on how best to bear a healthy child.
language_free_storybook_of_a_woman_s_pre.creator: 58f2039453eb0dec8a778e2b20eec20a

comments.text: These can be printed on cloth to enhance durability. Look for Meena's inspiration on grassroots comics.

Absolutely, the more characters that are involved then the more people that can relate to the story. My thinking was that you would follow multiple women through their pregnancy covering the different scenarios women find themselves in when they get pregnant. To answer your question about visual representation, my original thought was almost like a comic book or a flip book concept. Though, you could certainly turn one story into many different formats, creating an animation/video of the story, or having a deck of stacked cards that almost turns it into a game (you could even have people role play characters as an additional learning experience). I really think once the story is out there it can evolve into many different things.

Good idea - and also, stories are great shared experiences too. I believe it will be very valuable to create solutions that engage more than individual's alone..in the case of maternal health - the healthworker, the father, and so on?About the metaphor of a "storyline"..and the passing of time and pregnancy progress/development in general..what would be the best visual representation for it?  A book? A timeline? A deck of stacked cards? Something else? Any ideas?
Great idea David! We look forward to hearing more on this during our upcoming Concept Phase.

language_free_storybook_of_a_woman_s_pre.title: Language-Free Storybook of a Woman's Pregnancy

access_to_finance_for_local_doctors.description: Expanding local, affordable healthcare services will be key to the challenge, especially in cases involving complications. Expanding access to finance will be in turn be central to expanding these services. My idea focuses on increasing access to finance to rural doctors, who can then expand to provide delivery services and related supplies.
access_to_finance_for_local_doctors.creator: 56b804a4a1c89d0d53c01bcb3e1851ea

comments.text: Sounds like a great idea for countries with less developed public health care infrastructures (or ones with a functioning but very resource-poor system).  Not to imply that doctors aren't naturally motivated to perform high-quality work with as many patients as possible, but what would incent greater productivity and reach? Perhaps the loan repayment scheme/subsequent loans could factor in a doctor's increased impact? Just a thought.  Great idea!!

Hi, nice idea. The Indian School Finance Company http://www.isfc.in/ has been working in urban areas to provide financing to private schools so they can build capacity - improved facilities, teachers etc - with the idea that this will generate more revenue for the school - the reality being that many/most schools are private and this is a way to try and improve that education. I thought of this link for you because these are loans that are bigger than microfinance but not something that banks or other traditional credit markets are going to do - it seems like maybe that's what you need for the doctors - definitely seems to me that there's probably a finance gap there. Good idea!

the_suami_siaga_201c_alert_husband_201d_.description: I am an alert husband. Ready. Send. Guard. My wife is safe. My baby is healthy. My family is happy.
the_suami_siaga_201c_alert_husband_201d_.creator: c8716371472be3927ec507907285442d

comments.text: Thanks for all comments. Agree, kind of campaign may diferent in each culture and need observation before run a campaign programme.

Nice inspiration. Involving men on the childcare is so important. We have just to focus this kind of campaing in each culture. The men participation is different in many countries. There is some "open-minded" countries for men participation in childcare, but there are others that is more difficult.
Hi, Heni! Be welcome! The issue of father involvement was treated in another inspiration, but this is the first successful solution presented! Congratulations!
And great to be getting inspirations from Indonesia! Cheers Heni.

Great to read about a campaign specifically around increasing father involvement. Loved how the slogan stressed the interrelatedness of a safe wife, healthy baby, and happy family; and how communities were motivated to prearrange for transport, funding, and blood donors before an emergency strikes.

comments.text: Brainstorm away :DOn the girl band - I was thinking about a band of elders - seriously(!) - I've found that the mother-in-law can be a powerful influence during these times and often a decision maker - we'd have to get her excited about a ringtone too.local musicians - maybe it would even be possible to make software that you could capture the ringtone and distribute it as part of the workshop.

I was thinking about those NGO's bands, and if a girl band could touch more the womens in villages than o mixed band. This could be in microtone or macrotone. Just to power the influence on women!What if we have in this villages interventions contact with local musicians and they teaches they  how to play the song and the educational lyrics. With the ringtones  this could stay on people's head.Just brainstorming! :-)

midwife_partnerships.description: Providing support for midwives by partnering them with midwives in the US or Europe.
midwife_partnerships.creator: f86beae605f264a32bdb17a8ff33118b

comments.text: Hi Tania. Thanks for your comment. I didn't realise that midwives were often taught "on the job", I had thought that they had to undergo some medical training and they would therefore be literate. But since the idea is a telephone link, it would be through the spoken rather than the written word. I like your idea of matching midwives from similar cultures, as long as they could contribute the kind of knowledge / training about which I was talking...

Helen, this could be a key to develop a project but being midwife doesn't necessarily mean to be literate. In rural communities in Africa, Asia or Latin America, midwives learn and get experience from other women and practicing. Also, some of them speak dialects. Cultural differences and resources are also different. The connection could work if matching two midwives from similar cultures.
Simple and at a level that I believe would be effective. Great!

midwife_partnerships.title: Midwife partnerships

telling_a_story.description: This was a small school project done for UN summit on MDGs. The idea behind this project called "Tell a story" was to reach rural communities in India using popular story telling methods such as shadow puppetry, also extremely cheap to accomplish, which can address a broad spectrum of audience from children to elderly on Maternal and Child health without direct intrusion to their lives.
telling_a_story.creator: 3ba05f47ac7fe72c6ba2fe8e27d9112a

comments.text: This is brilliant Seema! If you want more DQ points you can use the Update button (on the right of your post) and link to posts like this: http://bit.ly/eZGy8Y using the Build Upon feature. It also helps everyone see the resonance between various inspirations.
Hi Seema, Thanks for sharing this inspiring concept - using popular and inexpensive media to educate a community.

telling_a_story.title: Telling a story

creating_a_sense_of_family.description: IDEO Palo Alto led a brainstorm in our office today to think through how to involve Dads in the maternal health process/experience. Here, two IDEOers explain the idea of how to use texting to create a sense of family.
creating_a_sense_of_family.creator: 6a75b6ebe0dd913f0971ada060e2f7ea

comments.text: Great idea IDEO Palo Alto.. when I read your concept, at first I thought this would be a difficult idea to be implemented in a low-income country, but then a project I know came to mind:"Noticias de mi Gente", a blog from an Ashoka Fellow from Guatemala, that tries to maintain migrant guatemalan communities in the US in touch with their culture of origin. He has created a blog, podcasts, photo galleries that provide the migrants with very valuable inputs about their roots.Its true that linking parents with their ancestors is a very powerful tool for them to understand their own context and moment in history, and will eventually help them planify their family better. I think that partnering with local websites like Noticiasdemigente.org will a be a great success to this idea, as it will also provide a bond with their community.

"Dads could receive text notices that help them piece together their family history." Can you give an example of such a text message? In many cases acquiring this information would seem to require some research--who would be doing this research?Regarding the idea about sending "updates and tips about how to keep their wives healthy and cared for during their pregnancy": why direct these messages at Dads in particular? If the wives have mobile phones, why not direct messages at them? (I imagine in some target communities, Dads have not traditionally been involved in childbirth.)
This is a great idea! Involving dads is extremely important.  Can't forget the other half. Love the text notice idea.
Just a quick update - Jake from our Palo Alto office is the brain behind this great concept. He'll be refining it very soon for all of us to enjoy!

I really like the dad outreach" idea. Its approaching the problem from a different angle to how it is usually tackled. Are there specific indicators of success  how do we know that this has helped maternal health? Whole family involvement can be really good and so how can we ensure, through this concept, that the mtother and baby benefit from educating dad?

Hi IDEO Palo Alto. Texting and family lineage is a great way to involve dads and the extended family in the health of mother & child. This approach has a lot of potential and can be fleshed out to create a substantial impact. For example, I believe there's ways to get the family & maybe even beyond to directly contribute (socially, financially, and otherwise), as mused about here: http://bit.ly/i1DJPy . Excited to see your concept develop!

Or maybe scheduled alerts to dads of what to expect while your wife is expecting. Like a text at three months to say what the average size of a baby is then and what to do to help your wife specifically at this time. It teaches fathers who may be under-educated about the process and also helps the mothers if the fathers help and assist the mothers using the suggestions.This could continue beyond birth, as well, as to what help they could be giving to the mother and child at that time.

Getting fathers involved is critical. Expectant fathers need education and guidance just as much as expectant mothers do. This is especially the case during hard/special needs pregnancies. Information on the baby's development, the mother's needs, doctor's course of action and recommendation, appointments but also information for preparing for post-pregnancy.  I agree with Lisa about it being interactive so that fathers can SMS if they have concerns or see problems during the pregnancy or after. Often women are seen as the managers of family health, it is important that we empower fathers and husbands for this task as well.

Getting the whole family involved is a great way to ensure the success of a solution. Children are often fearless with technology. Health care workers can use the opportunity to educate young girls and boys about what it takes for a mother to deliver a healthy baby. The family can SMS questions to health workers if they have concerns about something they see with their mothers.
Loving the lineage concept  great way to engage Dads  and indeed extended family members.
"Happy 1st b-day! Buy condoms!"...lol. Seriously though, good thoughts about how to keep dads involved beyond childbirth.

creating_a_sense_of_family.title: Creating a Sense of Family

cellphone_facilitated_community_emergenc.description: When someone suddenly faces a medical emergency such as a heart attack, generally the first actions are 1) bystanders asking “is there a doctor here” and 2) calling 911. In many cases, immediate response within minutes is critical for the success rate of lifesaving actions like CPR. To help find the nearest qualified person to help, the San Ramon Valley Fire Department in California just released an iPhone app that enables anyone that is CPR-trained to volunteer themselves as willing and able to help in an emergency. Then, when a local 911 call is received where someone needs resuscitation, dispatchers not only send an ambulance (which generally take 8 minutes to arrive), but also push notifications out to the IPhones of nearby volunteers that indicate the location of the emergency as well as any available automated external defibrillators.
cellphone_facilitated_community_emergenc.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Vincent, this is exactly what was brewing in my mind as well. I come from Kenya and sms apps work perfectly. I am sure that you have all heard about the MPESA phenomenon- http://www.safaricom.co.ke/index.php?id=250It works because our mobile penetration is at 60% going up. Even in rural areas where there is no power in every house, there is usually a general shop that offers charging services at a small fee. So Vincent, this would work perfectly if connections you suggested are powered by an SMS based app. A mobile based information service.At best, I think that the pregnant woman especially in rural and low income should be one to have this app working on her phone at a subsidised monthly fee. She could receive sms reminders about important check ups, vaccines etc that she should get. Close to birth especially, she and/or a local midwife can ask questions or call for a doctor's or expert midwife's advice.This can work just like the Mhealth service launched in Kenya just some days ago. See here: http://www.telecompaper.com/news/safaricom-launches-mhealth-service

From what read, not sure texting part of rural phones?  Or power strong enough to support apps.  But perhaps some colored coded system.  Or pre-loaded programs Come w phones w press of button, can get.  Maybe dial certain numbers and get #800 number - what to do?
This inspiration has great potential as a concept for maternity health, Vincent. So many different angles. Good find!

As someone employed in emergency management, I love this concept--the collaborative consumption of "resources" isn't/shouldn't be limited to libraries, Zipcar, etc. An individual's skill set and benevolence are resources that the community can tap into too. Great stuff.
Absolutely love this idea. It would be good to figure out how usual phones could automatically also send their positioning, especially if there are not many indicators as buildings or streets around.
Loving how local volunteers are co-opted by this Vincent!

cellphone_facilitated_community_emergenc.title: Cellphone-Facilitated Community Emergency Response

we_know_whom_are_you_takig_care_of_but_w.description: This concept pretends to improve the way the daily life of pregnant women in Burkina Faso is. Our solution aims to change the works the women daily do, by another person taking care of them. We know that they need to do this work, but what would happen if all of us join together to build a solution to these mothers? This project will be developed with the help of the world.
we_know_whom_are_you_takig_care_of_but_w.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: Thanks for the comments, Althow we didn't pass to the next round we would really like your feedback. Look at this update in the concept.http://prezi.com/n-d975f-johy/estudio/
Yeah i really like this concept, its really scary the positions these women adopt while working, love the process.

I certainly like the concept of educating expecting mothers on what type of work they should and shouldn't be doing...we might be able to call on youth or HCW's to help pregnant women out with the stuff they shouldnt be doing.  I'm thinking along the lines of how I used to shovel snow or mow lawns for elderly folks when i was young...they got needed chores done, and I had a part-time job.  Great concept!

voice_mail_4_baby.description: Text4Baby provides free text messages with to help moms through their pregnancy and baby’s 1st year. VoiceMail4Baby builds off of the Text4Baby concept by using Twilio to enable moms to receive either text or voice messages with helpful advice. VoiceMail4Baby can extend the reach of Text4Baby to also help illiterate moms.
voice_mail_4_baby.creator: 986367cab041526c6231636304ad25ce
voice_mail_4_baby.title: Voice Mail 4 Baby

mobilizing_indigenous_technology.description: The emergence of mobile platforms for education and information sharing presents an enormous opportunity to mobilize existing resources and urge a shift in the existing health paradigm.  Traditional healers and complimentary medical practitioners (a major source of care in low-income countries) equipped with mobile technologies can provide critical link to maternal health care.
mobilizing_indigenous_technology.creator: 8b331ee87480bd11ff01e6ae60a6f9e9

comments.text: I am glad you posted this, it is important to incorporate people's traditions into the solutions.  It would be great if the women in need of this service could tell us what they need or would like as well.  That way the proposed solutions really reflect the person or group that it was meant to assist.

mobilizing_indigenous_technology.title: Mobilizing indigenous technology

maternal_health_system_interface_points_.description: I started thinking about the greater maternal health network that has been addressed by all the awesome concepts that have been posted so far, and wanted to try to lay out this network in a way where I could start to wrap my head around all of the possible interface points in the network.  We have concepts posted that address almost all of these interface points...I just wanted to lay them out in one place and share them w/ everyone.
maternal_health_system_interface_points_.creator: 89f0fee17250dd3bf28ed7533c51edd1

comments.text: Dan  we love it when OpenIDEATORS think beyond the challenge guidelines and post stuff like this which helps others out. So we've loaded you up with 50Community Champion Bonus DQ points!
Interface Points, I like it =). Good way to think through the concepts and how they might be refined, work together, or be added upon.

Dan, you thought this one out! Bravo! I can see other concepts plugged into this. I'm glad you put it out there. Sarah came up with something similar (local networks)...check that one out too. And, there are some concepts floating around that use GPS-enabled tracking via graphic interface, which highlight the critical resources (hospitals, HCW's, other moms, pharmacies and hospitals).The diagram shows the critical connections within the network, and is making me also think about how each entity gets power for the devices.

maternal_health_system_interface_points_.title: Maternal health system - interface points diagram

From broken bones to tuberculosis, patients can now immediately notify doctors via text messages; in turn, medical professionals can access records and initiate treatment right away through mobile devices.
write_a_hello_message_and_give.creator: 206778bc91c46fa5881aa95455072617

comments.text: This is a cool project!You (from a developed country), gives your old cellphone to someone in Africa and write a hello message for her!This could be a good manner to improve their cellphone capabilities!In another inspiration, we agreed that the most part of cellphones there is like Nokia 100, that don't have so much resources, but with this kind of project it could be possible to have more powerful cellphones there!

write_a_hello_message_and_give.title: Write a Hello Message and Give!

comments.text: I like your comment Vincent :)And maybe we should find alternatives for countries where beer is not that popular...

Or maybe even a special/bundle pack of the milk & beer together? =P. This could be applied to other nutritious food and maternal healthcare products too. Just need to figure out the right milk/beer ratios to make sure enough is being spent for adequate milk, while still providing the beer incentive ;)

do_a_positive_deviance_inquiry.description: The method which Jerry Sternin applied in Vietnam gave rise to the Positive Deviance thinking. Together with the community, find the positive deviants who use unconventional behaviour or alternate ressources to improve maternal health. Let the community decide how these strategies can be spread and adopted.
do_a_positive_deviance_inquiry.creator: 729de80457ac4632667686c883e677ea
do_a_positive_deviance_inquiry.title: Do a Positive Deviance Inquiry

community_maternity_education.description: Maternity education and knowledge about health services would drastically improve maternal health across both high and low income countries. Mothers and support figures go to meetings where interested experienced mothers and healthcare professionals educate first time mothers on progress and possible complications of maternity. This is complimented with a nationwide SMS and radio awareness program to help those that cannot make the meetings.
community_maternity_education.creator: 93405661fa00bc8a27ce5f91938d3767

comments.text: You might want to take a look at mDhil and BabaJob as examples of business models to support SMS education/alerts (both based in India). Integration with an operator could work well, since many are focusing on value-added services as a way to differentiate in a competitive market. Something as simple as providing the service for free if you want to receive an alert once a week, and then options to receive a) more alerts b) access to Q&A with doctors c) reminders etc. Unfortunately, this would exclude the poorest of the poor, but potentially still be able to impact a subset.

Thanks for the build!Wow, mDhil is very similar to my idea and seems to be very organised and successful. BabaJob is also a very, very good idea for ways to help finance the women that join the program. I think the option to have specific Q and A's or consultations with the doctors for a fee is a great idea.

Hello there LilNinja. If the local community were to own a solar panel, 12-volt battery and a regulatorthen set up an association/co-operative shop, they could charge other people's mobile phones - for a fee of course. The percentage of mobile phone ownership is increasing, but often there's no electricity to charge the phones...so selling that service at a grass roots level will make money.Other services would be to sell phone credit...local kiosks can sell single text message services, and flat-rate local calls. They would then generate profit by adding a mark-up. It's also possible to rent of mobile phones units (people normally already have a personal SMS card). They can also charge radio batteries (important as the pollution/waste stream from disposible cheap imported batteries is high damaging pristine water aquifiers).Scaling up would be through a micro-shop selling other products and services - with a LED light at night so people could socialize and storytell ;-) An option could be to get initial investment costs (of a single PV panel, 12-volt battery and adapters for various mobile phone chargers) paid for through 100% aid funding or mico-loans and then make the group/community cover-off their operating costs (pay for black-board repair after year one, photocoping) and then try to make some extra cash to make it worthwhile for everyone. At a local level, this would perhaps make the project independent, self-reliant and focused on local village networks.maternal health education...linked to decentralised self-sustaining micro-economy hub/social space......using clean energy.

Thanks for the build! I know that there are some charity organisations that offer to install solar panels in rural areas that don't normally get electricity off-the-grid. This could be used to our advantage-perhaps get a solar panel and its installation donated. The kiosks can also offer services that are usually not provided to rural areas such as handset servicing(troubleshooting, e.c.t) and a form of a pay phone service. In the upscaled shops, the socialising factor can be expanded and food and drinks can be sold there- some of the radio shows and meetings can take place here as well. It'll make the idea of going to the meetings less forboding.

Thanks for the comments guys. They are really great and I've implemented them all into the Builds section of the concept. Jason: I'm curious to know if you have any more ideas on how to make the groups self-sustainable financially? At the moment, this concept spends money but recoups very little.

Lovely idea Lalli.Community meetings really are something special in Africa. I'm based in Mozambique and community meetings are great social event...many held under big trees with much formality and excitement. Reinforcing these meeting for women with maternity health information and knowledge sharing would be a great assetand support local civil society.All the tools, to make the project work (small handheld radios, mobile phones) are widely available in rural African countries so I thing the idea is totally do-able.Just thinking of a build to promote the concept in the field...and how viral marketing works over here : can t-shirts, caps and capalanas (local sarongs) be printed with the community group name, relevant phone numbers and radio station name/programme...and distributed locally? A kinda mobile bill-board crossed with a community group uniform.In terms of the limited access to electricity for mobile phone charging in many rural areas (more often than not, the mobile phone coverage is wider than the central electrical grid): Could the community groups be supported with off-grid power - a solar panel to top-up the phone charge? A mobile phone charging hub integrated as part of the decentralised mobile health centre...the radio could plug into it too (saving money for batteries) Mobile phone charging for a fee is a one of the few ways for local revenue/income generation in remote rural areas...and so if the group were to be able to generate and manage their income then the project could become sustainable by using the income to buy phone credit for Mothers-to-be, photocopying, buy batteries for radios etc.

Lalli, I like that you're creating multiple entry points for involvement and and offering different levels of involvement. I would encourage you to broaden radio to public outreach. Depending on the region/country, this could be anything from traveling puppet shows to a television show. The methods can be tailored to budgets, cultural expectations, and desired scale of impact. The idea of having a Q&A and capturing lessons (like Ben suggested) would stay the same.

I like the story telling elements of these ideas. Combined they can offer a range of solutions. The community aspect and the networking opportunities that this gives is what I think makes it exciting, how can these be brought out? With the radio, would it be a womens Hour show that wed look to make, how would you get listeners engaged to make it interactive. I agree with @mokeira about not losing the community aspect but I wonder whether we need a production company/radio professionals to ensure viability?

Hey there Lalli!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge!As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought into what might be involved. When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Its great that this is community based so that every community can tailormake to suit their circumstances and needs.  This aspect should not be lost.  Also what really adds value to this is the use of other media like phone and radio and I think this needs to be developed even more so as to really increase access as not everyone will be in a position to attend physically all the time.  For example community radio stations are a growing phenomena and this should be leveraged for such a concept even for live coverage of these sessions.

This is a great idea! It would be good to find a way to externalise all of the information too. Recording the radio broadcasts, various text questions and other useful information and creating a hub of information somehow could be a great asset. If you miss a broadcast it'd be great to know that there's somewhere you can ask for a copy either via cassette, CD or maybe even downloadable as a podcast if the phone/network is capable? It'd also mean the broadcasts wouldn't need to repeat themselves if the same questions keep getting asked.

Thanks for the comment! That's a great idea, especially as it's relatively cheap to send SMSs. I've been thinking this could be used in conjunction with the GroupMe Micro Health Network and Mom-to-Mom Mentor Matching

Great Lalli! And perhaps some of the community SMS networks which were highlighted in the Inspiration Phase could be used to notify local groups about upcoming meetings and spread ongoing locally-relevant messages. And maybe even support a buddy system between a pregnant mother and experienced other?
