I think most of NGO do that, but I not sure if they realizes that!Very good inspiration Miguel!

people_from_different_cultures_in_touch_.title: People from different cultures in touch influence so much each other - Personal Experience

mom_community_gardens.description: Community gardens organized, set up, and maintained by expecting mothers and 'mother mentors' in the community could be a good way to facilitate a mom to mom social network as well as provide nutritious foods for expecting mothers.
mom_community_gardens.creator: 89f0fee17250dd3bf28ed7533c51edd1

comments.text: I agree Dara...I think the garden paired w/ the shopping list would provide excellent information and actually guide mothers in getting the nutrition they need.
Food is always a fantastic way to connect people!  Perhaps this concept could be connected to the "visual nutrition shopping list" concept?

Thanks for the comments all!  I agree that something like this would work really well in conjunction with an education center where health care workers could meet, care for, and educate mothers, fathers, childen.  Having a central gathering place would open things up for a slew of mobile techs i think.

Dan, I really like this concept as it taps into the community spirit. I can also imagine that women could also sell some of the fruits/vegetables they grow in the local market. The money will be used by the Mom Community for purchasing birth kits, doc's consultations, trasnportation to health centers. They might even purchase a cell phone- the Garden's Community mobile phone and have it for common use.

Great stuff Dan! I'm a big fan of urban gardening in low-income contexts and covered examples in Kenya's Mathare slum late last year http://bit.ly/guIhHe  but really love how your concept turns it into a community/social network. And I can imagine this becoming a hub for visits by Community Health Workers too.

The moms could grow raspberries - red raspberry leaf (Rubus idaeus) tea is rich in iron and is used by many pregnant moms to tone the uterus in the last trimester! Maybe all the plants in the mom community garden (ginger, etc.) could be chosen for their beneficial effects on maternal health?
Creative combo of nutritious food and maternal community support Dan!

This is a great concept as it would help to establish a good sense of community, as well as life-long learning that will be passed to generations to come, while encouraging and sustaining good nutrition
Great Concept! I love the idea that the community garden offers the chance for moms and pregnant women to connect, while also providing nutritious food!

mom_community_gardens.title: Mom Community Gardens

dad_of_the_month_club.description: A good way to engage fathers to participate in and support maternal health activities might be to tap into their sense of friendly competition.  A reward-based "Dad of the month" program would be one way to do this.
dad_of_the_month_club.creator: 89f0fee17250dd3bf28ed7533c51edd1

comments.text: Don't give me props--this is all you, Dan!

I think certificates are a great idea.Building on this, anecdotally, once I remember I wanted to give a merit-based certificate for participation but I discovered it was more appropriate to give everyone a certificate. Although I felt that some people had clearly participated or learned more than others the training was seen as a group exercise and certificates should be given to the group. So I love the idea, but I would also propose a more collective certificate for the cultural contexts where that's the done thing.

dad_of_the_month_club.title: Dad of the month club

an_audio_guide_through_maternity.description:
Imagine the audio guide that you get when you enter a museum. You punch a number and you get to know all about the statue of Venus de Milo or Van Gogh’s Sunflowers in front of you.
If we consider pregnancy a journey that a woman embarks on, then we can equip her with a simple to use rented mobile phone where she can listen to audio narratives and watch short videos related to different stages of pregnancy in her own language.
an_audio_guide_through_maternity.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Disney had an interactive wireless plush toy called "Pal Mickey" that would activate when you neared an attraction to give yo info and tips - Maybe there could be "Pal Minnie" to accompany the journey of pregnancy?:http://disneyworld.disney.go.com/guest-services/pal-mickey/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9oLoTYu4-Xk

Kirk, thanks for the comment! As for the pre-recorded content, I was thinking  of sort of an application on a mobile- you enter the week of the pregnancy and the application calculates which information to push to the mobile device. Is this along the lines you thought?
Lots of fab features here Krassimira  and nice build Kirk!

Krassimira, the idea made Mona Lisa smile! Your description really made it come alive. I like how the concept uses verbally communicated messaging to address the literacy issue. James' idea of tracking the progress is great, as the pregnancy patterns are fairly predictable. At some point I wondered if this pre-recorded content / program could be stored in a chip on the device, rather than relying on satellites. It would still rely on mobile functions to communicate emergencies etc.  What do you think?
James, brilliant idea! I will adjust the concept; this actually closes the loop- not only does the expecting mom receive information but she briefly sends information as to how she feels.

Great concept - i wonder whether this service include a personal account that tracks the prenancy's progress. In other words as well as sending information to the mother, information is also sent back and logged against an 'account'. This could create a picture of the pregnancy that helth workers could use to help provide tailored support particularly to support the birth. This could be a communicated by emoticons to get past the literacy barrier
thanks, Vincent!

Nice work on building up this concept Krassimira. Can see how you weaved various themes from the inspiration phase into this. I especially like how you incorporated songs and stories into this to aid understanding and remembering, and also how you extended the potential benefit beyond the pregnancy by offering the phone for purchase.
Thanks, Avi! Another source (based on inspiration posted by Meena): http://www.adaptivepath.com/blog/2009/05/18/mobilglyph-making-data-tangible/
The Talking Book device could complement this concept:http://www.literacybridge.org/talking-book/

an_audio_guide_through_maternity.title: An Audio Guide through Maternity

sos_column_for_mothers.description: In low-income countries the biggest issues regarding maternal health are the lack of healthcare personnel and motherhood disinformation. One possible solution to these issues could be to build a free and permanent information channel between mothers and healthcare personnel which allows them to have a remote and trained assistance anytime and anywhere.
sos_column_for_mothers.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: Thanks!!  We are currently doing some research about pregnant women here in Colombia to be able to adapt these columns for maternal health help. We will be more than happy to share all about it in the next phase.
Great to see this inspiration from Colombia! Will be interesting to hear more about your thoughts on how this can be adapted for maternal health in the upcoming Concepting Phase. Cheers for sharing.

sos_column_for_mothers.title: SOS column for mothers

shanti_uganda_birth_kits.description: The Shanti Uganda Birth House and Learning Center sells birth kits that help support the organization.
shanti_uganda_birth_kits.creator: b35fe9f812f395a74d0a9967a4de3846
shanti_uganda_birth_kits.title: Shanti Uganda Birth Kits

maternal_checklist_inspired_by_the_check.description:
Creating 'Maternal care checklist' and distributing them directly to mothers could be an effective way to impove knowlege of critical maternal heath care.  It could also be delivered in a number of ways (mobile app, text messages, internet app, centralized information center, etc.)

The effectiveness of checklists to take complex processes and simplify them into a list of simple actions has been proven in many industries such as aviation, manufacturing, and medicine.  Checklists such as the 'Surgical Safety Checklist' have been shown to drastically decrease surgery death rates (see NEJM article link in description).
maternal_checklist_inspired_by_the_check.creator: 89f0fee17250dd3bf28ed7533c51edd1
maternal_checklist_inspired_by_the_check.title: Mother's Maternal Care Checklist inspired by 'The Checklist Manifesto' & 'Surgical Safety Checklist'

a_distributed_milk_bank.description: I think everyone knows about milk banks (it's not difficult to figure out), but in rural areas for examples it could be difficult to implement some centralized place as a real milk bank. What if this bank could be not centralized, but an informational network make closer donor and receiver?
a_distributed_milk_bank.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751
a_distributed_milk_bank.title: A distributed Milk Bank

a_village_well_of_knowledge_and_communic.description: Inspired by the Hole in the Wall Project and building on concepts on shared technologies for knowledge and communication (such as the Mum Radio or the Maternal Health Vending Machine), why don't we create open access computers where women can gather as around the village well to get access to knowledge and to communicate.
a_village_well_of_knowledge_and_communic.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: This idea ties very well with so many others, as you said - I am really liking the community 'knowledge well' concept - it would be effective in areas that have high individual mobile penetration and areas that do not.
I like the that this can become an impromptu community center where people will use technology and they also have the opportunity for social interaction with others that visit the Well.

a_village_well_of_knowledge_and_communic.title: A Village Well for Knowledge and Communication

voucher_based_healthcare_reimbursements_.description: Mobile voucher-based systems can be used to pay for health care services. Vouchers here can be defined as prepaid certificates either provided by the government to qualified individuals or sold at a subsidized price to individuals in order to pay for a pre-defined service.
voucher_based_healthcare_reimbursements_.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: Sarah, I was thinking more of NGOs. As Albert commented, based on his experience working in South Africa, working with private NGOs might be a good idea. What do you think?
I really like this idea! But who would subsidize transportation fees? NGOs? Governments?

Sarah, I love the voucher-based concept. I could imagine a combo- voucher for institutional deliver + transportation voucher as often women cannot allow to pay for taxi to drive them to the nearest hospital and back.
Absolutely Meena, that is an interesting mash-up!

And perhaps you could sign-up for relevant SMS updates as a maternal health voucher recipient? ie. Mash together with some of the discussion around nutritional info messaging, etc. that's been suggested elsewhere throughout the challenge. Starting to see lots of dots which could get connected between inspirations/concepts ;^)

voucher_based_healthcare_reimbursements_.title: Voucher-based healthcare reimbursements

mapping_happiness_mappiness.description:
This smartphone app is part of a research study by LSE (London School of Economics) that has the aim of trying to map happiness to environment. It beeps from 0-5 times a day (depending on how you set it) and asks you a few questions - e.g., are you happy? awake? relaxed? Who are you with? What are you doing? If you're outside it asks for a photo of where you are and captures your GPS coordinates. It then provides a report to the user of their happiness levels - when, with whom, where. 

What might be the equivalent for maternal health? It could be used to gather data or inform mums, etc.
mapping_happiness_mappiness.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: It's a good point. Emotion is an important benchmark to evaluate health.

mapping_happiness_mappiness.title: Mapping happiness - mappiness

wonderfully_designed_mobile_phones_softw.description: Frogtek (a for-profit social venture) have wonderfully designed mobile phones software applications for BoP customers. I really believe they can be of great inspiration on developing specific softwares for health care solutions.
wonderfully_designed_mobile_phones_softw.creator: 8d6e426c5c9f6f7272bff21cadbf0c4d

comments.text: That is right Sarah! I saw it! I was fortunate to meet them personally in Mexico. They are really great and dinamic. Truly inspiring when thinking on great apps.
And I'm a fan of Frogtek! They are the very recent Global Mobile Awards mWomen Base of the Pyramid Apps Challenge Winner :)
Am always a fan of P2P approaches!

wonderfully_designed_mobile_phones_softw.title: Wonderfully designed mobile phones software applications for BoP customers.

first_5_la_help_line_for_parents.description: “First 5 La” is an organization created in California with the purpose of improving children´s life quality in Los Angeles County. Looking forward to protecting children´s first life stages as their mission, “First 5 LA” offers a different variety of programs. One of those programs is the help line for parents: a free assistance line that works 24 hours a day for parents, pregnant mothers and nannies that take care of kids under the age of 5.
first_5_la_help_line_for_parents.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323
first_5_la_help_line_for_parents.title: FIRST 5 LA, Help line for parents

sms_maternity_pregnacy_health_tips_simpl.description: Send sms messages with pictures that help local women to understand how to react in certain situations as well as how to stay healthy so the need for medical attention is minimized due awareness.
sms_maternity_pregnacy_health_tips_simpl.creator: 8d2f4a6e4def40216f32ca50eb795663

comments.text: That is an interesting idea Aaron! We could even extend the idea of sharing the health tips to more than the pregnant women only. I'm thinking here to the "Dad Outreach" issue. Tips could be send to fathers/husbands/whole family as well. Because I guess they usually are the decision makers in issues like: "paying bus to go to the local health center", "buying or not specific drugs/food", "keeping the pregnant woman at work or not".Raising their awareness, giving specifics advices maybe helpful to have relatives taking care of the women.

Nice one Aaron! I also just covered novels being delivered via mobile messaging in South Africa for Design Observer: http://bit.ly/do_yoza Check out how that elicited user comments to shape future communication... that may work with what you're suggesting too  though it's more complex than pure SMS.
That is a good idea, Halyan!
This idea reminds me of IKEA furniture instructions... and as you say airline safety booklets.Perhaps we can also make a booklet of these safety instructions and distribute them locally.

sms_maternity_pregnacy_health_tips_simpl.title: sms maternity/pregnacy health tips (simple, easy)

more_remote_communication_less_commute.description:
One of the problems in rural areas is the transportation. If we can expand the remote diagnosis capability via phone, Skype or any other remote communication tools, we can save lots of time people spending on commuting and waiting.  If we can rely on more local medical staff and people who have had similar experience and gained knowledge to help the new patients, we will be able to have the doctor working on more important issues.
In this way, we can improve the efficiency and solve the problem of insufficient equipments and hospital rooms.
more_remote_communication_less_commute.creator: 2a4fd84490bfcd93c78630b9af7d78ba

comments.text: Meena, Thanks. Actually, I finally figured out I kept typing my email address rather than my user name to log in...OpenIDEO, it might be an improvement you can make in the log in screen. I'm so glad to back to the great community.
Yay Qirong! You made it  we heard you'd been having problems logging on. Some great thoughts here.

more_remote_communication_less_commute.title: More remote communication, Less commute

mobile_phones_as_201c_personal_assistant.description:
Community Health Workers (CHWs) are relied upon in many remote areas to provide health education and services, such as antenatal visits to expecting mothers. But they often lack administrative supports to do their job - such as the ability to collect, compile, and act on patient data.

This solution is simple: (1) CHWs visit expecting mothers and text patient information to a central number; (2) Local data entry clerks (or an automated system) enter this information into a database; and (3) The database sends calendar-style alerts about follow-up visits to CHWs and patients.

This system would help CHWs keep track of their clients' diverse needs, as well as send health-related messages and alerts to the expecting mothers themselves. Finally, with enough community members registered in the database, the system could also facilitate the delivery of services to expecting mothers, such as motorbike ambulances for transport to a health facility.
mobile_phones_as_201c_personal_assistant.creator: cc4037bae72cda5910f69b588a271cc4

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback, guys!  MoTeCH looks awesome - excited to check it out.

I wonder how the maternal mortality rates compare with that of motorcycle mortality rates.  Aren't those the highest?  Also, do CHW's actually have incentives other than civic responsibility.  In my experience many did not get paid and therefore their reach was limited.  Otherwise I think this is a great idea.  Empower CHW's--- buy recognizing how wonderful they are.
Great idea and great detail. In particular, the idea of a centralized database could be leveraged in many of the concepts that have been suggested.

I think the MoTeCH system may meet many of your needs - it's functioning and currently being studied at scale in Ghana - http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/mobile-technology-for-community-health-motech/

mobile_phones_as_201c_personal_assistant.title: Mobile phones as “personal assistants” for Community Health Workers

smart_band_aids.description: Smart band aids using small ultra low power censors to transmit information.
smart_band_aids.creator: abf5b97bb70ed2e460f6b71d70b5f899
smart_band_aids.title: Smart band aids

_i_ate_what_campaign.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b
_i_ate_what_campaign.title: "I ate what?!" campaign

mother_mati_2019_s_phone_and_flipbook.description:
SUBTITLE: Call Mother Mati for A Trusted Voice.  Follow her picture book for a healthy Mother and Baby.
SUMMARY: Linking picture flipbook, an automated phone messaging service and an automated SMS service to assist mothers and midwives to take simple steps to prevent major causes of maternal mortality.
mother_mati_2019_s_phone_and_flipbook.creator: 94292e3ffc2c71d299d570b8fe937804

comments.text: It might be interesting to work with local artists to produce images for each book that are specific to each region, or alternately, to work with nationally recognized characters (maybe cartoon characters, or perhaps actors in photographs rather than drawings).

Great ideas.  Tailoring the message to the culture is important.  Perhaps we can get a mother from a tv soap opera on board in some cases where access to technology is better?  I remember being in remote Vietnam and Indonesia and some places still having access to tv.

It seems like a lot of the ideas here are leveraging the burgeoning SMS networks in developing countries. However, there are lots of people in rural areas who might not be able to read information passed along via SMS. I really like this solution because it also has a component (i.e., the flip book) that uses minimal text/words that will really make it more accessible. Additionally, it may have a better chance of reaching more people because, while SMS is still growing, not everyone still has access.

Hi Samuel.  Thanks for the feedback.  It's not necessarily just SMS - we've ensured the concept 'could' work if you have low literacy.   (essentially see a number and dial).   We tried to make this point in the video... hope we succeeded.Also, about the access to SMS - you might be right but the breif was about using mobile technologies (basically mobile phones) to improve maternal health.  I'd suggest that if you can't access SMS then your almost outside the reaches of this project.A vaild point though: the most in need are the hardest to get to.Thanks again.

What a compelling idea. Props to you both.Couple of thoughts come to mind:Woman-to-woman connection: This builds off Veronika's point about new/not-so-new mothers presenting themselves as women who've been through the childbirth and new motherhood experience. This is extremely powerful. In the spirit of leveraging existing networks which you guys have emphasised (fantastic), what if those religious organisations and community networks could be used to build buddy/support groups of mums/mums-to-be? Some countries may already have HCW networks (like Bangladesh, through the nonprofit BRAC, for example), based on their province/district/village etc, and a source of support that is near your home is something many mums-to-be may find handy.Adoption by mums-to-be: The system currently looks like it would work great once mums-to-be have picked up the book/phone service. Question is, how do you get them to want to pick this up in the first place? Perhaps the previous point about community networks could help - where trusted relationships confer significance to the having of knowledge around maternal health?Form of media: This thought was triggered by Robyn's point about many families not coming into contact with books as a form of media in the first place. Well, perhaps context-specific elements of a local culture may help -- from what I understand (Bangladeshi's please correct me as needed!), education is hugely respected in Bangladesh culture. What if the connection between education and books (as a medium) could be better made? Might this trigger aspirational motivation to get the books? And if there was an educational element (either in the same book, or in a follow-on book to incentivise mums passing the original book on to mums-to-be), might that drive behaviour to have the books so their kids could access it in future?Just throwing ideas out there - I am clearly no expert!

Hey,  nobody is an expert here, and I think all of this is a great addition.  The 'how do you get them to pick it up in the first place' is a great.  We have give this some thought: essentially making the design of the thing approachable, free and accessible.  But, as the metaphor goes when I worked in a sales job, that only leads the horse to water.I think the conversion between getting this book to them and getting it to work is very important.Perhaps more of a field trail question.But I will admit, something that the idea tries to live on is that it could work without having specialist staff distribute the flipbooks.  Other interventions have been able to do this effectively... so we stand a good chance of success, but it is no way a lock.Thanks again.Tristan
Loving the depth of thinking + visualisations here. Go Tristan!

Regarding distribution channels: the midwife / community health worker infrastructure may be a better way to distribute this flipbook rather than using channels like soft drinks and mobile sim sellers. This would work well for 2 reasons: 1. it would get it to mothers exactly and 2. it comes from a trusted source so that mothers know to trust this information. There is a lot of information about childbirth, hearsay and others that exists in many communities, and new information cannot fight against these: trusted information can. This also might help you to focus the flipbook on childbirth and post-birth information rather than pregnancy information, as you could easily get a "too much information" flipbook, which wouldn't really work I think.
(sorry, posted in the wrong place, reposting... no delete function :(

Hey no worries Prabhas... you made me look really good as though it was something to do with what I'd said ;^) Great point about the trusted networks. That's something I really came to appreciate when researching in Mumbai slums.
ooops  I meant go Tristan *and* Tom in my original comment!

All nice points which I essentially agree with.  We were not necessarily saying 'use soft drink transporters'.  But what we are saying is 'use existing networks/infrastructure'  that is our mantra with this idea.In short, if a network already exists then let's use it.  If it's trusted then all the better.  Health networks are easily the  best of this... however, I will make the point that the areas most in need probably don't have a great health network.  So relying on it could be fraught.So the advantage with using SIM sellers and soft drink distributers would not be the 'trust' but rather the 'reach'.  Even with a lower hit ratio the larger networks can reach more people.  With our intervention we have hoped to make it worth without health networks.But points taken.  I think these are questions for a pilot trial.

Dear Tristan and Tom,You've come up with some great ideas!I have just a few comments that may help you develop your concept further:- Distributing the Flipbook through existing commercial channels is a great way to use existing resources. It is unclear whether a company like Coca-Cola would really be willing to distribute these Flipbooks for free. Also, to reach more remote villages, it is often informal retailers transporting smaller quantities than large trucks full of crates. Perhaps you can think of ways to engage this informal sector?- The fees for calling from a mobile phone are quite high in many developing countries. People often prefer to SMS or send "missed calls" to page others to call them back because they cannot pay for the talk time themselves. Couldn't the Flipbook audio be loaded onto a SIM card? That way, the mothers don't have to pay for talk time to be able to hear Mother Mati.- Also, every child birthing experience is slightly different. It can be dangerous to have an automated voice message leading the midwife's every action. Often, the correct action depends on the situation (eg. the position of the baby, how dilated the mother is, etc.). It could be alarming for the mother if the midwife did something contradictory to what Mother Mati is saying during the delivery. Perhaps the Flipbook could be a set of general guidelines listened to before the delivery, and the midwife could be allowed to make decisions as needed in the moment. Good luck!Jess

Thanks for the response! I am travelling for work at the moment, so this will be breif.In response to your three points:1.  Good ideas.  I do think that rather than trying to answer all holes before you start something like this is difficult.  I strongly suspect that the holes to remote villages/communities will be much more individual.  I don't think that I (or anyone) else can know how to fill those gaps before you start.  More importantly, you don't really know where they are before you start.  Kind of a learn on the job issue, but a very valid point.  Thank you.2.  We have already covered this with our concept, I think.  You can ask to receive a call at a specific time of day (signing up to the service).  Initially this was to be through a single SMS or phonecall.  I s'pose it could go even further to be if you miss that call then you get called back.  3.  This an excellent point.  I make no pretense that I am totally qualified to make a call about this.  It is something that would need to go through health organisations.   Again, excellent and important point.  Not sure it's a failing in our concept.... more of a 'move with caution' note.Thanks again.

Regarding distribution channels: the midwife / community health worker infrastructure may be a better way to distribute this flipbook rather than using channels like soft drinks and mobile sim sellers. This would work well for 2 reasons: 1. it would get it to mothers exactly and 2. it comes from a trusted source so that mothers know to trust this information. There is a lot of information about childbirth (hearsay, superstition, etc.) that exists in many communities, and simply *new* information cannot fight against these: it has to be trusted. This also might help you to focus the flipbook on childbirth and post-birth information rather than pregnancy information, as a flipbook with "too much information" is very much a potential risk here.

I really like the attention an consideration you have given to developing the personality of Mita. I can see this working really well in a type of pregnant women support circle (kind of like saving groups prevalent in many developing countries). CHWs would identify pregnant women in an area, and encourage the creation of a support group that might meet once a week or month (whatever is feasible). The group could be given a speaker, and listen to a lesson from Mita. The CHW could be in attendance for additional questions, and referencing the flip book as often as possible. I think your focus going forward should be on context specific content creation, and the development of an encouraging, caring, nurturing and informative individual. This could be used in a variety of ways and programs. Good luck!

Tristan, Here's a version of the recordable storybook that Robyn was referring to:http://www.hallmark.com/online/in-stores/recordable-storybooks/One would have to figure out a way to lock the recordings though!
Darn it!  Posted three times and I can't delete them!  (Please do administrator... and this comment too)

A comment, via email from my brother in law who works for a government aid in Australia and has been to Afghanistan and about to go to Pakistan for a 3 year posting that I thought was relevant to share:Hey Tristan - Just listening to your mother mita presentation with Thomas.  From a development perspective I think it sounds pretty good.  Health and maternal health is a big focus of our aid program, indeed for all international development agencies, so any innovations in this area are to be welcomed.  I wish you luck - maternal health is one of the toughest areas to make a difference.  We can get kids to school, improve literacy, get people on scholarships to universities, even make headway against corruption and improve governance, if somewhat incremental.  But maternal health indicators go backwards.  One major issue is of course cultural.  It appears to me that you're tried to build in culturally appropriate advice within the concept.  But it will still be tough, particularly in Islamic countries, where, not surprisingly, some of the worst indicators for maternal health occur.    One quick observation - we don't use 'first' and 'third' world terminology anymore.  That's a legacy of the cold war, when the first world were countries aligned with the US, the second with the USSR and the third were non aligned.  The terminology today is developed and less developed.  Aid specialists and NGO's, the type of peeps who would be interested in your concept, won't take you seriously if you use that type of language.  Similarly many countries take real offence being referred to as 'third world'.  We have to use very careful diplomatic language in our briefings and talking points for Ministers when they go to less developed countries.  A good example is India and China.  Obviously they have large swathes of their populations living in poverty, where they'll struggle to meet millennium development goals on health and maternal health, despite recording huge numbers of economic growth rates as they open up there economies.  But if you refer to them as third world, they'll put a fatwa on your arse and be hugely offended.  Pakistan another great example.  Terrible indicators in health, one of the worst in the south asian region for maternal health, but an extremely proud and nationalistic country.  Improving maternal health in Pakistan even by a few percentage points is one of the major challenges for all development actors. Millions of dollars have been thrown at the problem.  But refer to them as a third world country, they'll tell you to piss off and damage will be done to the good work and sweat and tears that have gone into building trust into the relationship. I'll be interested to see how you go with this, for the obvious reason that its something relevant for the development world.

Excellent work! The Flip Book idea is quite intuitive. Consider having local actors to voice the character. For example, in India telly-soap actors have tremendous pull with audiences. Hearing their favorite characters suggesting steps might increase the trust and impact factors of the message.

Hi guys, congratulations on making it to the 20 finalists!Living in Mexico, I have spent a lot of time in rural areas during different social work, and i wanted to point out some context facts about rural communities that may help you re-design or re-think part of your strategy:- People in rural communities get a lot of written material from local health clinics, NGOs, etc.. How will you incentivate women to use your booklet instead of any other? I feel you could take out all the basic info like how to wash hands and really show in depth knowledge on maternal health in very easy to understand drawings.- One thing that happens in rural areas is that everybody has a cell phone but with no credit on it. If they ever make a call its because it represents an urgent matter. I don't think they will use their credit calling an "automated" message, which might be very bizarre for a rural lady that has never heard a machine telling her what to do. Have you thought about the cost that represents for them making that call?Good luck in the competition!

Hey Guys, Nice work! I haven't had a chance to read all the comments-- but one think you could do is combine the phone and flipbook into a "talking book" using Mother Mita's voice so that women who have no literacy can get the information directly from the book. A talking book is one of those books that has pictures on every page and buttons that are associated with the picture (or something along these lines), so women just have to push the button to hear the content. This means you could also have only one version, perhaps-- that is pictorial, low literacy, and has some additional information for women who are literate. I would keep the language to a minimum, in either case, and make sure that there is only one concept per page to ensure greater understanding. I would also focus on making the phone line a hotline-- I realize you have back-up operators, but I think in most country settings a hotline of some sort could be set-up and talking to a real person is always nicer than a recorded message. But, I agree, that in cases where a hotline isn't cost-effective or for some other reason, a recorded message is better than nothing!A companion manual that goes with the midwife and includes more technical information (such as information on misoprostol) could also be helpful. Additionally, when you adapt your materials in country, you will need to pilot test it in community groups and use their illustrators, etc... to get the right types of pictorial representation. The community groups can also be utilized to distribute the flipbooks. The last thing that I'll add, just to think about, is that most families don't have a book in their home-- any type of book (except maybe the phone book in some limited cases in urban areas). People haven't been exposed to this form of media in the same way that we have. Although this will make it unique, it may also be that a different mode of delivery for a particular community would be more appropriate. Or, it may work better as a job aid for midwives, with a companion community mobilization component that utilizes street drama or radio in combination with the community-level talking book to get the message out.
great idea, simple and accessible *APPLAUSE*!
OMG! We're loving the lengths you guys have gone to for refinement! Outstanding ideating! Global applause from the OpenIDEO Team.
Absolutely Tristan. BTW, awesome video guys. You've really done a great job of fleshing out and explaining your concept in depth. Worth the watch!

Thanks Vincent.I like the idea of over the air downloads...  but not sure you can do this on the Nokia 1100 - the phone who's capacity we are targeting.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia_1100However, there is huge capacity to update this idea.This idea would work really well with smartphones but don't want to put the cart before the horse.  Our whole idea is based around 'what is the existing infrastructure'.Certainly, one way we are getting around this people registering to 'recieve' calls from Mother Mati.  Certainly, not good for repeat viewings... but likely to be easier to make free.  All that said, we could more clearly articulate a plan to grow the idea with improved resources/ infastructure.

Hi Tristan, just letting you know that Siri & I posted some further thoughts about alternative delivery/storage mechanisms on Siri's related concept. Am copying it here for your reference.Siri: "Vincent, your suggestion on how to cut call costs got me thinking of other possible ways. Perhaps it would be less costly if the audio was sent as a voice message, and the messages were either offered as a subscription or "ordered" by sending a text with the numbers for the pages you were interested in hearing about? Thoughts on this?"Vincent: "Interesting voice message idea Siri. This would work if the charge for listening to voicemail is less than for regular calls. Also, in cases where phones can store & play audio (beyond tones), there may be opportunities for over-the-air downloads (like how you can download a ringtone once and it can then be played as many times as needed). Anyways, which of these ideas makes sense will depend on the common phone charges and capabilities for each region. Your original call approach is the simplest to implement and I wouldn't be surprised if it makes the most sense in the most places right now. Just throwing out other possibilities that may make sense in the future or currently in specific areas."

Hi All!Wow.  Nice comments (don't forget to applaud!)Okay, responses:  Crystal:  Having a different, and culturally appropriate, figure for each region was part of our initial idea.  The journal idea is really interesting.  It would require some thought, but I like the idea of an 'action' you take with the flipbook.  The idea of giving the flipbook more cultural and personal relevance can only help.Vincent: Totally.  One thing I do like, if this concept actually works, is that is can grow and improve with the technology.OpenIDEO: Thanks!  Very happy to be selected.  About to update this with a video that includes (and appropriately recognises) a number of additions inspired by a number of people.  Really giving this 'use other peoples ideas' concept as much as we can.Veronika:  Again, great idea.  In fact, it's already in the update we are working on.  However, I think you are really looking at a way to leverage the interaction between mothers.  Really good idea.  Not sure if we need to 'trigger' that behaviour or it will happen naturally with the handover.

Yes I agree on many of the comments so far. The first thing that caught my eye was that your initial character is an Indian woman. As OpenIDEO pointed out, it would be great to have multiple characters/flip books that women from other cultures can relate to. I also love the comment about creating an income opportunity for community members to assemble these flip books. Have you thought about employing translators from villages to help with the voice overs so that there is also cultural specificity in the languages? That would be another employment opportunity for someone who is bilingual and eager to utilize their skills for such a great project. Additionally, what if you added a section to the flip book where mothers can add to a shared journal that would grow as each flip book is passed on? Such a method of accretion will not only further personalize the exchange but will also enable mothers to pass on valuable information, self-discovered solutions to problems they encountered, stories/songs that their children loved, and other experiential knowledge.Great concept and cheers on being in the top 20!

Congrats Tristan & Siri on your strong related finalists concepts that combine the audio of mobiles & the visualization display capabilities of physical flip booklets. Just wanted to point to the future possibilities of using limited capacity, low-cost, copyable/sharable SD cards in cases where phones support this to store the audio (& maybe backup images), which could save on call costs.

Hi Tristan, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of a simple communication tool to teach mothers about health issues and the idea of using a well-known character to be the champion for this cause.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some thought as to the content of these flip books. What sort of issues can we address in this format?We also ask you to develop the character of 'Mother Mati' with regard to introducing her to different cultures across the globe. Should she be visually dressed different in different parts of the World? Could she be a character other than a person to cross cultural barriers?We encourage you to work with Krassimira http://openideo.com/profiles/1496897674/ to incorporate her thoughts from: An Audio Guide through Maternity http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/an-audio-guide-through-maternity/ So you can build a stronger concept together. When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields: - Concept Builds - Here you can list additional builds on your concept - Virtual Team - Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept. Cheers! OpenIDEO

There is one aspect, Id like to stress which is an important side effect I think: When women pass on their flip books, they also present themselves as women who already went through the pregnancy and "education" provided by the service of your concept. Maybe the pregnant woman did not know the woman passing on the flip book before, so this act is establishing a contact/friendship to a person who can help out the pregnant woman - thanks to her experience - in the future. I think this moment should be supported by your concept, in the sense of "pass on what youve received yourself". Maybe women who acquire new pregnant women to the service, get a new flip book for the first months in the babys life. I think on a longterm perspective it would be reasonable to use the knowledge that was spread throughout the villages as a human support to your system.

I'm thinking that these flipbooks will have to be produced. Why not give a few rural women some nice jobs by providing them with an old laptop, a printer, a laminator and something to create holes in the laminated pages with.

Great concept Tristan! This made me think of Meena's grassroots comics inspiration - local collaboration on producing the images is always more effective:http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/inspiration/17th/This paper has some guidelines based on fieldwork -"Text-Free User Interfaces for Illiterate and Semi-Literate Users":http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/people/indranim/text-freeui.pdf
Refining it is! :D
Thanks Nidhi!We're re-doing the concept now and will include that idea.  Pretty neat and easilly fits the concept.  Expect a vimeo in a couple days!(Sarah, same goes for you idea - thanks).

Tristan: :) yes! Although a little more expensive, I think automated phone calls in the local language at specific intervals of time will be much more effective. To reduce costs maybe target a few mothers for the automated phone call at first and then ask these mothers to spread-the-word.

Sarah - Thanks.  That was the idea.  And about the hook flip charts: our idea was to make it cheap and 'flip' easily'.  However, certainly that is an extra positive.Nidhi - Thanks.  Just checking: you're suggesting that our SMS prompt idea be an automated phonecall?  Good idea.  Probably a little more expensive but a good option to explore.
I love your idea. Since the mothers might be illiterate or have low literacy rates, how about giving audio tips through phone calls on a specified time of the day everyday?

I'm imagining how easily these flicharts could be passed around within the same village/community. Once a mother has delivered, she would naturally give it to her neighbor, sister or cousin when she is due as well.This might sound minor, but I really like the fact that it has in your drawings a keychain shaped hook. I know in many villages where there are risks of floods (I experienced this in Laos), people tend to hang stuff on their walls in order to avoid it being deteriorated.

There is a nice method for making attractive and very durable flipcharts, owned and used by a German company Infoflip ULM e.K.  I have had infoflip charts made up by working with Flip Productions in Canada, at www.flipproductions.com

Thanks Dara,  checked out your concept.  Video gaomes right."Gamification" is being bashed a bit at the moment... but I do think that if this concepts could connect with kids then that would be useful.  And even think that making a game out of it for the kids is the way to go.  (gamification seems like a concept that would work better with kids).Also, and lets be honest, many of the first time mothers will be little more than children.  In Bangladesh there are 117 births per thousand women 15-19.http://globalis.gvu.unu.edu/indicator.cfm?IndicatorID=127

Great idea - could perhaps combine it with my concept to target youth audience? Given the fact that many youth are forced to take on adult roles in emerging economies (especially where HIV/AIDS has wiped out the working-age demographic), this concept could reach even more people if youth understand this is not just for adults.Examples: include images of youth playing role of midwife (which they do already).

Hi!  Krassimira Thanks for the feedback.Great name by the way!The idea is that each number on each flipcard would be unique and give an audio recording of the tip on that flipcard.  The audio recording would be in the voice of Mother Mita.For example, the handwashing flipcard would have the spoken out tip for how the midwife should wash their hands.We could definitely add sections for emergency numbers if they are locally available. If you can make that link clearly it should be made.  We could simply have 'press 1 to speak to a helper' in the call.However, the base intention was to have something that you could build, at low cost, separate of the formal heath system - making sure that it could theoretically work for those most disadvantaged and then be ramped up for those slightly more fortunate.

I like your concept and I really like the plastic flipcard idea! Just for my understanding: 1) is there a regular contact between a mom-to-be and a midwife? 2) emergencies can be handled via the 5555 number?

The SMS messages would just be text, no pictures. Screen size wouldn't be an issue, and the messages could be delivered to any device from an iPhone 4 to the ubiquitous Nokia 1100. I'd also like to point out that a plastic flip book could be quite durable and have high pass-along readership.Regardless of which concept is ultimately chosen in this challenge, it makes good business sense for mobile carriers to donate services or reduce prices for the project. Healthy mothers are better customers.

Agreed on the flipbook being image heavy.It's a concept sketch and the words here were only to show the intended meaning.  Ideally we'd have little to no words in a final product.As with the funding... well that is the question of all of these projects isn't it. There isn't one that's free. In reality this would be Oxfam's job.  However, the designers role is to thing of programs that will have low cost and high impact. I think it's cost would be pretty low and certainly I'd hope a chance at having a great impact.  We designed it with that in mind.  I suspect you'd also be able to have local mobile suppliers sponsor the initiative out of goodwill and PR. Thanks for the comment.

Hi. Seems very well thought out in terms of leveraging what people already use, trust and are comfortable with. Given the limited screen size it would probably be better to have the images in the flipbook without the text and use these together with the freecall to get the audio explanation. Any ideas on sustainability? Free yes because many cannot afford to pay for such services however what happens in the long term if funding runs out?
Thanks Meena, Really put some heads together and proud of the concept.  Hope the group like it too.

mother_mati_2019_s_phone_and_flipbook.title: Mother Mati’s Phone and Flipbook

py/tuple: Does this concept have the potential to save lives related to maternal health in the poorest and most marginalized communities?

It's very realizable
There are some hurdles to realization
This concept is not realistic

How much does this concept leverage resources and partners in existing low-income communities? Thus enhancing positive aspects of the way things work in the community as opposed to taking away what is a valued way of working and living in the community.
This concept works harmoniously with existing resources and partners
This concept does not work against existing resources and partners
This concept conflicts with existing resources and partners
Can this concept become self-sustaining and even provide some livelihood value add to the community?
This concept could become a self-sustaining business for locals
This concept still needs some work before it is self-sustaining
This concept is not self-sustaining at all
Will this concept work in low-tech & low-connectivity environments?
This concept is very well suited to low-tech and low-connectivity environments
This concept needs to be evaluated for technology feasibility
This concept may be too high-tech for low-income communities

knowledge_distribution_empowering_women.description: A group of women from different small local communities were there is no health workers are gathered for 6 month. During this time they will receive a basic education to become trained midwifes. After the training they go back to their local communities together with simple diagnostic equipment.
knowledge_distribution_empowering_women.creator: fabeacc75ec9dce98ddda9c56ca6043c
knowledge_distribution_empowering_women.title: Knowledge distribution empowering women

is_it_going_to_be_a_boy_or_a_girl.description:
In some rural parts of India the birth of a girl in not as welcomed as the birth of a boy. To my knowledge the doctors are not allowed to disclose the gender of the baby until it is born. Often girls are killed as soon as they are born.
In the community I see a lot of inspirations around eduction and training of the expecting moms:

What do you think: Shall the doctors and community health workers continue the practice of non-disclosing the gender keeping in mind the strong traditions OR Try to educate the expecting moms and the families that all that matters is not the gender, but the health of the baby?
is_it_going_to_be_a_boy_or_a_girl.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Ashley, I'm not sure how the technology could help resolving these issues. I believe they are not only deeply ingrainedcultural and socio-demographic, but also economic. The birth of a girl is considered a financial burden as the family of the girl has to pay dowry (certaon $amount or something of value) to the family of the guy when she gets married. Often families start saving for dowry as soon as the girl is born. I think a good start for changing such behaviour will be face-to-face kind of work with community participation.

This is such a great question. I know I've been focusing on coming up with ideas directed at the mothers specifically, but thinking about raising awareness among health professionals is crucial too. I wonder how these concerns about gender could be eased or even resolved through the use of mobile technology? Could mobile tech be applicable here? Or would this kind of work really need to be face-to-face?

Moms are also often held responsible for not being able to "deliver" a baby boy, whereas, genetically, it all comes to the father's side of things... Maybe this could also be something to raise awareness around.

is_it_going_to_be_a_boy_or_a_girl.title: Is it going to be a boy or a girl?

information_in_layers.description: Many of the initiatives proposed so far in this challenge involve the direct contact between helpers and the people directly interested on helping. The problem is that we'll need a 1-to-1 proportion of resources (people, technology, etc.). So why don't we flow the information in layers?
information_in_layers.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751
information_in_layers.title: Information in layers

phone_charger_and_colloidal_silver_gener.description: Colloidal silver is and will be a great matter of debate. But we can not deny: it is a true serial killer of bacteria, fungus and viruses ... We are dealing here with a serious problem of death from infections. So I thought: why not?
phone_charger_and_colloidal_silver_gener.creator: 155a2e9ba2686b27dfccb0ab6b2034ee

comments.text: The purpose of the subject, do not forget to see the link: http://bit.ly/h8DQhK

One important thing I want to make clear this concept is that, even if there are discussions about colloidal silver for internal use, we can not deny its power as a sterilizer of environments, tools, etc., that is for external use. Herself NASA is using colloidal silver to purify water from the ISS astronauts. So, the spread of low-cost devices capable of producing colloidal silver could go to clinics and small hospitals a great ally in fighting infection.

phone_charger_and_colloidal_silver_gener.title: Phone charger and colloidal silver generator

grameen_danone.description: Slip in vitamins with the kid's daily yogurt!
grameen_danone.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Thank you for bringing up Danone, Avi! In my view, Grameen Danone is a brilliant example of a social business that has been backed by a committed for-profit organization. Some highlights:It is one of the organizations where Prof Yunus - one of the biggest forces behind the establishment, insisted for "the smallest plant technically possible, located in a rural area, surrounded by the village people it would serve"('Creating a world without Poverty' by Prof. Yunus). Accordingly, Group Danone built a plant that had a footprint of 7500 square feet and was dependent on the neighboring villages for both production and consumption. There was a cross-subsidy model because of which products were priced higher in Dhaka. "We sell our products in Dhaka with a margin aiming to sell those at lower prices to poor people in remote areas to get them nutrient-rich food."(Article on dailystar:  http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=71797)It is also a good example of a patient capital investment. The company has projected that the first plant in Bogra will reach profitability by 2011 or 2012[source: http://www.muhammadyunus.org/images/stories/in_the_media/GDFL_BP_27_10_2010.pdf]

a_low_cost_telemedicine_solution_that_ai.description:
ReMeDi (Remote Medical Diagnostics)  telemedicine solution overcomes these issues with the cost per consultation being less than a dollar per teleconsultation. This solution has been commercially deployed in rural Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra, India.
The solution addresses three common problems in rural India:
- no electricity and frequent outages
- lack of skilled personnel (traditional HCW, doctors to scooters who visit villages once a week)
- bandwith/connectivity available

mom_adopt_a_mom.description:
How can we create links between moms all over the world in order to support and help each other using just their own experience? 

In places like Burkina Faso and Bangladesh, moms have major limitations when it comes to obtaining information about pregnancy, most of them are single moms or the father is barely involved in the pregnancy process. Based on this issue we want to offer a program where a mom no matter where she is located in the world may adopt another mom anywhere around the globe, so they can share their experiences and knowledge. We want to transform a local problem into an international issue but giving practical solutions.
mom_adopt_a_mom.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: I love the idea of connecting moms. How about forming local groups of peer mom support groups? That way, they would speak the same language and be from the same culture.
Another requirement: The two moms would need to speak the same language
i really like the heart of this idea > to connect people with people and share common wisdom and knowledge. moving away from simply the expert/recipient model to a collaborative one.
Thanks!! it was really helpful during brainstorming, that's how we came out with the concept.

Kudos for the chronological process graphic you've posted! Great job!

mom_adopt_a_mom.title: Mom Adopt A Mom

a_low_cost_infant_incubator.description:
In developing countries, 80% of all premature and low-birth-weight infants are born far away form hospitals and traditional incubators.
In the US, an infant incubator costs $20,000. But what if we could rethink the problem and provide the world's poor with incubators for under $30 each? Stanford's "Entrepreneurial Design for Extreme Affordability" students took up the challenge.
a_low_cost_infant_incubator.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: Wow. This product won the people's choice award at INDEX http://www.indexaward.dk/index.php?option=com_content_custom&view=article&id=639:embrace-infant-warmer-&catid=40:winners-2011&Itemid=302&Itemid=302Way to go!
Yup. I actually casted my vote for Embrace, Janma and OpenIDEO, so I'm happy about the outcomes :)
Thanks for voting for us :) We are very honoured to be a finalist, of course.

Wonderful idea. It would be really wonderful if it's is affordable with materials widespread in the world, even, if you need some adaptation. I mean, go further on the Extreme Design and find a way to make it easy to produce locally.

@Daniel: I am not sure, really. I think the incubator is made out of phypoallergenic plastic "fabric" as well as wax, and I don't know if these type of materials are widespread in the developing world...
Is it possible to build this product using local materials?
Here is also a talk on this product on TED:http://www.ted.com/talks/jane_chen_a_warm_embrace_that_saves_lives.html
This is a fantastic idea.

Great inspiration Sarah. The drastically decreased price point and increased mobility could really improve access and save lives. I bet there are opportunities for innovation at the front-end of prenatal care (ultrasound, physical exams, etc.) as well to improve mother and infant health & mortality. Here's one example I came across: http://bit.ly/hFDr9j

As far as I know, since the class ended, the students incorporated as a non-profit, and began to seek funding. They are now working on piloting the product and business concepts in India (then eventually rolling it out to the rest of the world). It also seems that they're trying to file a provisional patent to use the phase-change material and for the sleeping bag design.
This is an amazing product, Sarah. Do you know if it has been deployed in the field yet?

aspirational_moments_for_dads.creator: 6a75b6ebe0dd913f0971ada060e2f7ea

comments.text: The use of imagery has been used to inspire cultural change; for some reason the way this idea is presented made me think of the broader context. We saw what happened recently in Egypt because of how quickly information spreads with the help of technology. And we're all aware (at least, subconsciously) of how the use of imagery in marketing influences our decisions and habits.I just read this article (http://genderindex.org/country/zambia) and am wondering how this idea can evolve deep-rooted cultural attitudes towards gender (in)equality. The article basically discusses the limited rights of women, polygamy, sexual violence, the weak institutions, prevalence of HIV etc. Not a cheerful read, my friends.I wonder if DNA testing to identify the father could tie in with this idea? (more research needed before weaving this into any concept; I inferred it from the article)

This could even be done in a low-tech way with aspirational quotes/feel good text messages. In India these kinds of text messages are super popular. When I was researching in Mumbai slums last year  many of our informants (especially males for some reason) would show us their favourite saved viral messages. I noticed that they would show these to each other also while hanging out together. One man's spam is a another man's inspiration!

comments.text: Great approach to this problem!  We have to ask ourselves how able or willing people are to use mobile technology.  Tech literacy is a key component to many of these ideas being widely accepted. bravo!

Meena, I like where you're going with this. "...use QR Codes to break down barriers between interface literate and illiterate phone users and thus opening the mobile phone up to its full capacity as a rapid information sharing device." QR Codes are a great idea. Just scan the code and boom, info.

Very cool Meena. Adaptive Path did a really great job of understanding illiterate users to apply QR codes in such novel way to intuitively meet their needs. In addition to the printed QR cards highlighted in the video (which could also be physically stored on the back of the phone), you could also imagine that the QR codes could be scanned directly from its display on someone's phone screen (enabling easier sharing of information whether that be the phone user's contact, their # for the local midwife, or diagrams for maternal health).

smartmoms.description:
Smartmoms is a smartphone centric program designed to bring pregnant mothers together in support groups where they learn about pregnancy, neo-natal care, health and other pregnancy related topics.  The program has multiple societal benefits, including training a wide population base in pregnancy-care and general health.  The companion smartphone will have a special app loaded with mini apps including videos, guides, emergency contact, clinic locations, and diagnostic recording.  The app will include a gaming component as a fun way to engage the women and provide incentives for the completion of the Smartmoms program.


View a live demo app here: http://smam2.shivamediagroup.com/mobile/index/SMARTmoms/
smartmoms.creator: 919e48e8de801a5fe3fa92d3f99910ca

comments.text: I love the idea of encouraging a network of women to learn together, and  videos/other smartphone content is definitely more engaging than SMS. I also like the idea of incentivizing women to complete the course (and to engage others later) with the promise of a smartphone. I'm curious if there's any risk of theft of the phones, as there is in the U.S. Would there be any need to monitor mothers' progress in the program in person, to make sure that they're actually participating and using the phones themselves?

Julien-You have incorporated several important elements of behavior change which is essential for any technological tool to make an impact in an individual;s life. I think how you are interested in fostering a community of support by grouping mothers based on which stage of pregnancy they are in. The incentives you are providing are very important to encourage the technology to be diffused in the society. In many areas of the developing world, the communities do not tend to be first adopters of new technology and thus by allowing for the mothers to take ownership of the phones in the first criterion for success. Also by providing tangible incentives that are needed for mothers, your idea provides them with not only the training via the smartphone to have a positive pregnancy experience, but also the materials they will need such as mosquito nets and neonatal vitamins. What I appreciate most of your idea is that you have created a feedback mechanism to consistency improve this product with local expertise: "Mothers groups will be able to participate in the creation and improvement of videos and content through active feedback features that are built into the smartphones capabilities." It is important as designers to acknowledge where our knowledge is limited and build the capacity to  take into account user feedback and suggestions, especially when working in developing communities. You may want to consider having some kind of meet-ups so that mothers that were not grouped together can meet and interact and share their stories. Also, by bringing together the mothers can be another opportunity to gain valuable feedback from the users themselves. Instead of just telling you what they what to see different, you can empower the mothers to work together to come up with solutions. Thus, while you are the enable of the product, you are also a mobilizer of women's empowerment beyond pregnancy.Goodluck!

Julian,I'm new to the forum, but your idea caught my attention immediately.  Even in Canada, there's support for after having a baby, but lacks (aside from a workbook I received) real on-the-go, connective support prior to.  In my case, I was involved in two medical emergencies with both pregnancies - and had no network to rely upon for questions.  Other than basic Internet bulletin board-based approaches.Even after the emergencies, there are tons of women out on Bulletin Boards asking what they should be looking for, expecting, worrying about.  But again, the in-person / peer-to-peer support is lacking.I recognize the limits of the challenge, but I'd also urge to think through the future value in a Western context, if you haven't.  We assume that all our supports are in place, and from a medical standpoint they usually are, but from a peer-to-peer support network, that is not always the case.Cheers

Hi Julian, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of a mobile driven education program for mothers.We encourage you to work with Dan Braus to incorporate his thoughts from: Mom Community Gardens http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/mom-community-gardens/Could there be a local hub, a community garden, where mothers can gather for these education sessions? Could this also provide other social services for mothers?When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields: - Concept Builds - Here you can list additional builds on your concept - Virtual Team - Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept. Cheers! OpenIDEO

hey julian, congratulation for reaching the final 20! One question Id like to ask you is how do you imagine the support in person? Is there someone explaining how to use the phone in the first group meeting, or is he/she attending each meeting? I see older people in western countries struggeling with smartphones if they are not too tech affiliated so how automonous do you think could your concept work?

Hi Julien, Last week I saw an interesting add-on for mobile phones you can maybe include in this concept. During the meetings with pregnant women you can use an add-on that is able to make echos. You can see the baby grow on your mobile phone! For more information: http://mobihealthnews.com/10165/fda-approves-mobisantes-smartphone-ultrasound/Hope it is valuable for you. And good luck!

The idea does a good job correlating the lack of education with expected life patterns.There seems to be a sharp difference between educating an alcoholic at an AA meeting, AFTER life-altering encounters, and educating a young person about the dangers BEFORE s/he is likely to be exposed to the situation.What if, instead of (or in addition to) targeting the most visible group (pregnant women)...we focused resources on educating young girls?

Thanks Vincent!  I strongly believe that creating a support group can play a big role in maternal health.  Rather than just relying on what they learned for themselves, women can put their education into practice by helping each other.
Interesting insight on how sharing of phones between mothers can not only increase cost effectiveness, but also build mutual support networks.

Julien is by far one of the more insightful thinkers on this website. This is a very progressive ideas that I'm on board with. I am a mother of twins and would have loved to have this when I was pregnant.

All but the very poorest of the poor (who don't have cell phones anyway) care about entertainment celebrities. This transcends all regions and cultures, except perhaps among the Taliban. So this could be a great method to get health information to poor and working-class young mothers in developing nations and to motivate them to do what they need to do.
