pregnancy_nutrition_package.description: This concept focuses on making nutritional intake convenient, attractive, and culturally-relevant to improve maternal and infant mortality and morbidity (direct improvements on anemia, neural development, infection, low birth weight, premature delivery, hemorrhage, heart failure, etc.). It was inspired by posts by Alessandro, Suzanne, Avi, Meena, Jennica, Chris, and others on this topic, as well as this New York Times Op-Ed: http://nyti.ms/69smBR . The example below focuses on the big 2 pregnancy nutrients (iron & folate/folic acid/vitamin B9), but depending on the common nutritional deficiencies in a region, this package could be adapted to account for other important nutrients as iodine, zinc, and vitamin A. This would also have broader effect on the long term health of the community. And adherence may be higher vs. traditional supplements that people often forget about or are afraid to take (fear of birth control side effects, etc)
pregnancy_nutrition_package.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Hey Vincent, I know this challenge is over, but I found something that I think is quite interesting and wanted to share w/ you- ..."President Evo Morales's government has even designated quinoa a "strategic" foodstuff and included it in a subsidized food parcel for pregnant women." http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/25/how_food_explains_the_world?page=0,6. It kind of also relates to the Food Challenge we currently have...

Thanks for sharing this Krassimira! The OpenIDEO challenge may be over, but the broader world issue most certainly is not. Quinoa indeed looks quite promising.And you're right about the application to the food challenge, I particularly like the page on eating insects: http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/04/25/how_food_explains_the_world?page=0,3

To follow up on Crystal, I agree that those population might have a strong culture of cultivating by themselves. Hence, the SMS could also tell you when to plant ! Plus, distributing seed is cheaper and more environmental friendly (cost of transport).Good luck- nice project

Thanks for the suggestion Crystal. Have incorporated a reference to this in the "Concept Builds" section, as well as adding you to the virtual team. Was curious, know of any success examples out there where this approach has worked? Also, thought you would find Dan's concept of "Mom Community Gardens" very relevant: http://bit.ly/dJeQ4f

Hey Vincent,I love this idea. Providing fortified cookware and SMS reminders is what really brings it all full circle. Have you considered how to also integrate personal or community farming by providing seeds so that they can grow some of the local food on their own? That would go a long way towards encouraging them to eat what they need it could also help assuage food costs, especially if some of the iron-rich foods are more expensive.

Thanks Simon! I really appreciate your support and insight on the importance of an actionable & concrete behavior change pathway, that draws from your firsthand personal experience working on international public health projects.

The strongest aspect of your project is that the pathway of behavior change is concrete and actionable. After working on international public health projects for several years, I've seen first hand how many interventions that attempt to bring about behavior change with education and awareness messages alone can be unsuccessful. By combining the sms messaging with the pot and cooking information, recipients will have all the components and tools needed to act on the educational messages. Health education campaigns can fail when the information being disseminated (an abstract idea) is not linked immediate practical factors (for instance, think of AIDS prevention campaigns that encourage people to use condoms, but in certain contexts condoms may be unavailable or quite expensive). Your project overcomes this hurdle. Nicely done.

@Margaret: thanks for your adds. I agree that there are contexts where supplements may make more sense and do feel there are opportunities for the broader community to contribute financially to support the wellbeing of a mother & child. In fact, I posted a related concept integrating these themes here: http://bit.ly/i1DJPy . Would love to get your thoughts on this related concept, and perhaps how it could be fit in here?@Tristan: Fortified bread, great! Just read something about triple fortified table salt as well: http://bit.ly/eYOYhy . I think part of the strength of this concept is that there's flexibility to allow for adaptation to different regions.
This is pretty great idea.We've been putting Folic acid in bread in Australia now for awhile.http://www.mja.com.au/public/issues/194_02_170111/bro10844_fm.html

Relevant article in Economist March 26, "Hidden Hunger". Points out the Vitamin A deficiency problem, Helen Keller International project in India to provide seeds and advice for gardens.  I personally think that vitamin pills make sense  because drought and water availability can limit what can be grown   I'd suggest tying in the idea of cellphone micropayments from donors to help pay for vitamins, greens, pulses, etc. This could get the food and vitamins directly to the individuals when they purchase the goods and the seller is paid  by cellphone.  It needs some type of bar-coding or photo-coding to minimize fraud, I guess.  But it might bypass the middlemen and government sticky hands.

Hey there Vincent! Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea posted here and as part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought to what might be involved. When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields: + Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept + Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept. Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Hi Kara, I came across Sprinkles and posted a brief link to it as a building comment in a related Community Micro-Funded Baby Booster concept ( http://bit.ly/i1DJPy ) that I think may be of interest to you, as it attempts to tackle affordability through mobile-facilitated community funding. Very cool that you're actually working to test it out in Rwanda. Thanks for nudging me about it's applicability here, especially as there's such a broad nutrient overlap, and efforts are underway to formulate Sprinkles versions for pregnant women. Have integrated a reference to Sprinkles in the "Other Nutritional Sources" section of the Concept Builds.

Thanks for including everyone in your builds, Vincent! I wanted to add some further notes as I've been working on a project around nutrition for mothers who can't afford fortified foods for their 6-24 month old children (part of a team who is aiming to test it out in Rwanda but you may want to check it out as a tested method of improving nutrition for this age range (which could align nicely with helping mothers too). I'm hoping to connect the mobile aspect once we determine accessibility/cost in various regions.For what it is worth, here is the link: http://www.sghi.org
Great discussion guys! And Vincent  love how you're so ready to give attribution to folks who have been part of your OpenIDEATING :^)
Just added Meena, Jennica, and Chris to the inspirational credits in the text as well.

Hey Alessandro, your posts were definitely a huge inspiration for me here! Great thoughts on the zinc (also from cooking container) and iodine (salt).I've actually been having trouble with trying to get all the related inspiration and concepts to all link. Some seem to drop off each time I post. For awhile, half the page views on this were from me just continually re-updating the post to try to give everyone credit! Sometimes once I get all the links in, I'm actually afraid to update, worried that something will drop out. Anyways, I think your inspiration is properly linked on both of my submitted concepts now...fingers crossed.

Thanks for the contribution, Vincent! I really like this subject and REALLY believe in it as a solution to many problems related to women's health. Anemia affects about 50% of women in low-income countries. It is very thing! With respect to nutrients, iron pan also liberates zinc, which is interesting. Iodine, in many countries, is added in table salt, which solves reasonably the issue of goiter. Folate is available from good nutrition ...(Hey, you forgot to include my inspiration here along ...)

Thanks for the support and great adds Krassimira! Business in a bag kits for mobile maternal entrepreneurs is a promising distribution approach and the phone-charging stove sounds like a cool option where electricity is not readily available.

Vincent, love the idea! How about this:Regarding Cooking Container: we can make use of the stove that could charge a phone-  http://bit.ly/gjTQaH. As far as the distribution model goes for the stoves, Kara's inspiration would fit well in my opinion- http://bit.ly/eW4RUq. What do you think?

Below is my section for "technology" needed for concept, as well as potential sponsorship opportunities, as it doesn't seem to be showing up on the post:Potential places for sponsorship (by Oxfam, Nokia, telecom providers, multinationals or local companies, government, etc.):1.  Cooking Container: perhaps if this could be purchased at an affordable price, bundled with the handout and text messaging service, it would be frequently used and displayed, becoming an aspirational object that other households want as well.2.  Food/Images/Names Handout: A food or grocery company can pay for the development and printing, especially if it comes with coupons3.  Cellphone Coaching: automated text messages/ voice calls, and maybe even the cellphone, could be subsidized by telecom carriers and cellphone providers like Nokia. Pre-existing solutions for automated voice calls and text messages can be leveraged.

disrupting_innovation_on_extreme_situati.description: NetHope’s “Network Relief Kit” fits in a backpack!. One of the great new innovations at tech non-profit NetHope is called the Network Relief Kit (NRK) - satellite receiver about the size of a medium-sized textbook. It provides a broadband connection to the Internet, runs off a car battery (or small solar panel) and works almost anywhere on the planet. It has a built-in wireless router for WiFi to support up to ten laptops or Internet phones. So it creates a fast, temporary but crucial voice and data communications hub for a small group of fieldworkers when they need it most immediately – in emergencies.
disrupting_innovation_on_extreme_situati.creator: 8d6e426c5c9f6f7272bff21cadbf0c4d

Giving some kind of incentive for the human being always gave a lot of results. This suggestion was made by Dan Braus in this inspiration: http://tinyurl.com/4rdnzl2.
Incentive as:
  - Money incentives (my paycheck)
   - 'Points' incentives (my DQ score or my Xbox LIVE rating)
   - Peer acceptance incentives (Applause or 'Like' on facebook)
   - When I was younger I used to get candy at the doctors office...
Was given by him.
This concept that can turn some action in one kind of reward and creating a new currency is called creative money or sometimes social money.

health_points_on_urban_card.description: My city /Wroclaw, Poland/ is planning to start a new programme this spring, to enable the citizens profit from healthy lifestyle. It is called 'The city in shape". The health points will be gathered on an urban card each time you go to the gym, to a swimming-pool, to get an extra  vaccine, to buy a health equipement, to buy healthy food. The point will be exchanged to discounts and special gifts. Normally, the urban card is used for city communication - busses, trams, trains and parking fees, but their functionality will be extended.

crowd_source_childbirth_financing_throug.description: Set up a "child fund" savings account for mom, dad, family, and friends to contribute money towards for the one-time childbirth expense.  Increase access & earmark usage of this fund by administering it through a mobile money account, which is connected to a traveling maternity clinic. Child 'supporters' send money via SMS (text).
crowd_source_childbirth_financing_throug.creator: 4565ae8593aea655196aef5881206c2a

comments.text: I really like the addition to the concept of letting expectant mothers 'work' in clinics. It's a great way to address the lack of staff as well as costs of childbirth. I'd add that fathers, relatives, friends could also get involved? Perhaps then it could be a scheme that could filter out to a whole community, whereby people can 'work' up extra hours and in exchange get better facilities.

Dianna, good point about the scenario of not raising enough money for the minimum threshold. In that situation, I suppose the maternal organization that's administering the account would transfer ownership back to the mom so she can use it for whatever prenatal care is possible on her own. The other point you suggested is very interesting! Expectant mothers, who cannot otherwise earn a wage, 'work' in clinics and serve moms who are farther along in pregnancy. (e.g.) For every day she serves in the clinic, the expectant mom earns $15 into her "child fund" while at the same time addressing the shortage in health care personnel in rural area.

I really like the idea of targeted savings accounts for a specific purpose (like childbirth) and think it could lay the groundwork for other savings schemes (school fees, emergency funds, etc), like Meena referred to.  The question is, what happens if the mom doesn't "raise" enough money, and would she be able to access it if she needed to pay her own transport in an emergency, or for another purpose?  We could also build on this concept by playing around with the idea of setting up a fund that makes deposits into a mother's "childbirth fund" based on her utilization of antenatal clinics and her participation in one of the other pregnancy advice platforms.  This would incentive the mom's participation in those programs and help her build up her savings account based on her own participation.

Hey Meena, cool article! Although you lose the financial advice and emotional connection of a visiting 'banker', I think the M-PESA vehicle allows women who live in suppressive environments to quietly and securely move money around. I imagine that women in the BoP have little household control over the money they bring in from wages. Incremental savings for other child expenses is a good idea, and I wish I had access to typical expense/wage numbers to see if it could work financially.

Some great stuff here, Peter. It could also be about saving incrementally for your own child via M-Pesa, etc. I came across a flourishing micro-savings scheme in the slums of Mumbai a while back and was amazed at the stories of what could be achieved by saving just a little at a time: http://www.randomspecific.com/women-together-incentivising-savings

crowd_source_childbirth_financing_throug.title: Crowd-source childbirth financing through SMS money

comments.text: Vincent, thanks for the kind words. We all have role models; for me it was a friend that helped me believe I could make a difference to people just through who I am. I spent years in business and the thing I enjoyed most was releasing and developing talent in people.If this is true in business, it is even more true in changing behaviours in communities in need. We work with community leaders and identify positive role models. Then we give them mentoring training and teach them how they can support & encourage others. See my white paper on Mobile technologies for social transformation. (http://nimbus.mobi/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/Mobile-technologies-for-social-transformation-concept-paper.pdf)

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback Sean. I was using the solar panel more as a graphic then actual sizing. Part of the inspiration for this concept was the WE CARE Solar suitcase (WECARESolar.com) which has many panels to power equipment. This concept would be similar but integrate the education of the midwives and have a mobile link to the hospitals. I see it as the solar suitcase with an infrastructure.

While I love the idea of the midwife suitcase, the components that you've mentioned will require quite a bit of electricity beyond what can be provided by the small solar panel that you've pictured above. While that solar panel would be sufficient to charge the cell phone, charging some of the other items you've mentioned ("heart rate monitor, ultrasound, incubator blanket") would require a larger solar installation. I wonder if there is a way to create a central hub (with rooftop solar panel installations) where larger lithium ion or lead acid batteries could be charged for use in powering these additional devices. While the suitcase concept is great, nothing could be worse than a collection of underpowered or uncharged electronic devices when the birth or another emergency arrived. I'd also love to see some kind of educational materials or teaching curriculum included in the suitcase. While the midwife will be trained elsewhere in this model, having simple illustrated curriculum materials for the midwife to use when instructing / interacting with local members of the community would be quite helpful I think. Great idea and would love to see it taken further!

one_laptop_per_child_wisdom_from_a_prece.description:
What can we learn from One Laptop Per Child?

As I studied this precedent, I wondered the following: Should there be 2 components of our program? The first component shifts cultural behavior by targeting young children, particularly young girls. Women begin to have children at the age of 12! The second component of the program could deal directly with the current crisis to reduce birth-related deaths. Both rely on mobile technology. It seems to me that in addition to providing band-aids, we would also want to confront the problem at its root.

comments.text: The price of a pedal generator is between $ 200 to $ 500 or so.Have no information about the durability of the equipment, but equipment is very robust and simple.The average rider will produce between 125 and 300 watts using the Pedal-a-Watt.  While this may not seem like much power, many pieces of equipment draw very little power and can be powered for long spans of time with small amounts of power.Lights, laptops, and radios all draw small amounts of power.  In addition, LED lighting and high efficiency fluorescent lighting now allow 200 watts to go a long way.  A typical 25 watt fluorescent light bulb, which replaces a 100 watt incandescent bulb, will last 8 hours on 200 watts worth of power.  LEDs (light emitting diodes) are even more efficient and will last days on 200 watts worth of power.Want  to know if you can power an appliance?  Look at the label on the rear (usually by the power cord) and find out the "rating" which is in watts.  For example, the label may read 30 W under electrical rating and this is 30 watts.  If you are unsure, please email us with questions.Power Consumption of Typical Appliances:Small TV                               75 wattsLarge TV                             200 wattsLaptop PC                             10 wattsDesktop PC                           75 wattsStereo                                    20 wattsCharging a cellphone               5 wattsHi Effic Desk lamp                 15 wattsAn Explanation of Watts vs. Watt-HoursWatts is an instantaneous measure of power at any moment in time. Watt-hours is a measure of power over time.For example, if the Pedal-A-Watt is creating 200 watts of power while being pedaled if you pedal for 2 hours, then you have created 400 watt-hours ( 200 watts x 2 hours) of power.This 400 watt-hours would power a 100 watt light bulb for 4 hours, a 200 watt large screen TV for 2 hours and so on.By: http://www.econvergence.net/electro.htm

I really like this idea, I think it's simple and effective.  I'm curious about the economics behind it, do you happen to know how much a basic pedal generator costs, how much energy can be generated per hour, on average, and what the lifespan of the machine is?  This could have broader benefits beyond hospitals!  If the economics work out, perhaps gov's could also set up a public station where people can come and recharge their batteries.  If placed next to clinics, it could even create an incentive to get checked up more often.

Thanks, Vincent! Sorry about the delay in responding! I've been sick for a few days ... I find the bike idea is very good, however, also do not know if that would significantly reduce the cost of the generator, and there would always be the need to take a bike around for the power generation, which could not happen at certain times. So, I still think that the best combination is a complete set. The most expensive component of the set is really the dynamo. For the other hand, this could be very useful to a health visitor or midwife that traveled up the family home. Especially if the transportation is by bicycle!
Well spotted Vincent! Cheers for sharing
Hi Alessandro, excited to share this with you: http://bit.ly/gESgK9 , http://bit.ly/fFl9UT

Yes, Meena .. would be interesting ... and if the pedal generator has an energy meter to measure the energy generated by the user? This counter could generate a code  based, among other things, in the energy generated (Coded by a secret algorithm to prevent fraud). The user could send the code by SMS to an... "central", and the credit could be converted into benefits. What do you thing?
And maybe husbands, etc could earn credits towards baby supplies based on stored energy they generate?
Great idea Alessandro! I totally relate to this, as I am one of those who like to do something "physical" when they're stressed out or anxious...
Thanks, Krassimira! The energy can be stored in ordinary car batteries.
I love this idea, too! I'm just curious- how can this energy be stored? or can it be stored at all?
Really loving this Concept! Great idea Alessandro.
Funny idea, but one I could actually see working too!

9_months_of_knowing.description: When childbirth and the 9 months of pregnancy becomes a "women" only activity its also more vulnerable and may not get the necessary political and community support it needs. This simple information sharing idea will make the dads more updated, involved and prepared. Its important to include the dads and make them feel like they are part of the pregnancy on fair terms, that they have access to information.
9_months_of_knowing.creator: bd752ee637110e10075b9e95e5f96e90

comments.text: One more idea as I like your attention to involving both parents. In attempting to think outside the 9 month period for which you've already proposed a great idea, I wonder if games (as described below) could target young couples with innovative content aimed to increase their understanding of the significant resources required to raise a child. For example, the game could highlight the cost of health care, food, clothing, and education a child needs. In some cases, couples may give greater consideration to not having children if the practical considerations are laid out in a fun, entertaining way.

Hi Anna, I agree that involving men is extremely important. Your concept began made me consider how fathers may be encouraged to get involved in promoting safe and proactive maternal health practices even before pregnancy. I believe mobile interactive games could deliver powerful messages of prevention and proactive measures women and men can take to enable a healthy pregnancy, while also clarifying common misconceptions about pre- and post-natal care.  Linking these games to mobile phones that are widely used in many developing countries can increase mens awareness about womens pre- and post-natal health in areas where many women suffer due to a lack of understanding about pregnancy and childbirth.  Integrating public health facts and good practices into entertaining games that males and females can enjoy could lead to meaningful behavioral change. Your concept made me consider a few more benefits of targeting young men using educational and entertaining interactive mobile games: -   Games can be locally tailored according to local culture and incorporate  interactive messages contextually adapted for regional needs, religious and social norms and activities. For example, games based on popular sports, such as cricket or football, may attract more users. -   Since some young mens immediate reaction to maternal health and pre- and post-natal care may be that its a womens issue, games can incorporate broader public health themes that are interrelated and interdependent. For example, information about nutrition and agriculture, water and sanitation, employment, HIV/AIDS, malaria, climate change, etc. can be incorporated. Oxfam, with its knowledge and networks, is an excellent partner to provide the expertise to make this information meaningful and accurate.-   Delivery of maternal health awareness information in the form of  interactive mobile phone games may particularly appeal to a generation of tech-savvy consumers who may be bored or unaffected by traditional public service messaging. -   Targeting young people, who may be most vulnerable to maternal death and disability, enables them to become critical agents of change who can transform policies, programming, and culture to reflect their right to comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services.-   Though this concept was designed with young men in mind, its appeal and influence is expected to be much wider (ie. integrating the edges).   If we combined "9 months of knowing" with preparatory entertaining and educational interactive games Dads could be informed and involved throughout the process. Thanks for sharing your idea Anna!

9_months_of_knowing.title: 9 months of knowing

thoughts_from_a_retired_doctor.description: So many inspiring ideas from your community! As a 78 year old retired obstetrics/gyne I thought I'd share a few challenges for low-income maternal health.
thoughts_from_a_retired_doctor.creator: 1ee1dfdbf68318030a68d76dfb1fb720

comments.text: living in egypt, I can tell you a lot of the low-income families living in areas with limited availability of doctors and clinis, families rely on "expert" mothers to deliver their babies. These mothers have no formal training and arent authorized doctors, however they use traditional methods to deliver which can prove quite dangerous at times. I would add to your inspiration that these network of mothers in low-income areas need to be connected to the nearest clinics. Maybe keeping a central record of all soon to deliver moms and proactively monitoring their sitation.

This is very helpful to all our thinking. It particular "the importance of raising awareness for fathers  attitudes can be nudged from the notion that maternal health is in the women's domain to one of co-responsibility". This is expanded on in Mobile mentoring of male partners as part of an integrated approach to maternal health - (http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/mobile-mentoring-of-male-partners-as-part-of-an-integrated-approach-to-maternal-health/)

The importance of proper nutrition reminded me of the Plumpy'Nut story (see http://nyti.ms/i1aeJv), the successful (and controversial) fortified peanut butter that has had amazing impact in fighting malnutrition places like post-earthquake Haiti.  I found a medical paper describing the results of similar product's beneficial effect on Gambian mothers who were breastfeeding. http://bit.ly/f5mF06 (via Christine Gorman, part of a group at Harvard Law blogging about patenting peanut butter http://bit.ly/fSKM31)Not sure I'd want to live off peanut butter, but it does suggest a line of mobile services around accessible nutrition, like easy recipes or advice for eating right per trimester delivered over SMS. There are no doubt dozens of books and magazine articles on the subject that just need broader (plus timely and tailored) distribution. Slight side-note, but it reminds me of a great insight from This American Life's story (http://bit.ly/i0KTdE) about the Harlem Children's Zone. The founder's big 'Aha!' was that parents in Harlem weren't tuned into the same media (and therefore 'common wisdom') around child-rearing and weren't getting the message: Read to your children.  They created a support network around encourage parents to be better parents.  Great story. #cmmn @thisamerlife
I'm interested in how we can blend together the community and the technological. Thanks for sharing

Thank you for sharing Chandra! I would like to emphasize your comment regarding nutrition. The first inspiration I posted was a mobile app for tracking breastfeeding, which I shared because I am a breastfeeding enthusiast! I honestly don't know where to start to solve maternal nutrition issues, what I do know is that breastfeeding babies is a wonderful (if not best) way to provide them with all the nutrition that they need - and its free!
Thank you, Chandra. It is very inspiring to hear these remarks about maternal health. These 3 guiding principles (community, communication, nutrition) I think are key in this challenge.
Great to benefit from your expertise and experience Chandra. From community health workers to family support to telemedicine to nutrition--lots of food for thought!

thoughts_from_a_retired_doctor.title: Thoughts from a Retired Doctor

comments.text: Very interesting discussion! I love the idea of using incentives to (actively) educate, and vice versa.

Ian G, I think it is a brilliant idea! And your elaboration definitely makes a clear distinction between withholding essential care from patients, and encouraging participation of patients in their own essential care. I also agree with the principle of incentives. An interesting thing that happened to a friend of mine: the lady who worked for him - a woman from a rural community, with minimal education - once commented on obtaining a debit-card, so that she can also "get money" from the ATM. After a discussion, they discovered that she actually believed that when you have that card, it entitles you to an actual limitless supply of cash. (Much like Paris Hilton's seemingly foolish belief that credit cards connects you to an infininite source of money.) Education breeds what we wrongly label 'common sense'.My point? An incentive could help create insight, and educate patients more than merely supplying services to a passive participant. In a situation that goes further than mere pregnancy-training, these moms are exposed to passive education, into the inner workings of a health-care system, and can possibly obtain a new respect for all the resources and infrastructure needed to provide this serviceAnother interesting article on the "hot topic" of aid: http://www.worldpress.org/Asia/3535.cfm#down

Ian I agree that it would be ideal to make healthcare free for everyone. However, since nothing is free and has to be paid for by someone, this system could help reduce costs and make care available for more people.  I'm not advocating an "earn it or receive nothing" type of plan.Let me explain a little more. I live in a state where a local church has a welfare program that outperforms any other welfare program in the world.  It helps more people with less money and allows people to take responsibility for their own welfare.  In fact, the system works so well that leaders from almost every single developed country have come to see this welfare system in action so they can learn how to improve their own system.  Almost every U.S. president in the last 50 years has also come here to learn from this system.  So what is the big difference?Instead of just handing out free food to everyone who wants it, the people in need come to the cannery and help can food for a few hours.  Once they are done canning food, they take whatever food home that they need (usually about 1 or 2  weeks worth of food).  This allows them to not only help themselves, but to help others at the same time.  It infuses confidence that they can help themselves and teaches how to work.  It also significantly reduces costs allowing the system to help many more people than it would otherwise.  Almost the entire system is run on volunteers from the community, the church and those receiving welfare.Welfare is still available for those who cannot help can food.  In fact, the food is shipped all over the world to people in need.  But for those who are able, the system expects them to come help when possible.  The biggest surprise is how excited people are to "earn" food by helping with the canning for themselves and for others. Sorry if I didn't make it more clear in the concept. The volunteer work would be highly encouraged, but not absolutely necessary to receive services. Excuse the insanely long comment, I just wanted to clarify and give more background.

Hi Ian, thanks for this concept! I think involving pregnant mothers could be a great idea at level 2, or in communities where it would be culturally acceptable for pregnant mothers to work. It might be more difficult for more remote rural areas, since the idea was to bring health care to these moms, in their natural environment, instead of asking them to go to health centers (that could be far away).That being said, I really love the on-the-job training idea, this could be kept in mind in any type of situations, by adopting a more "participatory" training amongst pregnant moms in a given community rather than a bottom-up type of knowledge transfer.

I disagree quite profoundly with the incentive for this concept. Healthcare for all, and especially mothers, should be free and I wouldn't want to encourage projects where this had tro be "earned". I think this is a precedant that we wouldn't want to set. That said, is there something in the idea of training for women - so they can play a role as community volunteers?

onkur_turning_a_waste_into_a_resource.description: In the US 426,000 cell phones get thrown away every day. Most of them work perfectly well. “Onkur” is a concept of harvesting this wasted resource that only sits in landfills to make a difference in people’s lives in the developing world. The penetration of cell phones into remote areas in the developing world is almost complete. Even villages that lack basic essentials like running water, schools, hospitals and so on do have cellular service. The system design concept presented in the following pages envisages a plan to re-program these discarded cell phones and to hand them out to poor pregnant women in remote areas connecting them to a health service network. As the target population is often illiterate or semi-literate information flow is through visual images and voice messages in the local language.
onkur_turning_a_waste_into_a_resource.creator: b3b1b846a118b0b143122f5acb4a1df4

comments.text: I've added an "Implementation" paragraph where I'm explaining how I'm imagining the first implementation steps as a pilot conducted in Uganda.

Wow Sarah this is such a brilliant idea - especially for people working in rural areas who may not be able to collect money from their employer during business hours since they are out in the field doing the work!  I hope it happens!
Thanks Susan! I also truly believe in this concept and would love to see it moving towards realization, but I guess it's all up to the people who will evaluate by now :)

There is no doubt in my mind that mobile payment systems have a huge potential for improvement - not only in health but more broadly in finding sustainable (monitisable) solutions in Africa in a range of areas that can improve economic development such as energy and water quality.Based on my work in Zambia, I've had to source bank accounts for 140 staff (women, mostly very vulnerable, living with HIV) in order to pay them. Once they have the accounts they then need to travel to the bank in order to get the funding.  Additionally, it is currently complex to provide expenses - money used for travel etc that needs to be provided or reimbursed.  Expenses are often paid into a bank account upfront to allow for staff to be able to afford to travel etc.  If mobile payments are immediate it would be possible to pay the amount to a mobile phone for expenses on the day that it's needed reducing the risk that the money is spent elsewhere. We have shifted to a mobile based system and the systems have been vastly improved. The banking system is not user friendly to most Zambians who do not have easy access to transport and are often in rural areas. I do want to provide some insights on the following, "Possibility to include a performance-based bonus to provide monetary incentives to health care workers who deliver on set targets. For instance, mobiles could be applied to similar programs like Rwandas performance-based initiative for traditional birth attendants: attendants who bring pregnant women to hospitals for delivery or accurately refer emergency cases to hospitals receive cash payments as reward."  I would like to raise a caution because the health system in many poor countries are made up of many different NGOs and in such complex systems small changes to incentives can have unintended consequences such as favouring one area of health supported by the NGO that provides a bonus over another. I do, however, believe that mobile payment of a "bonus" to clients who travel large distances in the form of reimbursement could improve the number of women visiting the centre and is the way of the future. Great idea!
Hi Tamsin, thank you very much for sharing your experience in Zambia, and thank you for the valuable insight as per the performance-based feature! I highly appreciate it.

There is no doubt in my mind that mobile payment systems have a huge potential for improvement - not only in health but more broadly in finding sustainable (monitisable) solutions in Africa in a range of areas that can improve economic development such as energy and water quality.Based on my work in Zambia, I've had to source bank accounts for 140 staff (women, mostly very vulnerable, living with HIV) in order to pay them. For instance, mobiles could be applied to similar programs like Rwandas performance-based initiative for traditional birth attendants: attendants who bring pregnant women to hospitals for delivery or accurately refer emergency cases to hospitals receive cash payments as reward." I do, however, believe that mobile payment of a "bonus" to clients who travel large distances in the form of reimbursement could improve the number of women visiting the centre and is the way of the future. Great idea!

Hey Sarah! I really like this concept. In developed countries, we tend to forget the underlying forces that shape our interactions, and economic development. I'm referring specifically to laws that recognize property and ownership. Without it, capitalism collapses.The concept goes a long way in addressing this issue, and several others. Electronic payments may seem like a small evolutionary step for those of us in developed nations, but it is paradigm-shifting in the developing world. Congratulations. :)
Absolutely :) Thanks Kirk!

I really like this idea.  I think it might be useful to keep track of the work in Haiti with cell phones being used as debit cards.http://www.npr.org/2011/01/30/133305663/in-haiti-cell-phones-serve-as-debit-cards
Thank you Susan! And thanks for sharing this link!

Hi Anita! Thank you so much for sharing your experience. I've heard so much about mobile money in Uganda but never really got to go there and check it out myself. Simon: I appreciate your comment, and thanks for sharing you friend's work. I've had a look at it and the voucher-based system they describe is really interesting. It's very promising to see the Uganda pilot being able to work out with so many different stakeholders (aid agencies, health services providers, mobile platform developers, government, etc.). Thank you!

Fantastic idea Sarah :) I totally applaud. In Uganda, Mobile money has just taken off and i was surprised at how popular it has become - my house-help was telling me how she used it to send school fees to her sister :) She just walked 3 minutes and she was able to find a mobile money agent. One of the reasons it works so well here is because many small businesses are telecom related (selling airtime and other related services) You will not walk 5 minutes without seeing a shop/kiosk/person selling airtime. That is just how our communities have sprawled. This has made it easier for telecom companies to provide these services to the majority. Many of these shop owners have also upgraded to mobile money agent status. With the current low transaction costs, and small biz opportunities, this is definitely self sustaining. And because many of these shops are located just about everywhere you go, user education has consequently resulted more from people buzz/ interaction :)

I really like the fact that you have thought of mobile phones as more than devices that can spread important health information - and made use of them in the administrative and management sides of health care. This comment also holds true for the "Medicine stock-outs" project as well.A friend of mine at Berkeley is working on related issues - and I wanted to introduce her work to you in case it is of interest - see the link below. http://www.ictdchick.com/research/

Fantastic idea Sarah :) I totally applaud. In Uganda, Mobile money has just taken off and i was surprised at how popular it has become - my house-help was telling me how she used it to send school fees to her sister :) She just walked 3 minutes and she was able to find a mobile money agent. One of the reasons it works so well here is because many small businesses are telecom related (selling airtime and other related services) You will not walk 5 minutes without seeing a shop/kiosk/person selling airtime. That is just how our communities have sprawled. This has made it easier for telecom companies to provide these services to the majority. Many of these shop owners have also upgraded to mobile money agent status. With the current low transaction costs, and small biz opportunities, this is definitely self sustaining. And because many of these shops are located just about everywhere you go, user education has consequently resulted more from people buzz/ interaction :)
Thank you so much Vincent :)
Great job continuing to delve into the details and build up this concept Sarah. I'm absolutely convinced =)

Hi Krassimira! Not yet, but they're planning on launching a financial education pilot this year: http://bit.ly/dVuPaII'd be happy to discuss what other financial literacy initiatives exist out there. Even though mobile banking has its specifics, most of it all comes back to basic understanding of the financial services themselves, and the consumer rights and duties.
Sarah, do you know if they started some kind of educational program to increase financial literacy and to overcome the mistrust amongst the farmers?

Here is another interesting example I found, from Mobile Transactions Zambia Limited (MTZL) and Dunavant, a large cotton ginning company that finances and buys cotton from smallholder farmers in largely rural areas: http://bit.ly/hhfpa4Dunavants challenge was the time it took to make cash payments to these farmers  often two weeks or more. MTZL designed and piloted an m-payments system for Dunavant to pay the farmers.There are two things I learned from this case study:1. Attracting additional private-sector investment: After the completion of the pilot, Dunavant decided to invest in MTZL, and now owns a 25-percent stake.2. Financial literacy: Farmers distrust of electronic money was one of the biggest challenges. In order to sustainably introduce m-money in Zambia, there needs to be a focus on increasing financial literacy and awareness of the benefits of m-money, to help clients develop trust in the system and make them more comfortable with sending and receiving funds via their mobile phones.

Hi everyone,I have tried to dive deeper into the details of this concept, and I have explained  what I see are the advantages, the opportunities and the constraints of this concept. I have also given further information about how it would work in a low-literacy context. In addition to the minimum level of technology, I added the main regulatory restrictions that could be an issue.@Vincent: Agreed, and thanks for bringing up this point! You might find this interesting, mobile money is 54% cheaper than informal options for money transfer: http://bit.ly/dzcSxI@Crystal: The good point about mobile money is that you don't have to carry cash around with you, nor use ATMs. In the cases where you need cash, you would go to an agent to cash out.
@OpenIDEO: Roger that! And already using both new fields :)

Hey Sarah,Congrats! This is very compelling and has a great potential to address other related issues around corruption in unstable countries and regions. It also allows people who may not have opened or who may have been unable to open bank accounts to do so. The only question I have is: How can this work in a country that has an insular banking service or unstable banking system? When I traveled to Mocambique, many years ago, I learned the hard way that I could not just travel through Africa on a credit card. I was unable to extract cash from the ATMs because they were not in communication with outside banks. In fact, cash was the preferred method of payment, and it had to be their currency because it was near impossible to exchange dollars or rands anywhere. Although plastic and wire transfers are not exactly the same, the concern may require some thought.

Hey there Sarah!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge!We really like your idea to enable payment of HCWs via mobile. As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought into what might be involved. When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Hi Sarah. Clearly there are strong success cases for mobile payments/transfers in Kenya, Afghanistan, and elsewhere. Kudos for envisioning how this can be applied to paying health care workers. Just wanted to mention for those worried about transaction costs/fees, that it's important to account for these, but that they become much more reasonable the higher the amount (which would be the case for larger salary transfers). Here's an example of M-Pesa's charges: http://www.safaricom.co.ke/index.php?id=255

Thanks Krassimira! Actually it's not that difficult to implement on a technical level, as long as you have the mobile money / virtual wallet platform, and any type of payment / money transfer feature. Here is a link where you can visualize all mobile money deployments globally: http://www.wirelessintelligence.com/mobile-money and these services are pretty common (except for rare cases due to prudential policy barriers in terms of the restrictions places on the float -possible use, balance limits, interest earning, insurance, etc.). I think that this is the strongest weakness of this concept: the business model is highly dependent on the regulatory framework, and thus on the country we're in.

Sarah, I came across the following mobile banking providers who offer the service direct deposit of salaries- Smart Money in the Philippines and Wizzit in South Africa....so, maybe they have some good use cases...

i really like this idea, particularly in at-risk areas or areas suffering from instability. I know they use MPESA (different spelling) in Kenya, and people have relied on this as a safe way to travel "with money". Great thinking here Sarah (as usual)!

Thanks for the comments!Sarah: Absolutely. Not only wouldn't they have to travel, but they could also transfer easily money to their relatives once they have the mobile money service set up. As long as their relatives live near an agent, this could be a lot safer than sending the money via a bus driver or something.

Excellent, idea, I believe this is also being done in Pakistan - http://www.tameerbank.com/moneytransfer.htm I think another advantage is that it means that health care workers don't have to travel to receive their salary enabling them to either get the day off they deserve or spend more time with patients.  Great addition to the concepts
This is a good solution for all the payment process in this organizations... but it would be good to think in a way to hand this tech to all people possible.
Great Sarah  simple yet potentially very effective.

i_feel_u_feel.description:
It's rural China and Bah-Ling lives in a small village caring for her 2 young children. She's mid-way through her third pregnancy and she hasn't seen her husband Cheukwah in several months. When he learned of her pregnancy, he moved to a large mining village 6 hours away in search of employment.  Cheukwah cares for his family but is unable to phone home or visit often.  It's bad enough that he's missing his older children grow up but now he feels completely detached from the child on the way.  

I Feel U Feel rethinks the communication process between mother and father by bringing the father into the pregnancy process.  A device sharing updates about the baby in ambient ways - from the mother's womb to the father's hip.
i_feel_u_feel.creator: fbc346b1a1050e613dcd417f3adff710

comments.text: Really wonderfully told story, I felt like I was there, lovely words to help bring the concept alive!

Hi Alessandro... Thanks for the feedback. That's a great point.  Maybe there is still a way to do monitoring that can safely send content to a remote device.  If so, the monitor could share updates with the mother's device (which she's not necessarily carrying on her person) which then sends to the father's device.  I'll look into existing remote monitoring medical technology.

The idea is very beautiful ... the problem is the baby's exposure to electromagnetic waves ... can be dangerous and there are not really conclusive research on the subject, but it is advisable avoid ... there is no way to do it another way?
Great that you've used personas and a scenario to tell your concept through  makes it so much more engaging!

i_feel_u_feel.title: I  Feel, U Feel

comments.text: re:Incentives/MotivationIt's the type service I wish I knew more about, how it spread, how it's viewed by the average farmer, and how much effort the operator+government invest in it vs how much the farmers themselves invest to make it work.  It is more or less a technological subsidy for state-sponsored agriculture, so I do wonder how the incentive system would work if it were operated as a private enterprise.re:IndiaIt would be interesting to compare the Chinese way vs. the Indian way given the contrasting bureaucracies at work.  I would assume the services in India are more grassroots/P2P vs. top down/State run in China, but it's always good to check your assumptions at the door.re:WokaiI'm not sure if there is an explicit link between Nongxingtong and Wokai, but it's a great idea.  It would be great to apply some learnings from Web 2.0, i.e. creating latticeworks of services through increased interoperability and partnerships. mom_to_be_camps.description:
I'm thinking of Aravind’s „eye camps“ in India, which are a great example how to bring health care service to rural India. The same  concept can be applied to improve maternal health in remote areas. Aravind’s eye clinic provides basic tools for diagnosis as well as advanced satellite-linked telemedicine trucks that travel regularly to remote locations, perform eye exams, teach eye care and identify people who may require surgery. Using the telemedicine trucks, the doctors back in Aravind’s hospitals participate in decisions and make diagnosis when needed.
Similarly “Mom-To-Be Camps” can be organized periodically, where women could be registered, examined, re-examined, taught about pregnancy and birth. If required they could be sent for advanced diagnostic services to the nearest hospitals.
mom_to_be_camps.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead
