comments.text: @krassima - hhmmm getting around the one size fits all info is a challenge, after all if too often the info isn't relevant then people will lose interest. I guess if women sign up for it and give over details like due dates etc, then you could tailor it to their needs, HCW could also record what info people are interested in receiving. Then there are things like putting out different info that is relevant to the season. I guess then the challenge is keeping the system simple enough to work but take the above points into consideration....I'm not too concerened about the loud issue as I think there are plenty of places that wouldn't matter - especially in rural areas.I like the oral alternative for low literacy environments.

I think using pictures and audio cues would be a great way to disseminate the necessary information in a low-literacy context. Also having direct access to a human on the line is always appreciated and comforting especially when faced with specific health-related questions. This could also create a new job market in health education.

Avi, the Questionbox device is a great implementation! Thanks for sharing!@Ian: how do you imagine the information to be pushed to the devices? is it going to be targeted to user groups or everyone gets the same information? If we consider the case of pushing information to the mobile device, I'm thinking more of visual data (pictorial sequence). For those who cannot read, visual and audio are good alternatives; places where people congregate are usually very loud, so audio might not be the best option. Thoughts?

Great idea Ian & the Oxfam-ers! Brings to mind the Japanese SMS novels which are dispatched at queues http://www.coolbusinessideas.com/archives/queue-time/ Am wondering if others have thoughts on ways to make the messages really compelling within this novel delivery channel?
Ian, this could work well with the Question Box device:http://questionbox.org/
got it- I like the idea a lot! Markets (i.e. flower markets), places of worship that people visit regularly (mosks, hindu temples, gurudwaras, churches, etc.) could be potential locations...

You can get a server for about $90 put them in bus stops and at taxi ranks. You can go firther by doing it at appropriate places where people congregate. You could power them using solar and yes, push the information out to their phones.What do you think?
Ian, quick question: this information will be pushed to people's phones whilw they wait at bus stops?

oxfam_brainstorming_session_bluetooth_an.title: Oxfam brainstorming session - bluetooth and bus stops

hub_and_spoke_rural_healthcare_service_d.description: Filling the gap between professional healthcare expertise residing in urban areas and maternal health care needs for low income populations residing in rural areas through community health workers and mobile technology.
hub_and_spoke_rural_healthcare_service_d.creator: 02a53be8ad240506af50ec1998fe5ad2

comments.text: - Referral system where specific hubs are linked to specific spokes so when emergency or higher level care is needed, there is a particular place to go Consider the eRanger Motorcycle Ambulance.

Interesting strategy to leverage expertise on the field, you have developed with others here.That is a critical issue, for what I know from a friend in this sector, India for example has one of the world highest ratio of health workers per citizen, but their average expertise is too poor. Using rural hub to deliver experts analyses via mobile technology could clearly by a way to foster the training process of low skilled health workers as well as actually delivering the good services immediately.You also pointed the right challenges to address in order to firmly implement the hubs.
Wow Emily  comprehensive concept! And it's great to have an international development consultant join our diverse OpenIDEO community.

Very nice system you've laid out here...you're point about thinking through the payment structure to keep such a system sustainable is a very good one.If there were a limited amount of health care workers in a certain area to act as the 'spokes' it might be possible to set up community education centers to act as spokes.  These ed centers would be connected to the hub and operated by the surrounding community...just a thought that popped into my head.

hub_and_spoke_rural_healthcare_service_d.title: Hub and Spoke Rural Healthcare Service Delivery Networks

i_will_call_you_from_the_cloud.description:
Most of the times we think how the community can help expectant moms; here is a way how the expectant moms can help the community:
Imagine a mom-to-be in a remote village who owns a mobile phone. Most of her friends and members of the community cannot afford to buy a handset but they see the benefits of making calls, sending sms for connecting with family members in the city, employment opportunities and even marriage possibilities. If the expectant mom in the community offers the rest of the people in the community to use her handset against a small credit, this would be beneficial for everyone.
i_will_call_you_from_the_cloud.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Sina, thanks a look for the comment!Anne-Laure, in case you have a link you could share on the project of Telenor/Grameen Bank, that would be fantastic. I really like the microfinancing idea! I will update the concept with this nugget you suggest:-)
Really appreciate the visual story board. Great idea.

Great idea indeed. I did not know Mortivu, but Telenor did some interesting work with Grameen Bank a couple of years ago. The idea was that a woman in the village will get a micro-loan to buy a phone and she would become the communication hub in the village. This had a lot of social implications, in particular empowering women and specially the one with the phone. I think building upon the social structure and the sense of a community is a great idea.al

Meena, fantastic ideas! I definitely believe pregnant women should be offered a selection of services/products (i.e. transportation costs, nutritional supplements). I can imagine maybe a choice of 2-3 services and/or products. One way to make women aware of these services could be at the local village phone operator booth. When a pregnant woman purchases the subsidized mobile phone, she receives a mobile phone charm ( a small card, or a coin) with it, that has icons that describe the services she could receive with the credits on her mobile.A campaign to make the community aware of the way they could contribute using the cloud phone is essential (posters in the village phone booth, psoters next to the places of worship, at the locla market). The word-of-mouth campaigning is also important....

Nice one Krassimira  I'm a big fan of Movirtu's work! I wonder if there would be increased incentive for pregnant women if the credits could be converted to a selection of maternal-health-related products and services. This may also help with attracting sponsors of the project, given you're suggesting a subsidised scheme? I can also imagine an associated campaign for this so that folks are aware that by using the cloud phone of a woman that is part of this scheme  that they are directly helping fund maternal support.
Thanks, Sarah and Ashley!
Great concept! And I agree with Sarah - I'm loving the images you posted.
Very interesting idea Krassimira! (and nice visuals!)

i_will_call_you_from_the_cloud.title: I will call you from The Cloud

mom_may_not_be_the_decider_or_have_power.description: Even if the mom knows what to do, does she have the power to implement the best decisions for her and her child? “You have health projects where young mothers are targeted, but the elder decision makers in the family are not involved. That woman may not be able to decide whether she gets to see a doctor or not.” Use mobile technologies to show "soap operas" about community involvement in maternal health. Image by Munem Wasif.
mom_may_not_be_the_decider_or_have_power.creator: c9c0d433ce58f94b0f167b62ffa6b6da

comments.text: Thank you Vincent, I agree there may be a need to consider others who are affecting the mother's decisions.
Interesting take on why the power dynamics situation may make it all the more critical to get the whole community involved.

mom_may_not_be_the_decider_or_have_power.title: Mom may not be the Decider or have Power, involve the Elder Decision-Makers & Community too.

plan_your_pregnancies.creator: bd752ee637110e10075b9e95e5f96e90

comments.text: To comment on the technology bit of it... I dont think it has be be relying on a smart phone at all. A simple program for existing low-tech phones will do. I live in Africa and have spent lots of time out in the bush with women that would be considered as this target group. And many many of them already have simple mobile phones. One of the simplest models now retails for about 9 Euros here in Kenya. Yes, of course for some women its not possible to plan when intercourse is going to happen because its a mainly male decision. But she will be aware of her status and can if possible avoid unwanted pregnancies. A awareness campaign directed to men at the same time would be very beneficial.

I like the idea of tackling maternal health through family planning.  While many women are not able to control when they have sex, some can and this app would prove useful to them.  Knowledge is power.

The challenge also is that at least in Africa when it comes to family planning married women have little control.  Basically the men decide and yet there is very little intervention of awareness and education being targeted to the men to change their attitudes so even with such a solution as this concept proposes it needs to go hand in hand with awareness creation also targeted at the men.  That way women would be able to use this tool.

The problem with this concept is that it requires every woman to have regular (weekly) access to a smart phone.  In the areas of the world under discussion this is not realistic. Any solution will have to begin from the premise of only sporadic access to any phone at all and not necessarily a top-of-the-line 3G mobile.

Lovely idea, probably it is better to avoid unwanted pregnancy if possible. I am wondering if there would be any way to utilise low-tech mobile phones such as Nokia 1100, to adopt this kind of ideas. It would be great to see some kind of device which can be plugged into low tech phones to change / or add the programming which can be implemented on to basic functions like the calender. Thanks for the idea Anna!

I like this idea, v. simple. Again, may not help in all cases, but knowledge is the first step.  Also, I would say that it could help identify when someone is pregnant, maybe knowing earlier could help with a healthier pregnancy.

plan_your_pregnancies.title: Plan your pregnancies

mbaby_making_information_actionable.description:
To date, neonatal mHealth SMS programs have taken two forms: reminders sent to expectant mothers, and reporting done by certified health workers. mBaby asks the question - what if we combined the two, making the reminders actionable?

Real-time reminders and concrete calls-to-action will help health workers get a clearer picture of their patients' well-being and habits. In addition, these actionable reminders will ensure mothers get quality information and concrete steps to keep themselves - and their babies - healthy.
mbaby_making_information_actionable.creator: 9b8148f451829f24328c0e3a0e85e5a0

comments.text: Hi Erica,What a great idea to use mobile technology, which is so prevalent, to spread educational information!  I wanted to add a comment about the language and phrasing of the questions which mothers are asked to answer.  In the examples, the question is preceded by a factual statement (i.e. Pregnancy increases your change of contracting malaria.  Do you sleep under a mosquito net?).  My first thought looking at the questions was could people who are not sleeping under a net (for example) feel pre-judged before answering the question?  The statement makes it fairly obvious what the "correct" answer is.  I think this could have a few different problems.  First, women who figure out the "correct" answer might chose yes even if the answer is no, especially if they know that sometime in the future the information is going to be seen by a doctor.  This would first and foremost be a danger to the mother because she might not get appropriate counsel from her healthcare provider.  It could also pose a problem if the answers are going to be complied and used for research purposes- if people are pushed towards one answer or another the data would be invalid.  Another issue that could arise is if a mother feels in any way "judged" for her answer, she might be less willing to continue with the program.  What about having the question be short and straightforward, without extraneous information in the first interface (i.e. Do you sleep under a mosquito net?) and then include the factual information in both of the answers, with appropriate corrective advice for a "No" answer?  I think especially if one goal is to be able to aggregate the data for use in policy, advocacy, or research, it would be important to have someone familiar with survey design look over the application to make sure there is no bias implicit in the question design.Overall though, I think you have a fantastic idea that could provide a lot of people with a lot of needed information!  Best of luck!

Great comments, Laura.  I agree that it's worth the time and effort to think carefully about how the questions and responses are crafted to ensure that mothers are responding honestly and accurately.  Your suggestion to flip the order to question first, then fact is a great solution.
That's a great idea, Laura. The order of the statements in the SMS messages are absolutely flippable. I wouldn't want the women to feel judged at all.
It's really great comment! Laura, you really think people behaviour! Good job!

Congratulations. I really like the potential to gather data and then mine this at a later point that this conept offers - it could be a great spin off project! I also like that the activities are focused on actionable outcomes. This is one of my favourite of the 'educate' concepts.
Thanks for the nice feedback, Ian! Looks like your team had fun brainstorming, too :) Congrats on the win & I look forward to seeing some of these concepts actually put into action!

Hi Erika!I just came across this open source project that seems highly relevant to your concept and wanted to pass it along.  You may already be aware of it, but in case not, it is called OpenData kit and is available on google code (http://code.google.com/p/opendatakit/).  It is made for mobile data collection and aggregation in developing countries and has built in features that might fit your project well.  Some of the features include medical decision trees, tasks that can be pushed to mobile devices, and built in compatibility with the open medical record system (http://openmrs.org/).  You can see a full list of the features here: http://opendatakit.org/about/tools.Have a great day, Cj

CJ - all of your input has been so helpful! You're definitely going on my "collaborators" list now! Thanks for this... just shows that this sort of data collection is actually needed - and hackers are developing to meet that need.

Hi Erika,I think this is a fantastic idea with great potential! You've obviously done a considerable amount of background research. To help you develop it further, I'd like to just note some points that you might consider:- I think it would help to consider how this concept can be adapted for areas where downloading info from an online database and printing it is not an option. Are there affordable phones or handheld devices that can display the information directly so health workers can have it in field?- Midwives and neighborhood health committees are often the 1st line of contact. Can they also be incorporated into your network somehow?- It would also be interesting to see how you can motivate moms to respond accurately and consistently to these SMS's. Maybe you could tie it to mom's receiving some phone credit or a free mosquito net?- Is it possible to have the questions played on audio to the mom on her mobile phone, and to have her voice response by transcribed and entered into the database? - Could you also adapt this idea to include local dialects?- Could you combine the notices for multiple children in a single SMS so mom's do not have to see the same prompts for every one of her children?Again, great work! I'm excited to see the evolution of this idea!Thanks,Jess

Hi Jess - Thanks for your feedback. I've already addressed a lot of it in the comments below! Although I think it would be hard to view the mother's responses via SMS, I think there could definitely be a low tech mobile app for accessing this information.I think midwives and neighborhood health committees could definitely help women get started in the program - acting as catalysts and guides. Regarding incentives, see the exchanges between me, Nathania, and Niko below!Slide 16 shows how this could be adapted for voice alerts. The translation mechanism in the back end would definitely account for the local translation, see the exchange with Poorna below.

Hi Erica,This idea seems like it could have a great deal of potential.   I would love to hear more about the system for developing the content of the checklists and how they could be tested and adapted to fit the needs, resources, and cultural sensitivities of individual communities.  This seems like a solution where the technology will be relatively straightforward, but the success might hinge on how well the actual content of each text is customized to be applicable and effective to individual readers.  Even if every mother has this phone in her hand and is receiving the texts that offer medically sound advice, her trust in the importance of words appearing on the phone might be lost if a task is requested which is against her religion or is not applicable to her region.  It would be great to explore how to build a process that could address this need by directly involving local community members and medical personnel from the areas where the program would be deployed.

Hi CJ - Great feedback. I think this is a good point. In the back-end translation system could probably be flexible enough so that location specific questions could be reviewed and implemented by a monitor. OR, to make it less high-touch, we could allow CHWs on the ground to alter (in addition to the existing translation capability) the questions based on location or religion.

Hi CJ - Great feedback. I think this is a good point. In the back-end translation system could probably be flexible enough so that location specific questions could be reviewed and implemented by a monitor. OR, to make it less high-touch, we could allow CHWs on the ground to alter (in addition to the existing translation capability) the questions based on location or religion.

Thanks Erika,  I was thinking about your idea at lunch today and realized that a good resource for how to refine the questions could be to use some of the lessons learned in the World Health Organization's Safe Surgery program.  It was an initiative where they carefully developed checklists to improve the quality of care in operating rooms,  allowed for some types of localized customization and had an incredibly positive outcome.  Dr. Atul Gawande headed up that initiative, and would be a great person to connect with in figuring out how to focus in on the most important actionable steps and how to allow for customization without loosing value.  You can read more about the WHO initiative here: http://www.who.int/patientsafety/safesurgery/checklist_saves_lives/en/index.html  Dr. Qawande also addresses the study in his pop-science book "The Checklist Manifesto." I really look forward to seeing where this idea goes.  So much potential!
Perhaps there could be incentives for individuals to participate. These could be in a form of phone credits if you complete the quick mobile survey or when you send data to the central hotline.
Thanks for the feedback Nathania! I think incentives could be a powerful motivator. Check out my comment to Niko to see a possible implementation of an incentive system.
@Erika -  always up for (fairtrade) coffee if it will change the world:) If you pass by Stockholm, send me an email. http://www.linkedin.com/pub/siri-johansson/27/33b/108
Careful, I might take you up on that! Headed to Barcelona in May & thinking of skipping up to Sweden to visit family! :) Thanks again for all of your help.

Erika, nice work done here. You've clearly thought through this concept.  I found the slide presentation to be helpful and it was especially helpful to have an example of an unsatisfactory answer. I also like that you're using existing channels to come up with your idea, reminds me of mPesa, which has changed many lives in Kenya.  Have you thought about where you would want to launch this?  If so, have you identified some of the major NGOs or even social enterprises that could be potential partners?  Would questions be tailored to particular countries and regions?

Thanks Jennifer! I hadn't heard of mPesa - thanks for introducing me! It sounds a lot like what Venmo is doing here in the US! https://venmo.com/ I originally concepted the idea so it could be widely applicable - as the challenge dictated, from Burkina Faso to Bangladesh. I'd love to get the IDEO community's thoughts on a potential location for the pilot program!

It would also be great if you had separate actionable instructions that could be sent to the father or family members to support needs that might be outside of the mothers control, particularly in the third trimester.
This could definitely be a secondary opt-in set of texts for family members!

Hi Erika, I think this is an incredibly feasible idea that would be fairly easy to implement using existing resources. I love the idea of being able to alert community health workers if a mother appears to be in trouble. Is there a way to ensure that a woman would always be able to access the information and not be limited by her phone credits?

Thanks Niko - yes, I think the alerts are super important!  To address your comment on the credits, perhaps we could combine your feedback with Nathania's (below) and offer free credits as an incentive for participation?
For Literacy issues, the local languages could be used and high usage of universally conveyable pictorial representations on the message could solve lot of issues from my perspective.

Absolutely agree, Poorna. I think there could easily be a back-end interface that allowed local health-workers to log-in and translate the questions into their language. I'm curious, though, how you would use pictorial representations using SMS tech? Would love to hear more!

Nice work Erica! After reading through the concepts I feel the need to address two background factors that affect maternal health: female infanticide, and female genital mutilation. This may be more appropriate for the concept section but it is closed. I think many of you would be surprised at the high rate of occurrence of both of these tragic social phenomena because of how closely linked they are to mental and physical health in low- income communities. I think the Maternal Health concepts can go further and address these topics in addition to healthy practices during pregnancy in the effort to make a greater impact for women. Target points: Female Infanticide, Female Genital Mutilation, and Barefoot College The following are ways to enhance the impact of mBaby and concepts alike by way of prevention through additional calls to action:1. Address female infanticide 2. Address female genital mutilation  3. Train women at Barefoot College to participate and be part of the educational and healthcare efforts in India and Africa  4. Women will aid fellow women and girls about healthy pregnancy practices, FGM and FI prevention 5. Women will utilize technological tools for communication to build change from where they are  6. Educate men to establish project support Additionally, mBaby could serve to make women more aware about opportunities for women and girls. Women and girls that are part of the Healthcare team at organizations like Barefoot College could be part of the change by helping to implement the project. By using this project to utilize the efforts that are already being made, the target demographic will have someone they can relate to. This approach increases the possibility of layered change through educationthe primary focus remains on improving maternal health while expectant mothers get the opportunity to interact with empowered women that are visible, valued, and heardultimately adding to the value of the impact of mBaby. The work of Barefoot College graduates and employees expands all over India and Africa!For further information on FGM:Female Genital Mutilation in Africa leads to pregnancy complications. Agnes Pareyios' work focus's on eradicating FGM as a human rights violation, specifically the right to physical integrity that affects the lives of millions of women around the world. http://www.adventuredivas.com/divas/profiles/agnes-pareyio/http://www.who.int/gender/other_health/Studentsmanual.pdfFor further information on FI:http://www.sascv.org/ijcjs/snehlata.pdfhttp://www.gendercide.org/case_infanticide.htmlFor further information on Barefoot College: http://www.barefootcollege.org/default.asp

I think Erica hits the nail in terms of identifying the fact that SMS reminders for pregnant women should be linked to data collection, however, my major concern with this program is the fear that it might elucidate in the pregnant women. Receiving a text message saying "that x amount of children die b/c of xyz, so do this" - can be terrifying for someone who is uneducated and illiterate. A more gentle approach needs to be taken. I would advise that CHWs encourage women to sign up for the program, and administer the questionnaire, coaching them through the questions and advising them on action that needs to be taken. Then, train them on how to submit information, develop a trusting relationship to access the information from inception with the incentive that they will respond with customized treatment information through SMS or voice as challenges arise. This can be supplemented with customized SMS messages depending on the answers to the questionnaires (i.e. reminders to take zinc pills)
Thanks Siri! Your input was super helpful! :) It must be the Swedish connection. I think I might be headed over there later this year to visit my family! Let's get coffee and change the world.
Hi again Erika, great work with the update and good luck!
Good luck Erika!

Hi Erika.Our team has recently had interviews with a social worker director in latin America, who told us being pregnant for us westerns is completely different to women in Africa, whereas for them being pregnant represent having the 3rd baby, and won't be the last one... which probably 2 have died, and they see it more like being handicapped rather than our concept of pregnancy.would be a good point to take in account, how to deal with their minds and avoiding to crash with their thoughts towards pregnancyregards :) x

@Cliff - Thanks for the feedback. Not sure about the tribal/patriarchal lore. I tried not to get too deep in the weeds on culture-specific questions so that I could build an idea that could be applicable globally - from Burkina Faso to Bangladesh. I do think, however, that cellphone use is getting to be so widespread that many of these mothers do (or, will very soon) actually have their own cell phones and be able to participate freely in the program.@Nancy - Funny, the new changes I made re: @Siri's and @IDEO's feedback kind of touch on your great point. I think the initial questions should always err on the side of Y/N for literacy purposes, but if mothers begin to give unsatisfactory responses (answers that indicate her health is failing or she is unable to make healthy choices), she will be guided through a series of more specific questions (see slides 13-15) that can help pinpoint the problem and offer a solution - whether that solution is a behavior change or a ping to the local CHW to come to her aid.

Hi Erika,This is a well thought out and detailed idea - I like the simplicity of it and the clever use of existing technologies without the need to invent new ones.I am interested in your thoughts on possible cultural challenges to the use of the SMS system. I don't know enough about the cultures in relation to tribal or patriachal lore, but will expectant mothers have access and authority to use the system? Or might they be stopped for some reason (such as unwanted pregnancies?)Well done -

What a great idea! I love the idea of yes/no answers because it makes it so easy and accessible for everyone. I was intrigued when Joe and Maria brought up the option to chat. If the feasibility could be worked out, that would be a great addition to this! Also, if there isn't a chat option, there could be some sort of FAQ incorporated, so that a woman could review a list of commonly asked questions, and find the answer she is looking for there.One thing I wonder about is the option to rank answers, along with the yes/no option---thinking particularly about pain here. What about using a scale, like 1-5, to rate how severe the pain is? That might help to differentiate minor pain from more severe or serious health issues. I could also envision some answers that might not always be yes or no, but would need to be answered with a "maybe" or a "sometimes." Could this be an option? Or would this add confusion to the data collection? Or perhaps if someone answered "maybe" this might lead to a follow-up yes/no question to really get to the heart of the problem. As you mentioned, if a woman gives a certain number of incorrect or troubling answers we could ping a local CHW who could make a house-visit--this is such a good idea! That would help to focus the in-person calls to the people who need it most.Great job on this, Erika!

@Estudio 6: Hi! I understand the concern here - we definitely don't want to come off as spam. But, I think the main difference is that it's not the telecommunication company that's sending the message, it's mBaby, and mother's have the opportunity to opt in or out at any time. I also think the fact that we're providing info on how to improve their health and the health of their babies makes it more valuable than random text promotions.@Brian: Are you thinking about being able to use the collected data for national/international statistics? I think that the information could be available for studies, but probably shouldn't be up on the internet (publicly accessible) for the layman. I'm intrigued to hear what use case you'd see for making her answers public?And thanks for the article! Very helpful!@Timothy: I hadn't thought of using the radio - mostly because the concept is based on the idea that a two-way-street helps with the issue of data collection, whereas radio is more of an old-media approach. I do like the idea, though, and think that radio has proven to be a valuable means of broadcast communications in developing countries. (I like the hours-scheme, too!)@crystal Fascinating! I'd never heard of By Your Side, but it's a fascinating example of a CSR campaign that fits perfectly with the core offering of the business! I also like the fact that they keep their communications to mothers short and sweet - so as not to overwhelm them. @Siri Thanks! So glad they matched us up. I definitely think a once-a-month mobile check up could be fantastic. The report-back mechanism fits perfectly with this new piece, as it's just one more step in the data-collection process. I also think this might be a good place to involve Community Health Workers (CHWs) which I so far haven't cited in the concept. If a woman gives a certain number of incorrect or troubling answers (either to the check-up or the prompts) we could ping a local CHW who could make a house-visit. This way, they can focus their very limited time and resources on the women who need them the mostIn any case, I think we have to keep the answers as simple as possible (if we can keep it close to the y/n format I suggested, great, but we could also incorporate numbers for the more metrics-based questions.@Maia, @IDEO & @Robyn I think your feedback works well together it could be awesome to provide a way for government and local initiatives to plug into mBaby and provide offers to the mothers for further information and services. For example, if a mother answers "no" to "do you sleep under a mosquito net?" it could either ping an NGO like the UN Foundation's Nothing But Nets to notify them of the need, or provide instantaneous response to the mother, directing her to call the NGO to get access to the net. If a mother replies "yes" to "Do you ever have cramping pain on one side of your pelvis?" it could be a sign of ectopic pregnancy, and a follow-up series could be triggered to help narrow down the symptoms and/or put the mother in touch with a CHW to follow up.@Iybosa I think this could definitely be partnered with house visits, and throughout the presentation, I tried to use the word "health worker" instead of "doctor" to maintain flexibility in this case. That way, a CHW could visit a woman at home, and she can grant him access to her health records, as well. @Marie and @Joe - I definitely like the concept of a group chat. The reason I tried to keep the concept simple (y/n answers, less interactivity) was to ensure that the program was scalable. I think group chats would have to be mediated by a CHW to ensure that women are getting access to good information. This additional functionality could be released a partner piece that could link women serviced by the same CHW in a locale - probably to great success, as it would help build community and relationships among pregnant mothers.

Hello Erika,In Colombia, a telecommunication company tried to promote its services by sending constantly SMS to every user. But that caused that people felt annoyed and everyone asked to the company to stop sending this messages.How are you planning to develop your concept without make user feel annoyed because of the constant SMS during a whole year?

Hi Erika,This is great idea.  Just a couple questions.   If a mother could protect her identity (and her mobile number) would her health answer have to be password protected.  I believe it would be relatively easy to automate the sending of messages via  calendar or time line. Likewise, y/n answers could be easily stored.  If there was way to publish text messages to web do the mother's answers need to remain private IF her identity could be protected?Here is recent article on using SMS interface in question and answer format title "Mobile Phones for Health Education in the Developing World: SMS as a User Interface data sheet" 1/11/11"  From NYU http://dev2010.news.cs.nyu.edu/papers/13-danis.pdf

Erika,I was wondering if you had thought about also utilizing radio waves to transmit maternity information out to the masses in addition to SMS utilization. In application, this maternity radio station could loop in a daily repetitive track, each hour giving tips on pregnancy each month (1pm = 1mo, 2pm = 2mo, etc). I think this could be an additional way to increase your viewer base, since radios should be more affordable than cell phones (and don't require the cost of SMS texting). Just a thought.... great job!

This IS great Erika! I love that it's simple, intuitive and yet comprehensive. I also love that expecting mothers will need the technology already available at their fingertips. For examples of calls-to-action and reminders, I suggest you take at look at JOHNSON'S BY YOUR SIDE, a program implemented by Johnson & Johnson that offers expert advice and stage-based guides to help help expecting mothers provide the best care for themselves and their growing babies.

This is great Erika! The concept is so well researched and presented. Still, if you're refining the concept and want to include some themes from my http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/self-diagnosing-phone-service/ idea, I think Marie Leznicki's suggestion (see comments) of offering automated routine IVR check-ups would fit nicely into your concept. As she explains: "Additionally, I think the system could work in two ways: either the women call in when they feel like something is wrong or the system calls/SMSs them once a month as a routine mobile checkup. Personally, I would vote for the latter. Because health issues are so common in the developing world, many women dont realize they have a problem until its too late."The automated calls-for-action could be combined with these routine check-ups/diagnosing and the data gathering would also make it possible to send out alerts to health care workers if the answers indicated that there was something wrong.
Wow! So many great comments. I'm going to be refining the concept over the next few days and I'll be responding to this great feedback tonight! Love this community...

Hi Erika, This is very awesome! Specially not just reminding information but gathering responses makes this idea more compelling. I'd like to add a small idea on it - using responses results back to reminding information as collective intelligence. For example, mBaby message can show importance level of the information based on the response rate and Yes/No tendency. Then, mothers might be more cautious not miss critical actions.

Hi Erika,Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge!We really think your idea is building on existing, realisable technologies (SMS) and adding a fresh new spin on things by letting mums respond to calls to action.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some examples on what these calls to action might be. What are some example texts that might result from pregnancy? What areas in a mother's life could these cover? (ie. such as health, nutribution, personal welfare).We also ask you to think about what are the implications of sending a response. What if the mother says no to some action like having a mosquito net? Could the service connect her with locals to acquire or barter for a net?We also encourage you to work with Siri to incorporate her concept: Self-Diagnosing Phone Service (http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/self-diagnosing-phone-service/) So you can build a stronger concept together.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side and answer our 2 new fields:- Concept Builds - Here you can list additional builds on your concept- Virtual Team - Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers!OpenIDEO

Many countries have incentives to get women to go to hospitals (free treatment, in India new mothers even get a cash payment) to reduce infant mortality. It would be great to link to current government initiatives and campaigns. In remote areas, there may be other NGOs that provide transportation to hospitals or clinics - there's a cost to providing local information, but perhaps local NGOs could sign up, even pay a little to get their information or services linked to the messages.

Hey Erika-This is great - so comprehensive.  I'm really excited you made it to the top 20.  I'd like to second Joe's idea of adding a group chat component.  I feel like a lot of these women are either shy or aren't sure what to ask.  Hearing other women's questions could help.

Hey Erika, congrats on top 20! In reading through your idea I thought to myself that perhaps this could be partnered with house visits. So that expectant mothers are not always required to go to the doctor's. Additionally, creating that relationship of comfort and familiarity could be extended beyond the expectant mother to include the expectant father or primary caregiver, strengthening her circle of care. Also partnering two expectant mothers and/or fathers in the same area may really contribute to the success of the project.

Hey Erika, do you think there might be some way to link this to telemedicine options too? For example, if there was a comprehensive mHealh program designed to collection information about a woman's pregnancy symptoms via your application and this information was applied to a validated algorithm that indicated when a women should consultant a healthcare professional (for ectopic pregnancy, maybe?), then the mobile application could also alert women on when to seek help. If this could then be linked (particularly in rural areas) to a telemedicine provider, think of the number of hard to reach women that could be touched!

Hey Erika, do you think there might be some way to link this to telemedicine options too? For example, if there was a comprehensive mHealh program designed to collection information about a woman's pregnancy symptom via your application and this information was applied to a validated algorithm that indicated when a women should consultant a healthcare professional (for ectopic pregnancy, maybe?), then the mobile application could also alert women on when to seek help. If this could then be linked (particularly in rural areas) to a telemedicine provider, think of the number of hard to reach women that could be touched!

Sounds Awesome Erika!Would be interesting to structure this as a group chat that had helpful messages from a sponsor or the institution running the program, instead of a one way communication.When you joined you would be put in a group of maybe 5 - 10 mothers that live in your area and are in a similar stage of pregnancy. The group would be guided through a get to know you process where the host asked everyone to tell a little about themselves. Then the group could ask each other questions as well as get helpful tips from the host.There are already group chat apps and websites out there like Vol.ly that could facilitate this kind of interaction.Best,   Joe

Wow! Thank you all for the support in getting my idea into the Top 20! I'm going to spend the next few days refining the idea and fleshing it out. Please feel free to leave comments and questions here about how I can refine the idea. IDEO has suggested incorporating a some of the themes from Siri Johansson's http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/self-diagnosing-phone-service/ which I'm totally in favor of. (It must be fate, since we have the same surname!)@Amber - Thanks for the support! I definitely think the provision of facts will be essential to the application. And giving them concrete actions to help ensure those facts are actionable will also be key.@Paul - Yes, I definitely think the yes/no part of the concept is key. Some questions will obviously have to be text or number based, but for the most part, I think the SMS reminders can be messaged in a way that the requested response is very simple.

Great! I was in a situation recently where the Dr. wasn't providing us with the information needed. It was found on a fact sheet as we were leaving the ER. Just that little sentence gave the expectant mother the comfort and knowhow to move forward. Proactively providing basic information can go a long way.

I like the idea of making answers super simple like Yes or No.  The recent elections in Kenya used this strategy to reach out to the rural less literate areas by asking Yes for a new constitution or No.
Excellent, feasible, necessary idea!
Excellent, feasible, necessary idea!
Great to see you found the Update This button to edit your post to include this, Erika ;^) Staggering indeed.
Typo! I meant 5 BILLION cellphone subscribers... not million ;)

Perhaps having valuable information/training could aid in the social stigma against women as well...?

the_full_story_booklet_audio_phone_servi.description:
By using a combination of printed material and audio, knowledge about maternal health can be shared in an inclusive way using simple methods, while still offering a rich learning experience. 
NOW UPDATED!
the_full_story_booklet_audio_phone_servi.creator: 91c731a8ad504c4dde932f79104f992c

comments.text: Hi. The community aspect of having a local woman administer the booklet library is great. It becomes a community effort and gets everyone involved. It reminded me of a recent article posted on Next Billion with a similar strategy. To confront the condition of low-income women in under-developed areas with little access to education in health, nutrition and agriculture and taking into account that many of these women are illiterate, "Co-Op Audio" by Both Your Hands was created. Its aim - it's in its beginning stages - is to educate women on issues that they have expressed interest in and that they will benefit from.The idea: a local woman travels to an internet caf with a donated educationally-equipped MP3 player to download educational MP3 files, which are then shared among the women in the respective community. The program has been piloted in two Ugandan villages with positive results: empowering women and increasing awareness and involvement outside the community - the youth around the world get involved by collecting MP3 players for Co-Op Audio.Both programs are on to something special. If interested in learning more on this initiative and getting in touch with the Deborah Naybor, the director of Both Your Hands, I have included the link below.http://www.nextbillion.net/blog/2011/04/21/from-unite-for-site-hearing-the-pitch-Best,Asaia

I think this might be one of the most cost effective concepts by addressing the lack of health care information problem. To really cut costs, I would see if OXFAM and Nokia, (perhaps also include Intel and Brightstar) could pre-load the cellphones with 9 chapters (9 months) of instructional advice in audio podcasts  form as oppose to asking the pregnant women to use her credits to dial a number where she accesses the content.  This might be even cheaper since the mother would not have to waist money dialing the phone number and should she run out of money, she could still access the health information content since it is stored on the phone itself.  As the price of memories decreases, we may consider pre-installing as much health and financial education content already on the phone prior to transport to the point of sale.  The challenge would be ensuring the audio content is pre-installed with the local language of the end-user.
I love how you have built on this concept!!! the personal binder is great, it makes the book flexible and personalized.  this is so complete now!  great work!
Wow - reading these last comments, I'm overwhelmed by the support and positive feedback from you guys! Thanks, I hope we'll get the chance to join forces on challenges ahead!

Siri, I want to give you kudos for a brilliant idea, and one that you did not pollute with too many frills. Everything is to the point, and fairly simple, which I love.Again, the idea of on-your-hand information augmented by mobile voice information, as well as this community information hub and support through the librarian is just brilliant. Keep it up!

I love the idea of creating a central hub for health education through the librarian concept. Brilliant! Overtime, as this idea scales, distributing updated and/or new types of health education will become a lot more feasible. This hub can also train women on how to access health information on their mobile phone, if they can't visit the center on a frequent basis. Also, I love that this provides the opportunity to employ women into a "community-leader" role. The status itself will serve as a motivating factor. Great job!
Vincent same here. I wanted to double vote!
Awesome update! Agree with Krassimira about the librarian idea. I tried to applaud your concept again, before realizing I had already done so =)
Siri, great updates! I like the librarian idea a lot! Great job!

Hi Siri, congrats for being selected as one of the final concepts! I was thinking that the following ideas from my concept "An Audio Guide Through Maternity" might be relevant to your concept: 1) add small videos that could be stored on cards to talk about wha happens to the mother and her baby on every stage of pregnancy 2) play some popular songs or just some background music with every # she punches that could make it even more pleasant to listen to the narrative. Please let me know what you think.Additionally, I was thinking about packaging the mobile phone with the book in a simple yet stable packaging to avoid damage (i.e. the phone could have a pocket inside the booklet). In case the expecting mother is illiterate, if the mobile phone is lost or damaged, she couldn't use the booklet or she has to ask a family member to read it load to her.

Hey there Siri!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea combining printed material and audio, knowledge about maternal health.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought into what might be involved. We encourage you to work with Krassimira http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/an-audio-guide-through-maternity/ so you can build a stronger concept together.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Interesting voice message idea Siri. This would work if the charge for listening to voicemail is less than for regular calls. Also, in cases where phones can store & play audio (beyond tones), there may be opportunities for over-the-air downloads (like how you can download a ringtone once and it can then be played as many times as needed). Anyways, which of these ideas makes sense will depend on the common phone charges and capabilities for each region. Your original call approach is the simplest to implement and I wouldn't be surprised if it makes the most sense in the most places right now. Just throwing out other possibilities that may make sense in the future or currently in specific areas.

Thanks again for some great input. I'll try to integrate some of the community oriented ideas by Sarah B and LaToya and update the concept soon to hopefully give you the time for another round of comments. Vincent, your suggestion on how to cut call costs got me thinking of other possible ways. Perhaps it would be less costly if the audio was sent as a voice message, and the messages were either offered as a subscription or "ordered" by sending a text with the numbers for the pages you were interested in hearing about? Thoughts on this?

Congrats Siri & Tristan on your strong related finalists concepts that combine the audio of mobiles & the visualization display capabilities of physical flip booklets. Just wanted to point to the future possibilities of using limited capacity, low-cost, copyable/sharable SD cards in cases where phones support this to store the audio (& maybe backup images), which could save on call costs.

Hi.  I think this concept could work well or be merged with the Mother Mati concept also one of the top 20 finalists.  Then what we would have is the actual print book and also a mobile version of the book so that one could access or use one or the other and maybe the print version would then have much more detail but the mobile one has the portability advantage or when there are distribution challenges of the printed matter the mobile version can be downloaded easily.
Nice concept Siri! check this out:http://maternalhealthtaskforce.org/discuss/wpblog/2011/01/01/comic-books-for-safe-motherhood/
I'm smiling and have to applaud my fellow top 20 member. Check mine out: the overlap is considerable and plain to see.
Thank you for your enthusiasm and the ideas for builds and combinations with other concepts! Sarah - I'd love to read more about that project if you can dig up a link.

As an anecdote, I heard of a project in Indonesia (sorry I don't have a link at the moment) where booklets were being given out for different stages of the pregnancy - I think initially as an incentive to encourage people to keep seeing the CHW. Over time they found that mums started to swap the books, like baseball cards, to build up a collection. Not that is something that you'd necessarily want to build in, just a thought. (I'm aware it would be more helpful if I had a link - if I find one I'll repost).

This is s great idea!  I think it could be combined with Anne-Laure Fayard "A Village Well for Knowledge and Communication", where women can go to the community site to get more information, watch videos, and connect with other community members.  This center might even offer a "library" of other similar booklets that can be checked out and shared.  The women could return the books for other expecting mothers to use, and then they can pick up a booklet called "caring for your new born".

Great concept! I really love the idea + the awesome visuals! I like that the audio part could not only include voice messages, but also things like breathing techniques (maybe also sounds of babies crying, etc.).
Really great stuff Siri. And we're loving the savvy Swedish designer-liness coming through in your engaging visualisations!

Very nice concept - this builds well on the 'audio guide through maternity' concept.  You could also substitute listening to the audio on a personal mobile phone (assuming all the moms in the area didn't have access) for listening to the audio on a community mobile phone, or even at a central point (like a learning center or something).  Well done!

keep_a_child_alive.description: Keep A Child Alive takes an extremely hands-on approach to supporting and caring for those affected with HIV/AIDS in Africa, India and other hot spots around the world. In addition to improving access to ARV therapy, KCA offers a range of support services including nutritional projects, diagnostic testing, training of health care workers, counseling, and funding sites where AIDS orphans can be cared for. There are currently 14.9 million AIDS orphans in Africa alone, 16.6 million worldwide. Learn more about KCA and all of their active health care and educational sites at: keepachildalive.org.
keep_a_child_alive.creator: 223d2e7a7d3df1efc55114b3a17116a0
keep_a_child_alive.title: Keep A Child Alive

pregnancy_health_geo_poll.description: Information about what to expect during each phase of a pregnancy is paired with health polls that collect data about the expectant mother's symptoms. By completing the health poll, mothers will have a better understanding of whether their condition is normal or if they should seek medical attention. The collected data is compiled and available to midwives and other health providers so that the areas in the most severe need of help can receive it.

radio_ctg_s.o.s.description: Method to measure heart rate of fetus and contractions of mother with a micro-CTG /cardiotokography/ and a data transmission network. Early contractions can be a sign of threatening preterm delivery, changed heart rate of a fetus can be a sign of many diseases. Measuring these parameters and sending the alarm to the cellphone which shows the phone number to the nearest hospital can be crucial for the safety of the pregnant mother and her child.
radio_ctg_s.o.s.creator: f663744062e5876058493e584f1dbd3e
radio_ctg_s.o.s.title: RADIO CTG + S.O.S

comments.text: I don't know the India phone market - incidence phones owned by females vs. males. But it would seem the phone can be pre-loaded with educational factoids such as warming baby after birth, and/or pregnancy care with birth and after birth care whereas the phone serves as a learning tool since it's the primary form of outside access for many.  Add a phone number with questions in native language and the phone becomes 'a class' of a class. Free phones with possible free, cheap battery packs for those communities w/o electricity would be norm.  In addition, might consider segmenting the phone by situation:  The Pregnancy Phone, The Harvest Phone (for better yields).  Branding ideas to narrow use but elevate use.  When any women becomes pregnant they get their Pregnancy Phone.  The essential companion.  Once a month person can take to XYZ to download new ed programs.  Ed programs can be videos of local meetings, or made special.  Good Luck, great work.

What I like about this is that mothers-in-law get involved in the process. This is very important point as in many cultures and countries around the world the young brides/soon mothers-to-be live with the family of the man they marry. The mothers in law play a major role in the life of the young bride. And I couldn't agree more with the folks who commented already- this video puts thinsg in perspective!Bill Gates at the World Economic Forum in Davos...http://www.livestream.com/worldeconomicforum02/video?clipId=pla_2c978eae-ad29-464e-a344-49c8a50bd49d

Wow, this video really brought these ideas to life for me. Thanks so much for sharing Avi!

cheap_discrete_mobile_std_tests.description:
A STD test is being developed in the UK which will allow people to simply pee or spit onto a card, and then receive their diagnosis within minutes (sort of like a pregnancy test, but for STDs). The vision is to eventually distribute these for ~$1/each through vending machines. 

Compare this to going to a clinic, having your results sent to a lab for analysis, then waiting anxiously for days to receive the results. This combats under-testing due to embarrassment, cost, inconvenience, etc.

What maternal tests could be made more accessible through such delivery mechanisms?
cheap_discrete_mobile_std_tests.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: A big part of the innovation here is in distribution. The technology does sound amazing, and if it can really do the trick, then the challenge becomes ensuring people are incentivized to do the tests. The convenience of vending machines makes this a brilliant concept for how these tests could be made available. Given that the challenge is about maternal health, it seems like vending machines might not be the most appropriate place to find mothers, unless the vending machine also had healthy items for moms and their kids. Nonetheless, moms could be drawn to the simple convenience of vending machines as part of naturally busy lives. A great concept to do further market research on.
Great Idea!
This is really cool!  Would be great to implement something like this, although it may take a lot of time/work to implement.

cheap_discrete_mobile_std_tests.title: Cheap & Discrete Mobile STD Tests

test_text_quizing_for_maternal_health_.description: After initial training sessions on maternal health issues, expecting mothers and maternal healthcare providers are quizzed by text message. Correctly answering quiz questions, which can be timed with important milestones in a pregnancy, is rewarded with phone credit for the pregnant women and certificates of completion for caregivers.
test_text_quizing_for_maternal_health_.creator: 6c3027bcc26e0cfef1c8c80ef8328805

comments.text: I like this, you could also do it with IVR I imagine which may cost the end user less (as it costs nothing to receive a call and answer the questions so they don't have to pay for outgoing sms) and could help overcome low-literacy environment. There's some notes on IVR here: http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/self-diagnosing-phone-service

test_text_quizing_for_maternal_health_.title: Test Text - Quizzing for Maternal Health

port2port.description: Building on several ideas for motorcycle ambulances, how about a fleet of boat ambulances, or boat mobile basic care units? In countries like Bangladesh which are dominated by large rivers and frequent flooding, marine transport is probably often easier than overland transport.
port2port.creator: 4e75aa86155d8fbb847893c0ffa0c67d

comments.text: Nice one Marika! Thought you might enjoy this inspiration from an earlier challenge which shows how innovative Bangladeshis have used boats to take books, technology & teachers to where they are needed: http://bit.ly/9lps8u Perhaps some good learnings there which could be transferred to healthcare.

Nice idea. I am reminded that in many countries during rainy season roads can become very difficult to navigate from mud or temporarily impassable from a wadi filling/flooding.This is a slightly different topic to what you're addressing in a Bangladeshi context with low-lying flood plains, but I am just wondering what the opportunities for hybrid/crossover are? For sure the same technology system could be shared, and maybe the training and medical supplies, but what about transport? I don't think hovercrafts would be particularly appropriate! :) ... am just wondering out loud.
Terrific reminder, Marika, that boats are an important transport method too!

family_planning_via_mobile_phones.description: Institute for Reproductive Health (IRH) at Georgetown University  xplores a mobile (m)Health solution that supplies a modern family planning method directly to a user's mobile phone.
family_planning_via_mobile_phones.creator: f165e8f15f9a0435b347c785dbb33015

comments.text: This is a powerful solution for women in situations where they want use family planning/birth control without the consent of their partner. My mom works in a public health clinic, and this is a common desire, even here in the US. Mobile phones are a discrete way to send information about family planning methods as well as "hidden" birth control methods like the shot or the IUD.

Nice find Melissa. Seems to be a simple and attractive way for women (and couples) to engage in family planning, and looks like IRH learned a lot about tailoring the application to their beneficiaries from the research summarized in the presentation.

family_planning_via_mobile_phones.title: Family Planning via mobile Phones

easily_administerable_and_low_cost_medic.description: Drugs such as misoprostol can easily help prevent death by bleeding
easily_administerable_and_low_cost_medic.creator: 4c795f957a9d0c3d0a8727b46419e100

comments.text: Any estimates on effectiveness?I have post up on the causes of maternal death during childbirth.  Bleeding is a leading cause.  I had picked infection to tackle, because it seemed the easiest to prevent.  However, if is drug is actually effective it could be a winner.I have another post up on Oral Rehydration Therapy (simple effective solution) that would hold some lessons for gaining acceptance of something like this.

Though it has some disadvantages (lower effectiveness, side effects), looks like its benefits (cheap, room temperature stable, easy to use) make it a potential access-increasing alternative to post-delivery hemorrhage treatments like Oxytocin.

easily_administerable_and_low_cost_medic.title: Easily administerable and low cost medications can prevent death by bleeding

free_midwife_hotline.description: A free 24/7 hotline operated by volunteer midwives and doulas
free_midwife_hotline.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: I was thinking that maybe the volunteer midwives and doulas could also be connected to a network of locally based midwives or doctors. If an extreme emergency happens the vocal assistance form the telephone volunteers may not be enough. Then the volunteers can be the gatekeeper to a local professionel who can get to the woman in need within maybe an hour or two. Of course the local professionel should only be contacted in extreme emergencies. With regards to the network needed for operating the system. A perfect solution would create the opportunity for the volunteers to volunteer while at home doing his/her everyday routines. On person at the phone at a time is probably not enough. Letting them work from home could maybe make it possible to work two hours a week. So, the volunteer should be able to "log on" to the system from home and phone calls from people in need should then be directed to the volunteers private phone. When the shift ends the volunteer can "log off" the system again. It should be possible to solve this with a computer system that the volunteers can call to so that the volunteers do not need any equipment in their private homes.

How can this idea become something that offers both general advice but can also be rolled out to fit the most pressing times? Dealing with an emergency situation is a great challenge but also the most vital aspect of this issue. Can this concept offer both that 'NHS Direct' and Samaritan style support and advice from a call centre but can it connect up to provide the most important assistance to mothers and babies.Agree with @OpenIDEO on what they add.

Hey there Avi!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of a free 24/7 hotline operated by volunteer midwives and doulas.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some thought to more of details involved, perhaps that mash-up some of your cited examples for our particular context.You may consider how the hotline might be centralised and monitored plus how training, quality assurance and consistency could be covered. And in what ways pregnant women would find out and initiate contact to take part.We encourage you to work with Sarah http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/decentralized-mobile-health-care-system/ and Justin http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/pregnant-chat-line/ so you can build a stronger concept together.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Avi, very glad to see your Lokarpit voice concept make it as a final concept. And Robin, wow, great insights & ideas around maintaining privacy on shared phones, incorporating volunteer community members, and continuing communication, based on your direct experience!  Just wanted to point out that diagnostic checklists/charts may also be a helpful supplement for volunteers. And maybe a interactive self-diagnosing voice service option (for callers who want immediate information, and to decrease the load on volunteers), would be a helpful future add-on (see Siri's concept here: http://bit.ly/dLLLkm ).

Hey Avi - it would be great if there was a group chat or FAQ option for women too.  I feel like sometimes they're either shy or unsure of what to ask.  It would be great for them to have the opportunity to listen to what other people are thinking.

No problem! You know what else you could do? You could add a personalized SMS component to the system. For example, once a woman calls in to get an answer to her quesiton, you could include a short pregnancy history and tailor reminder messages regarding prenatal visits, local providers, and other health related messages!
Thanks Robyn for your insightful suggestions! I will integrate your ideas and have added you as a virtual team member for this concept.

Hello Avi! I have worked on a few hotline projects throughout Africa and Latin America and have a couple of things you might want to consider. (1) For rural/remote areas, one thing we have seen is the issue of privacy (in my case it is for reproductive health information/contraception, etc..) - in some remote areas in Nigeria women buy time on a community phone; in cases where midwives or doula's have to follow-up with a caller-- there are issues with other community members finding out about the content of the call. One idea we've had is to have a messaging system for these remote areas where callers would receive a special passcode and could receive private messages with out fear that others could access this information (the same idea could be applied to a family phone too, I suppose). (2) To make the concept even more feasiblewhy not have volunteers be trained community members? If you have a standard set of questions that are typically asked by callers, community members can be trained to provide information and direct women to services; this need not be just midwives and doulas. Rather, you could probably limit the number of professional midwives needed by having a midwife on call to deal with questions that are beyond the hotline operators ability or if there are more in-depth clinical questions.
Avi, this is a really clever idea, and it can be done.R&E

Hi Avi, Lokarpit looks like a well thought out technology. 2 things about it I just wanted to point out that aren't immediately obvious: 1) questioners can automatically recieve automated reply messages/calls at the time of their choosing, 2) answerers can choose to reuse previously recorded answers for commonly repeated questions.
I think our ideas can work together really well!
Wow Avi  the mp3 file really helps paint the picture of how engaging this could be.

free_midwife_hotline.title: Free Midwife Hotline

py/tuple: Does this concept have the potential to save lives related to maternal health in the poorest and most marginalized communities?
A great deal of potential
Some potential

How much does this concept leverage resources and partners in existing low-income communities? Thus enhancing positive aspects of the way things work in the community as opposed to taking away what is a valued way of working and living in the community.

This concept does not work against existing resources and partners

This concept still needs some work before it is self-sustaining

This concept is very well suited to low-tech and low-connectivity environments
This concept needs to be evaluated for technology feasibility
This concept may be too high-tech for low-income communities

remote_doctor_checkins_via_flipcam.description: When the healthworker or doctor cannot make it to every village in person, they can send a Flipcam. Local villagers or worker can interview women at risk about their health status and send the video back to the doctor. If the doctor notices any issues, they can make a special visit or alert locals.
remote_doctor_checkins_via_flipcam.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: Another simple yet strong idea. Inspiring.

Yes, very smart model - both for the ease of sharing info and the empowerment of engaging women as leaders in their own community (I am assuming the local worker would be a woman) also boosts the position of women. While it is not a direct comparison, I know that my HMO having an advice nurse available 24 hours a day means the HMO saves millions and it saves people an incredible amount of time in unneeded visits. At the same time, it means people don't fester on a potential problem because they cannot get to the doctor. Even if every village doesn't have a trained worker there, if people know where to find them and it is a fraction of the distance to a clinic, it can really help catch problems on the early side. Brilliant.
Agree with Kirk  I like how this suggests tech-mediators within the space we're looking at, rather than having everybody running round with gadgets ;^)

Great concept, Haiyan. I like the practicality and directness of the idea. In fact, from your concept I'm envisioning a virtual doctor within a permanent structure, like a tent (with a solar panel on top for power). Most problems and check-ins may be handled here, enabling the HCW's to make the best use of their limited time. I think that your concept addresses this critical need, through mobile technology.Some concepts (including mine, so I'm not off the hook!) suggest a mobile device for every pregnant woman, or every case...and there may be some potential limitations with that model, given this particular context.

remote_doctor_checkins_via_flipcam.title: Remote doctor checkins via Flipcam

comments.text: Hi Alejandro. Nice concept! Have you seen this? http://gcc.eyeptv.net/submission-list/page/4/ The Grand Canada Challenge have some really interesting projects on mobile technologies and maternal health. It may be interesting to have a doctor along with a health education theatre troupe. The troupe along with the doctor educate and then identify people in the community who could become community health workers. This group of individuals is then supported through telemedicine.

Commcare http://www.dimagi.com/commcare/ - may be of some use - it's open source. Guideview may also be of use, but it's not open-source as far as i know - http://guideview.shis.uth.tmc.edu/

portagram_a_portable_sonogram_to_connect.description: Building on various ideas submitted for robust Community Health Worker programs, how about a simple portable sonogram, which could be plugged into a cell phone to text ultrasound images back to a local doctor's office? This would provide both realtime feedback of any major issues, as well as build up an ongoing record of the baby's growth. The practice might even encourage further family support, as these might well be the first glimpses of the baby.

what_phones_do_they_have_already.description: Many of the inspirations are about new technologies.  This is fine, but it makes the diffusion of any concepts harder than if the innovation was able to work on existing infrastructure.  So I asked the question: what phones do they have already?  The answer: ones like a Nokia 1100.
what_phones_do_they_have_already.creator: 94292e3ffc2c71d299d570b8fe937804

comments.text: Nice one!!! The nokia 1100 is a great example of how we can work with low tech (also you can find it everywhere)... We post this a few days ago http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/sms-technology-helping-a-successful-pregnancy-the-malaysia-tsunami-example/You can do a lot of things with SMS technology we have three cases of how you can use use this technology for a lot of purposes

Meena, Thanks for sharing your great insight. I agree that eventually cheaper smartphones will be available everywhere, although the time and rate of adaption is unknown. Do you think that Dharavi and other urban slums are special cases, those markets are catching up faster because of the proximity and exposure of urban lifestyle, acess to consumer goods, media influence etc? People are willing to stretch their budget to own a smartphone and feel good about it.
Very valid point Tristan! Its good to learn about the exsisting intrastructure that can be leveraged immdediately.
Diogo, here is an idea- at every lelve of the snake game an educational video is played that sends a certain message- nutrition, the importance of delivering in a hospital, breastfeeding, etc.
Very good point....I had an inspiration about making cellphone games educational tools for the people and I ask my self now: how to make snake a educational tool? :-pThanks for the inspiration!

I agree Tristan, it is important to look at how we can fulfill the potential of the existing infrastructure. At the same time, there is also space within this challenge for people to help shape the future, including broader issues of equality and how to make communication and opportunity available for everyone. The point about keeping it practical is well taken though - Gregory Elphinston, Nokia

Interesting points Tristan! Also worth noting that this is a rapidly changing realm. This year when visiting Asia's largest slum at Dharavi, Mumbai I noted a big change from last year when I was researching there. I spoke to a mobile phone + shop owner who felt that entry level smartphones were starting to have significant uptake there. I also heard this in Kenyan urban slums, late last year. I guess it's up to OpenIDEATORS to consider whether they want to devise their concepts on your insightful inspiration here  or perhaps also for a rapidly changing future.

Glad you posted this Tristan!  I was about to ask what phones we should build our concepts on.  I agree that we want to reach the largest group possible by addressing those with basic phones.  I also agree with Vincent that smartphones can also play a vital role even in very low-income countries.Is this phone the most popular in low-income countries, specifically Burkina Faso and Bangladesh as mentioned in the challenge brief?

Very good point Tristan, especially when considering feasibility & affordability for mass end-user targeted solutions. At the same time, we should also keep our minds open to future possibilities and for cases where larger populations could be served with one device (e.g. through mobile community health workers).

what_phones_do_they_have_already.title: What phones do they have already?

Although a well rounded health education program can provide the basic understanding of the importance of food and nutrition for the pregnant mother, in reality it becomes very difficult to implement it in practice due to extreme poverty and the rising cost of food.


Can the family benefit from a food voucher program to purchase foods and medication at a subsidized rate?

Hi Nivedita, great Inspiration! I love the idea of using mobile technology to connect mothers and families with access to food/nutrition via vouchers. I wonder how this could be translated into a Concept in our next phase?

It was like a movie session!If those are in mobile phones and have some pregnancy's care information it could teach a lot! :-)

Peter, that is a great question to think about and also, would it be streaming or downloaded video? Vincent, I agree! And thank you Meena! I love stories in popular culture too. it would also be great if people could see videos like "Selina has AIDS" on their mobile phones. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v6zCNdEfm5w. This video has been aired on South African TV but how can we get it FREE to peoples mobiles?

In fact, this concept is not about the text that you send. It's about the text that you do not send. What to do with the characters that you have not used?
