Powerful communicators theses New-Yorkers! ;)

I like this idea a lot -- two question I would think about: 1) The part about pregnant women sending photo updates may not be possible given the relatively thin penetration of smartphones in the developing world (vs. regular mobile phones) 2)  You would have to find a pricing point for the app that makes the manpower on the ground (collecting video, images, stories) aka content providers time worth it. I think just as it is an issue w/ content providers in the developed world -- you would have to make sure the cost of the time used to create content is less than the funds it is bringing in.That said -- I think the model of connecting donors to the cause in a very real-time way is fabulous -- it's what Charity:Water is doing and they are rocking it. Good job!
Very nice method to connect two communities
Terrific idea Flix! I really like this concept!

Yes Krassimira, once the small costs of the app are cover all revenues from it will go to the health center.True also, the full package of social media sharing options is required to foster the ripple effect.

Bravo, Felix- I really like how you built on my idea and came up with a totally new concept! Great job! I was just thinking: the 0.89$ will be sent to the mobile phone of the health center, right?In order to create a ripple effect, the app users shall be able to share this on the FB pages and tweet about it, which I think is a no brainer once such app is available.

comments.text: Thanks for the comments. I believe that if we are building a new solution it needs to be something that is appropriate to the next decade rather than building on technology of the last decade. That said Grameen Apps Labs in Uganda did some research on SMS v Data and concluded that it was 1:20 the cost to send the same information via Data v using SMS. (http://www.grameenfoundation.applab.org/section/index). You only need 2G service for MXit and Java enabled phones are now available from $30. $Billions is being spent in Africa on improving infrastructure and new technologies such as the golf ball size base station from Alcatel-Lucent are going to make it even cheaper and quicker to roll out data coverage. (http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2011/feb/07/mobile-communications)

Nice inspiration, especially in how it extends to other facets of a woman/mother's health.  If a cell-based info source can be a trusted source before pregnancy, that greatly reduces the barrier to being top-of-mind for pregnant women.

Agreed  cost of mobile services is not the only barrier to use. Last year when researching in arguably India's largest slum at Dharavi  the feedback I got from informants definitely supported this. Ease of use was often sited as the key barrier. MXit is a great platform  I met the General Sales Manager in Kenya late last year and it was brilliant to hear about it's successes in Africa. It has *way* more subscribers than Facebook and has been used for a number of local social messaging initiatives. Cheers Peter for highlighting it here!

Very interesting, pointing out how mobile instant messaging can be significantly cheaper than not only voice calls, but also SMS. Was curious, any idea what the typical cost (metered or flat rate, as well as cost of data-service capable phone vs basic phone), coverage (area of data availability vs. basic voice & SMS availability), and penetration (what proportion of mobile phone users have data capable phone and also pay for data services) is like in various developing countries?

an_angel_at_your_fingertips_can_bring_ho.title: An Angel at your fingertips can bring hope and empowerment

[See "mLearning: A Platform for Education" http://www.ictworks.org/news/2011/04/04/mlearning-platform-educational-opportunities-base-pyramid?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Ictworks+%28ICTWorks%29&utm_content=FaceBook]The report has a summary of activity in the industry, to date, and might help generate some additional inspiration for you and the OpenIDEO community.Cheers,Lisa

Hey there Brian!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea that community members with low-end handsets could send and receive text messages to as part of an information hub to support the needs of families.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought into what might be involved. We encourage you to work with Jessie http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/phone-pool/ so you can build a stronger concept together.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!
They could also use the One Computer per Child MESH network to build on an existing system.
Brian, really comprehensive research and compilation ! Great Job.

comments.text: In Poland there are lots of them, too - for blood donating, for mammography... Some of the functions can be minimized. Regular ambulance is not that big and still supports basic functions. There are even bicycle ambulances in London, or mopeds in Israel: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ichud_Hatzalah_scooter.jpg. It could be ready to come and help with basic, yet very important equipement like a small portable incubator and a cpap for the baby.

sms_inputs_provide_actionable_data_for_d.description: Matt's program creates incentives for mothers (and potentially fathers) to respond to maternal health-related text messages, with the intention of using their responses to provide better individual care and advice/instructions.  In addition to this, the most significant benefit of implementing this program may be the data we can gather from asking binary and multiple choice questions of program participants (using the pictograph/coded response method outlined), ultimately leading to better program design.
sms_inputs_provide_actionable_data_for_d.creator: b3131c8b68bf5ff70fd2ecf462546114

comments.text: Hi Sarah,The idea is that hopefully a large company (e.g. Nokia), NGO, or government would have to take on the SMS costs -- basically the zero-rate option mentioned in the discussion you linked to.  As Matt's plan suggests, this would be a small price to pay if the program actually improves maternal health in the short term.  With the additions proposed above, you could even offer the backing group the collected data in return for sponsoring the zero-rate service.  The zero-rate service will only apply to users actively participating in the program, and it seems the per user data would be worth well more than the costs of their per user SMS service.  However, in terms of trying to launch this program on a smaller scale without the financial (plus hardware) support from an outside source, the credit issue remains a significant challenge.

Hi, I'm a big believer of the idea that you can't manage, what you don't measure. And as there are already other programs effectively using SMS to collect data e.g. Childcount, I definitely think this could work.Have you had any thoughts about the logistical challenge of distributing SMS credit? There was a discussion about this on the ict4chw google group a while back - http://groups.google.com/group/ict4chw/browse_frm/thread/766d5515be5740e1 some interesting perspectives were shared. Below is a copy&paste of the discussion round-up from Isaac Holeman (also available on the google group thread)***Hi Everyone, Everyone is welcome to continue posting, but this seems like a good time to wrap this discussion up by summarizing a few points and thanking everyone for participating. 32 posts is definitely more than I was expecting! - Reverse billing, short codes etc are possible, and usually the best option if your project is large and you have staff who can make a good business pitch to the local telcos. - Smaller projects, those that need to get up and running quickly, or project that lacks the savvy to pitch to/negotiate with a telecom will usually want to reimburse their health workers manually. The key to success here may be in creating proper incentive structures. For example, allowing some extra airtime for personal use, making airtime a collective resource so that peers in the community enforce prudent airtime use, - To "reimburse manually" could mean handing out paper scratch-off airtime vouchers, sending airtime directly from facility SIM to CHW SIM, distributing voucher pins via SMS, or having a telco or kiosk vender send out airtime for you. The most appropriate method may depend on your incentive structure. - There are also technical hacks - for example only buying data bundles among CHWs who don't use data, getting smart phones that can restrict which numbers may be called/SMSed, or working with a telco to restrict sms/voice/gprs services and outgoing numbers (the reality may not live up to the expectation with some telcos). - Long term, I'm excited to continue conversations about working with individual telcos and the GSMA 'union' to make available the services that will be most useful to us. Based on the broad issues we're discussing here I think there is a profit incentive for telcos to offer these services. Eduardo offered some useful insight on how to go about making the pitch to various telcos. I've recorded a some of this on my blog for any who are interested. http://www.isaacholeman.org/2010/managing-airtime-with-community-heal... cheers Isaac *****

sms_inputs_provide_actionable_data_for_d.title: SMS Inputs Provide Actionable Data for Design

treating_premature_births_with_limited_r.description: In the face of limited access to childbirth professionals, particularly in the case of premature birth, these limited resources should be allocated based on the best estimate of need. In doing so, the number of childbirth related can be minimized while using the limited resource of childbirth professionals most effectively.  An accurate and quick estimation of need could be provided using a combination of mobile phones, internet database of symptoms and a decision tree machine learning technology implemented either automatically or by a phone-operator.
treating_premature_births_with_limited_r.creator: 4499f3d48a887f19702a3c39090a4dc4

comments.text: The decision tree can be a device for educating the expectant mother as well as addressing emergencies.  A voice synthesis system could make it two way.

*Nod*, important to prioritize resources to best serve everyone by triaging appropriately. If the decision tree is executed through an automated voice system, may also want to provide a live operator option (for people with trouble with the voice system, and for life threatening emergencies where time is of the essence).

treating_premature_births_with_limited_r.title: Treating Premature births with limited resources

To care for pregnancy and childbirth, you need a midwife and a doctor. grameen_moms_support_group.description: Moms don’t have money to pay for healthcare, but midwifes find it hard to provide services without getting paid. Moms also need peer support from other knowledgeable moms. Building off of the Grameen Village Phone and Self Help Group models, a Moms Support Group (MSG) could help moms make an income and pay for healthcare. Moms can be trained to be village phone ladies, who operate mobile phones like pay phones, and pool their profits into a group fund. 10-15 moms per MSG can work with a midwife in their area. The group funds can pay the midwife for services like personal consultations or prenatal/antenatal workshops on subjects like nutrition and child care. The moms can also provide peer support by giving each other advice and helping to care for each others' children. Group funds buy supplies like clean birth kits (with hygienic instruments for delivery) or to pay for an ambulance service to take them the clinic in case of a complication. Group funds can pay for midwives to be professionally trained.
grameen_moms_support_group.creator: 986367cab041526c6231636304ad25ce

comments.text: Wow Jessica  fab visualisations and great for us to be able to draw on your insights from on the ground in Zambia!

keep_it_simple_task_calendar_and_contact.description: We always have some way of organizing our days. Why not leverage the Nokia phone for their existing technology of calendaring and task management, and contacts. For new mothers, having a pre-set checklist available from the time of pregnancy to the different trimesters and then to child rearing till 5 years (initially) would be a god sent. Then linking the checklist to the calendar for reminders and key appointment with links to contacts would further leverage the technology. If the internet is robust enough, then have feeds from key resources show health updates related to the stage in which the mother is.
keep_it_simple_task_calendar_and_contact.creator: 5b313d9be58be178837e55d275c860dd

comments.text: I love the idea of educating the mothers about tips to stay healthy, but worry about the costs involved in requiring a smart phone and data package in order to reap the benefits. Perhaps a more feasible solution based on the same idea would be to have the mothers-to-be receive phones that would send them educating text messages and reminders based on their reported due date.It would be great if a separate transportation system could be set up to transport these women to mid-wives, (that are potentially too far away to reach in a manor they can afford,) when it is time for their delivery. These distributed phones could be pre-programmed with numbers call on this service to pick them up, as well as a direct line to mid-wives for advise the women during all stages of their pregnancy.

keep_it_simple_task_calendar_and_contact.title: Keep it simple-Task, calendar and contacts

mobile_device_enabled_women_s_group.description:
Concept:
Create Women's Groups as a health service platform to collectively save money, share experiences and build social capital. Use a specially designed mobile device with simple applications giving access to preloaded health-related audio and video content, a simple finance tool, and communication with the hospital, midwives, and a call-in health radio program.
mobile_device_enabled_women_s_group.creator: aad00b6ec94fd327036988da1a118144

comments.text: My response to the comment by my Chinese friends: "your're very right in saying so and I didn't really intend to ignore such important elements. In terms of collective savings, poor people tend to borrow lots of money from private money lender with very high interests rate when they're in need of cash and I met so many poor family did so when their wives were pregnant. In many poor communities in rural Cambodia (as far as I know), people are happy to contribute with very small amount because they know that how much ever they put in the saving and the amount they would pay back if they borrow money from the saving, they will get it back later on. For service fee of hospital and midwives, quality of services etc, the concept itself only focuses on the use of mobile technology. of course it is very important to look at all the health system factors as you suggested and even if we introduce a very innovative way to integrate mobile technology into maternal health intervention, things won't make any sense if we don't take those health system factors into consideration."

My response to the comment by my Chinese friends: "your're very right in saying so and I didn't really intend to ignore such important elements. In terms of collective savings, poor people tend to borrow lots of money from private money lender with very high interests rate when they're in need of cash and I met so many poor family did so when their wives were pregnant. In many poor communities in rural Cambodia (as far as I know), people are happy to contribute with very small amount because they know that how much ever they put in the saving and the amount they would pay back if they borrow money from the saving, they will get it back later on. For service fee of hospital and midwives, quality of services etc, the concept itself only focuses on the use of mobile technology. of course it is very important to look at all the health system factors as you suggested and even if we introduce a very innovative way to integrate mobile technology into maternal health intervention, things won't make any sense if we don't take those health system factors into consideration."

My Chinese friend who studied together gave a great comments via facebook:"Great job, Ayako. Low communication is a major problem in rural area regarding to the womens reproductive health. I have two concerns about your concepts. 1.Collective Savings may not feasible, if the poor women are willing to contribute the money? And how to manage it? 2.How are the hospitals and midwives involved? Are their service free, and how this project can improve their services quality and increase the affordability?"
Great insights from personal perspectives + builds on existing concepts  embracing the power of collaboration!
Love the "Car Talk" for pregnancy idea!

comments.text: Nice idea! As others have suggested, you might also want to think about the incentives for contribution: how can you ensure that mothers will respond continuously and consistently?
What if women received free phone credit(s) each day for their text update. It would help keep regular contact, as well as incentive to check in each day.
I think that would be a great incentive :-)
Thanks everyone for your encouragement and great feedback!
I like your project. Its very well suited to fit low income countries. And the division between SMS and audio message is very clever. Good luck :)
Thanks Paul! Hope you are well!
finally my "put-it-off-until-later" strategy worked out for me ;)
Hi Vincent and Sarah, yikes! It's my own fault for being so late with the builds.You could write an email with your new evaluation to hello@openideo.com and it'll get added in. Thanks so much!!
Same here, Vincent!
Oh no! I evaluated your concept before you updated it Haiyan. Is there any way to re-evaluate?
Just updated my concept. Take a look at the image gallery for an illustrated scenario of the MumDiary service.
Haiya, This could also be used to push "meetup" notifications at local community get-togethers or religious festivals based on each mom's location and signup date.
Hi everyone, thanks so much for your builds! I've been a bit behind in Refining this concept. I will try to get to it this afternoon :) Cheers,Haiyan

In terms of feasibility, I wonder about dedication and duration.  The benefit of use (saying that the right tool, communication was found) would require a daily diligence.  For anyone who has written daily journals or blogs, there is a diligence needed that surpasses intention.  We first assume that healthy pregnancy is a critical value/event in life.  If so, that may be enough to keep woman using this.  However, it won't be the only factor.  Life goes fast, situations change.  Feasibility wise, its not the technology that will be challenging.  It will be the human behavior.

Excellent idea. However, I was wondering whether these updates could somehow be narrativized and visualized for the purposes of both the mothers, as well as, the medical care providers. Narratives or stories are easier to convey and transmit in most cultures, rather than list-type forms.

I was wondering if pregnant women connecting with each other in their neighborhood would be of any value? Also, would new mothers who have gone through the experience be of any value other than health care professionals - sort of mentors for pregnant women. The localization piece of the SMS could be used to triangulate mentors and other women in a similar situation to create a sense of community and collective welfare among these women.

I absolutely agree with Louise's point about keeping the system simple that pregnant women don't get frustrated and stop using it. We all know how bad it can get when you have to shout the same phrase five times to a phone!Louise also brings up an important issue - whether the technology can support icons or graphics. Based on my experience in the field, phones people own can vary from a basic Nokia phone with text only to a high-tec phone with color screen and multimedia functions. It would be really interesting to study the types of phones women of child-bearing age typically own and what functionalities they support.
you should probably think in the way we communicate with emoticons. I think that would help aswell.

To build on all these comments, the simplicity is great and an SMS service is a fantastic idea but anything with voice activation (answering yes/no to questions) can be frustrating, especially if there are accent/language barriers - just a thought, not a critism!One thing I do think could work, however is having a daily tip/piece of advice that pops up as an SMS which could relate to latest health trends, recent calls or general 'what to look out for during pregnancy'.  Thinking Twitter, a short piece of information can be very helpful, unintrusive yet engaging.I do like the idea of using icons if the technology is feasible - I'm assuming that the mobile phones these people will have will be basic.

One thought along what Sina and Kevin mentioned - about have a response-based system (are you okay? yes / no) and around medical emergencies - I'm curious whether a health care professional could be dispatched or located (via Map?) nearby?  Immediately after reading, I thought was that the health data could actually be being monitored outside of the city/region/country - a sort of outsourcing.  However, somehow there'd need to be a local option of connectivity.  Just a thought.

Came here with my comment readyand @Joy has highlighted my concern:There has to be an incentive for the mothers to be to remain engaged. After all, were all busy people. How can we achieve this? Another thing that I'd like to explore is that, for me, what makes this powerful is the potential to collect data and to use that data effectively to change lives (it could become a lobby tool, be like a census to help allocate resources) can these ideas play a role in achieving that?

This is a great idea!   To build on Kevins and Vincents comments, I like the idea of adding an automated system with prompts.  There may be signs and symptoms of problems that mothers may not recognize and, as a result, not communicate.  Maybe creating a brief what to expect in your ___ month message for women to listen to at the beginning of each month would be helpful. The message would have information about what is normal and what should cause concern.  This would give the mothers a baseline for what should be reported via SMS txt message.  A mother could even text the system indicating that she was ready to listen to the message and the system would  call her back for free (good catch identifying that potential cost barrier Kevin).Something else that came to mind when reading through this concept was how to keep mothers engaged in the process. Personal contact from someone on the other end of the phone may help ensure a womens participation throughout the duration of their pregnancy.  Their interest may wane a bit without a little more interaction. This may be running too far into left field but adding a periodic call from the healthcare worker tracking their pregnancy might be helpful.  It may help the women feel supported in all aspects of their pregnancy, not just emergencies.

Oops. I forgot to add that the automated voice system will allow standardization of questions and answers to simplify the analysis as Ryan suggested below. It can be also customized to target different issues as different stages of pregnancy as well.

This is a great idea. I agree with Vincent and Arjan that low literacy will be an issue, especially among women with poor access to maternal care and voice may be a more accessible option than SMS. Maybe it can be like automated phone systems (like customer service systems nowadays) where the system will ask a few simple questions and pregnant women will verbally provide answers (Q: "Have you felt bloated for the past five days? Please tell me yes or no." A: "No"). The program can actually call out future moms. This will not only work as a reminder but also cheaper for them since in many developing countries, it costs to call out and but it doesn't cost to receive a call.

Super cool. Also, as they are reporting and something goes through that requires critical condition or is a major risk to the mother or baby, the mom can get a text alerting her of the condition: "go see a doctor, you may be ..." or if it is a simple remedy to signs of dehydration, hints can come through "drink more water, you are showing signs of dehydration".

I agree with the general opinion below that the simplicity is a very strong element. And I agree with Vincent that alternatives for when literacy is an issue should be as simple as well. Like voice response or maybe icons.

I like the simplicity of this.  I think having simple, standardized answers would also have the advantage of creating a cleaner data set, which would make it easier to analyze trends.  It also makes it a much quicker task, less intimidating than entering free-form text.
I like this idea! You could build on this database to include pregnancy mapping for groups of women in villages or communities to see map overall the health and wellbeing of the women.

Haiyan, was just thinking more about this concept and appreciating the simplicity and the active involvement of moms. Perhaps where literacy is an issue, automated voice systems could also be utilized. Anyone with medical experience have thoughts on what information would be most useful for moms to report on?
Very nice. It's like a database as well with good info for future mums!

Really like how this might help women engage with their own maternal process  while providing an avenue for health workers to track in case intervention/advice is needed. Plus the simplicity of SMS + keyword prompts make the concept seem highly usable.

comments.text: I think mobile tech could be used w children in number of ways...games, social networking, text messages similar to the concepts of texting moms. Kids do so much for a family in rural communities.  I used to see children only slightly bigger than their younger sibling carrying them all day!  Children really take on responsibility like I have never seen before.

Nice one Dan. comments.text: Great point Alessandro. I dug into the topic and the most credible research (3rd party) that I came across is here:http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/cellphones The research does not even distinguish between correlation and causation, yet the inconclusiveness of the studies does not undermine your observation. It simply signals that we do not know as much about it as we would like.Since we're using mobile technology to reduce the acutely high death rates related to pregnancy and birth, I'm wondering how it factors in. One way or another, the device will remain close to the body. On the diagram I suggested the ankle as a possibility...does anyone have any more ideas, or comments?

It is an important issue! However, we should also consider that cell phones emit electromagnetic waves... Too close to the baby (belly) could have consequences for their formation have not yet studied...Nokia is one of the manufacturers who are concerned more with the subject, which, by itself, it is very controversial ...

Yes! I like it. If it comes in the form of a strap, collecting temperature and pulse data would be easy. (As long as it can't be easily ripped off, or cause discomfort)And, branching off of your idea (verbal educational content), placing it close to the neck would obviate the need for headphones / wires etc. because it would be close to the ears. Keeping it simple.

Hi Kirk, great idea! I was also thinking along this lines- what about a necklace. As women often bent over when they work at home or in the field, it might be useful to have the option to shorten the necklace as they want and whever they want. What do you think?
Thanks Ashley. Experience, although not always welcome, is the best teacher. :)
You've raised some really important questions here Kirk! Great job.

rainy_season_non_vulnerable_season_dry_s.description: Considering that Labour vulnerability (whereas victims are Burkina Faso Mothers) influences directly on the physical and emotional health and the fact that agricultural sector (where most of them work) has a Dry and Wet season, as well as non-productive seasons; we have decided to focus our concept taking in advantage this last season which has been named as “Non Vulnerable Season”, to develop activities with mothers and expectant ones. These activities will bring benefits to their health and also generate a better stability in the constant income, using the available resources in the zone and lowering the index of dismisses due to the pregnancy state of one women.
rainy_season_non_vulnerable_season_dry_s.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: Hello there Estudio. Thanks for the message. The internet is pretty poor over here today...so not much time to comment. Lovely concept...I'll share some ideas on localised community income generation when I'm better connected.
We have just uploaded a .pdf showing the social action model of the campaign. We propose and intervention strategy to enter and help develop the community.

Hi there Estudio 6, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of a campaign to promote the needs of the vulnerable.To further develop your concept we would really love to know your thoughts on how this campaign could be visualised? What would some of the posters and graphics look like? And what are some core activities that the campaign could organise?To build upon your Service Print, we wonder if these events could also be self-organised (in order for them to be scalable across the world with minimal support). Perhaps the organisers can provide the raw materials, a starter pack, and motivated locals can organise the events.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields: - Concept Builds - Here you can list additional builds on your concept - Virtual Team - Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept. Cheers! OpenIDEO

We have just uploaded a .pdf showing the project axis, structure and points where prototyping is necessary, we'd utterly appreciate comments, suggestions, feedback in general,looking forward to your attentionthanks :)x

You propose making paper, community gardens and yoghurt kitchens as jobs for the women. Maybe they could produce things to be used by pregnant women or new moms. E.g. they could sew diapers or childrens cloth (which is sold cheap). This would help other moms or moms to be as well as give the women a possitive feeling of helping women in "the same situation" probably making the work fullfilling.

Thanks for your comment!. Yes, probably there are ways for moms to make money using mobile phones. However, we decided to focus our concept not only on mobile phones, but also on other mobile technologies that already exist and can tell women  when, where and how can they get money, using local resources and making the most of the NON-VULNERABLE SEASON that we propose.
Very insightful that moms also need to make money. Perhaps there are ways for moms to make money using mobile phones?

Es importante disear centrndonos en las necesidades del usuario apoyndoce de herramientas tales como el design thinking como una clave para aproximarse a estas comunidades vulnerables y realizar un proceso de diseo pasndolo a las manos ... de los afectados para as construir de forma integral, con una solucin y oportunidad coherente a las capacidades de la comunidad, en cuanto a los niveles de alfabetizacin, los ingresos, el uso de tecnologas hbridas y toda una serie de requerimientos que responden a condiciones extremas de diseo, uso e interaccin; como elemento que permita escalar este tipo de proyectos a diversos lugares y poblaciones en el globo.

comments.text: great idea!~ simple and efficient

Olga, I really like this idea. What do you suggest be done in a case where the women to be reached are illiterate? Is there support for MMS for pictures and graphics, and would that cost be covered by some sort of grant or donations?

Thank you for suggestion!Generally illiterate communities would be less well off so I dont think that they would have devices like smar phones which support interactive pictures and videos. But MMS certainly should be used. For example, a woman can even receive images of her developing baby depending on her pregnancy time, inforgraphics explaining how things work, pictures of food, exercise etc.

Also, we should be mindful of how much can be answered in 140 characters, and what the process is if the question can not be answered within this constraint. Health issues can be complex, and answers should not be simplified to meet this requirement
The issue of longer messages can be addressed by cutting one message short and typing more or -> (to make an arrow). The cost per text message can be an issue that needs to be addressed.

Interesting idea, which makes so much sense given limited health resources and huge health needs. Like many things in a low-income context the how is where the best thinking becomes really important. I have noticed that Google has some recent experience in this area - http://blog.google.org/2009/06/google-sms-to-serve-needs-of-poor-in.html  From a brief discussion with a staff member of google.org about it, I understand that it worked in Uganda if it is completely free. This was supported by a pilot that started out free and then moved to usual sms costs where the usage tapered off. Perhaps you should get in touch with them to see the pilot evaluation to find out why. Best of luck!

I like this idea. The how is seems to be the tricky part - like with many ideas in low-income contexts. I understand that Google.org has some recent experience in this area - http://blog.google.org/2009/06/google-sms-to-serve-needs-of-poor-in.htmlFrom a brief discussion with a staff member of google.org, I understand that it worked in Uganda when it was completely free. This was supported by a pilot that started out free and then moved to usual sms costs where usage tapered away. Perhaps you should get in touch to see the evaluation of the pilot and find out why?

I like the idea of an SMS Q&A service that cross-references a data-base of existing information - definitely helps manage limited capacity. However, I think if the question can not be answered it should be placed into an "open-question" (like a help-desk open-ticket) database, that is managed by a group of doctors / nurses (vs. having the question sent out to a group of people via SMS). The business model is tricky - low-income mothers are not frequently a target market by companies that can afford advertising. Probably requires some more research to assess feasibility.

Hmm, Hima, some of your suggestions make me think of stackoverflow, the Q&A site that works with "karma," which has found some incredible answers about Q&A sites. Here is a google talk Joel Spolsky the founder gave: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NWHfY_lvKIQ Thinking what lessons could be pulled in for something like this....
Oh, sorry. You already mentioned it in your brief. My bad.

I see the potential here. Some refinement needed though. I think this idea can be further polished to resemble a dynamic FAQ page (I don't know what it's called). Basically, before you ask a question business/person/organization, the system looks up for similar questions and provides you with answers that might be helpful.This way, redundancy is eliminated. Quora is a perfect example of this. :)

Thanks for valuable comments everyone! To have a mentor is a good idea. Actually I was thinking a doctor or a nurse assigned to an area would take the responsibilities of a mentor. Having weekly SMS with high quality content is a good idea as well. For example specific suggestions can be given to different women depending on the their pregnancy period.

Thanks for valuable comments everyone! To have a mentor is a good idea. Actually I was thinking a doctor or a nurse assigned to an area would take the responsibilities of a mentor. Having weekly SMS with high quality content is a good idea as well. For example specific suggestions can be given to different women depending on the their pregnancy period.

Hello!I agree with some of the comments regarding the quality of the content that the women may be answering in the forum. Some times in rural areas there exist a lot if "myths" and "tabus" and if no moderation exist in this forums, it might as well be a source of dissinformation. So what I suggest is that you could maybe place a mentor per each of the geographic/ or social group, how can play the role of demystifier. Users might as well receive a weekly SMS with high quality content that you can provide as a free service to mantain the netwrk active.
groupme.com is a good technical model. i'm sure you could build a similar service using Twilio (which is a platform that boogies using SMS and Mobile interaction technologies).

I think this is great concept and agree with the recent comments.  I think targets the groups by geographic area is important for group/sms management.  My concept of geosocial SMS network would work well in supporting this initiative http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/global-village-supporting-new-mothers/

Hey there Olga!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea for a low-cost internet forum.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought into what might be involved. When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

Olga, the concept of creating community is a great one, and so is the idea that women themselves can be owners of information. However, it seems that misinformation can be a real problem. I imagine this could be a great add-on to one of the other ideas here that provide information. Perhaps the women participating in a camp during the NONVULNERABLE season, or midwives could keep in touch through this SMS tree.

Hi. This is a simple and great idea.  In order to make it more manageable in terms of numbers consider location based SMS forums so that the expectant mothers could automatically be placed into groups depending on their geographical locations and they would then SMS one another within a smaller group.  It would perhaps also make the conversations more relevant and closer to home with the mothers sharing similar situations and having a manageable continuous conversation via SMS which is more focused as opposed to a myriad of issues with very large numbers tapping into one forum.  Also maybe it could be possible for a mother in one forum who wishes to participate if only for a limited time in another forum in a nearby or far away location could also subscribe to it temporarily.  Just a thought. Looking forward to the refined concept.

Thanks for the comments. I agree that this will have lots of limitations (such as what you have listed and more). But I would like to stress that the idea is to simulate online forums where you dont necessarily meet knowledgeable people but rather people with the same issues and some previous experience (this is the answer to the 3rd point).

It's a nice idea... but I am a glass half empty person, believing we can learn from the holes/issues.  So please don' t take this the wrong way. I'll be putting up a concept tomorrow so you can 'half empty' that as much as you want.So, my issues:1.  I think this could suffer from size issues and the numbers of sms messages don't get unwieldy. 2.  Answering questions in the format of an sms itself can be limited.3.  You have to be confident that the people answering the questions will have good answers.  If they don't (and at worst give contrary info) then you'd have a problem.However, I understand this is just a brainstorm.  The great things:1.  I do think this idea creating a network with phones has legs.  2.  SMS is an existent technology so it will be able to diffuse quite easily. Overall: nice building block.  Well done.

I think this idea could work very well with the 'Cellphones as incentive and compliance mechanism for maternal health' concept (which established buy-ins and compliance), and could be incorporated as a more structured incentive for literate users to participate!
Yes. Thank you for the link! In this case it can be focused on a specific crowd - pregnant women and moms with new born babies.

Excellent idea. In terms of the technology back-end, Mobilizing Health - http://mobilizinghealth.org/ - have done a pilot of a system that connects patients to doctors in kind of a similar way, if I understand you right. Perhaps you can leverage off their technology but applying it to your idea here, which is a different context, but maybe you can save some time when you're going for a pilot.
Yes, since the program has to very cheap or even free (otherwise sending one sms to many numbers at the same time would make user think twice) then sponsorship should be provided. Ads is a way to go!

Great stuff Olga! And maybe a notification SMS could go out if the question is not answered within a certain period of time? If a telco were to sponsor this, users could earn airtime by answering queries  perhaps the user making the enquiry could indicate they've 'accepted' an answer to action points to the user providing the answer? And participating CHW's could maybe donate their airtime in some way? And we're loving the fact that you've used to Brainstorm-in-a-Box toolkit to generate your idea! If others want to check it out: http://bit.ly/brain_box
I agree! Powerful yet simple.
Olga, kudos for using the concept capture sheet!A lovely idea!

low_cost_internet_free_forum.title: Low cost free SMS forum

py/tuple: Does this concept have the potential to save lives related to maternal health in the poorest and most marginalized communities?
A great deal of potential
Some potential
Not a lot of potential
How realizable do you think this concept can be? Think about the real issues faced by low-income communities, such as literacy challenges, affordability of devices and tools, usage costs.
It's very realizable
There are some hurdles to realization
This concept is not realistic

How much does this concept leverage resources and partners in existing low-income communities? Thus enhancing positive aspects of the way things work in the community as opposed to taking away what is a valued way of working and living in the community.
This concept works harmoniously with existing resources and partners
This concept does not work against existing resources and partners
This concept conflicts with existing resources and partners
Can this concept become self-sustaining and even provide some livelihood value add to the community?
This concept could become a self-sustaining business for locals
This concept still needs some work before it is self-sustaining
This concept is not self-sustaining at all
Will this concept work in low-tech & low-connectivity environments?
This concept is very well suited to low-tech and low-connectivity environments
This concept needs to be evaluated for technology feasibility
This concept may be too high-tech for low-income communities

mom_to_midwife.description: A mother who has been through childbirth has experience to help others. How about giving her professional qualification and pride?
mom_to_midwife.creator: 1bfd77483278e03e830fe15491d59ef0

comments.text: This is a great concept, but I really dont see phone being effective in some rural communities especially in Africa

Hi Steph, your concept helped me to recognize that mom mentors would be a natural recruiting/training pool for future midwives! Have this into the "Concept Builds" section of my "Mom Mentor" concept, and added you to the "Virtual Team" so you get a Design Quotient Collaboration Score Boost. Would love to hear more from you about how we could effectively implement this mom to mentor to midwife program!
I love the idea of training people on the ground - built-in sustainability!

Great concept. I think one of the challenges to confront might be the sustainability of the effort. At some point, if the midwives/doulas aren't able to be paid for their time and effort, then I wonder how long they will continue giving their services. (This is presuming the mother's aren't able to pay for services.) But perhaps inventive other ways could be innovated to make it sustainable...

I really like this Concept. What I particularly like about this concept is that you're tackling the idea of where to source new mid-wives from - so many more are needed so I think this is a great idea.Building on this, I was thinking that a potential source of content could be the Khan Academy - they don't have any videos on midwifery at the moment, but perhaps they could make some. Salman Khan explains the concept really well in his TED Talk http://bit.ly/ted-khan-academy but one of the advantages of video-based tutorial is that people can learn at their own pace in their own time and then when they're with a teacher - in this case a professional midwife, time can be spent on concepts and questions and quality interaction.The phone could be the medium for viewing the video...of course this raises issues about what kinds of phones are available to the potential mid-wives. Perhaps Jessie's idea of a Phone Pool could be applicable http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/phone-pool/
Steph, we're working on a Refine phase for this challenge. Stay tuned, will announce in a day or 2.

Hi Heather and Priya, thanks for your comments :) I like the idea of the doula -- my thinking was that given there's obviously a skill shortage for midwives, more than mentoring, we need people with the skills--and as a by-product, the women who have the skills become important pillars of the community, and it's a personally empowering thing that will build confidence.Hi Sarah, you're so right re employment! I think we can't underestimate the empowerment in being materially compensated. There are so many great ideas and concepts generated so far, I wish we could all take these into a second concept phase to really solidify the ideas and collective turn them into something we can execute.

This is a great idea. It is sort of like a midwife/doula relationship. Anyone who has given birth knows that in addition to having someone with medical understanding about giving birth and dealing with complications, it is also extremely helpful to have someone there to give encouragement, massage, sing, get water, etc. The training needed to be a doula is less intensive, and therefor easier to share with a larger number of women, than becoming a midwife, but still a critical role that can bring a lot of satisfaction to everyone.

I like that this balances out the supply-demand of midwives-patients, all while empowering the community of women to learn emergency care.  I am thinking it's like volunteers who are CPR certified; knowing the most important things to keep the patient in stable condition until a mid-wife could be brought to the premise.

Thank you Steph for this concept! I am definitely fond of the idea of involving local moms in the process... It's a great way to ensure that awareness around maternal health issues will be spread amongst their communities in a culturally adapted way. It could also prove economically favorable to the local communities if the moms are actually employed. You can find some of these ideas at the level 3 of this concept too: http://bit.ly/eXr8ER

mom_to_midwife.title: Mom to Midwife

qr_code_amulet_activates_pregnancy_calls.description: A QR code amulet issued to the mom upon conception triggers delivery of timed maternal health calls to the mom's phone.
qr_code_amulet_activates_pregnancy_calls.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: This is a practical application of a developed technology. The hardware, Teknocharm, needs to be made available to the ones it benefits.R&E

Thanks Sarah - good to know!Thanks Krassimira - yes, the HCW would provide the QR amulet. The mom would still meet with the HCW regularly but the calls to her (prerecorded, automatic) would be customized according to the latest data collected by the HCW since (incoming calls are free).

Avi, I think this is a fantastic idea! Couple of question: The HCW would be the one to provide the mother with the amulet, right? the way to track how the pregnancy evolves is by giving the expectant mom calls, right? so, the only way for the HCW to figure out if anything is wrong is to rely on the mom-to-be information? Let me know ur thoughts...

Nice, to give you a little more elaboration on the "minimum level of technology" I have tested the open-source zxing on ~$70 nokia phones like the 2700c and it works but it does need good lighting and as the cameras on lower end phones don't have an autofocus you need to keep the camera and the qr code still - but very workable. Nice idea. Provides some confidentiality also.

qr_code_amulet_activates_pregnancy_calls.title: QR code amulet triggers timed maternal health calls to mom's phone

avalanche_transmitters.description: Avalanche transmitters, like Recco, send signal to the rescue teams which helps find the person under the snow. Same technology could be used to transmit the SOS signal whenever the basic parameters of pregnancy go below the safe line.
avalanche_transmitters.creator: f663744062e5876058493e584f1dbd3e

comments.text: Thx Arjan! ;)
Great out-of-the-box thinking, Lukasz.

avalanche_transmitters.title: Avalanche transmitters

involving_men_in_maternity_care.description:
"Men generally do not accompany their partners to family planning, antenatal or postnatal care services and would not be expected to attend the labor or birth of their child. In addition, men are rarely exposed to clinic reproductive health services as they often seek care for STIs in the private sector and condoms can be obtained from clinics without contact with providers. The issue of accessibility of reproductive health (RH) services to men in South Africa is a logistical and cultural problem. The exclusive use of services by women has to a great extent made RH services unfriendly for men. The need for integration of these services (i.e., antenatal, STI, family planning and male involvement) seems both appropriate and timely.
Traditionally, couples and providers alike have considered family planning (FP) a woman’s issue."
involving_men_in_maternity_care.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751

comments.text: I think you can reach fathers through teaching them what the health of their wife/mate means.  Health for their child.  What does health of a child mean?  Health of family ability to be provided for in the next phase as well as the opportunity for passing on gained knowledge.  With a healthy mate comes healthy children.

involving_men_in_maternity_care.title: INVOLVING MEN IN MATERNITY CARE

a_remote_sensing_solution_brings_urban_d.description: ReMeDi (Remote Medical Diagnostics) is a solution kit that connects rural patients with urban doctors at a low cost. Trained operators at Internet kiosks transmit the patients’ readings to doctors who make diagnosis and issue prescriptions. ReMeDi, a solution developed by the Indian based Neurosynaptic Communications, measures four vital patients’ signs: temperature, blood pressure, heart beat and blood oxygenation.
a_remote_sensing_solution_brings_urban_d.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: I wonder how I have missed this concept until now... Great idea Krassimira! I really like the fact that it could also be used for knowledge transfer, and not only diagnostic. And thanks for the figures related to the costs, this is helping me get a better idea of the possible business models...
Being a big fan of eco-system thinking  am loving your big picture considerations here Krassimira!

You're absolutely right that bandwidth (especially at a low-cost) is an issue, and may mean portability is more of a long-term goal. At the same time, some information (like temperature) only needs low bandwidth, while other information (i.e. certain disease testing) may require further analysis so slow upload, or storage and transfer later, may be less of an issue.
Vincent, thanks for the comment- great idea you have! I was wondering if the bandwidth would be an issue if the kiosk becomes mobile...thoughts?

Krassimira, great, well thought out concept! Really taking advantage of the decreasing cost and portability of health sensors to distribute out access locally.As costs and portability continues to improve, perhaps this kiosk could even become mobile, so that the midwife/health worker can actually use it for home visits.

a_remote_sensing_solution_brings_urban_d.title: A remote sensing solution for moms-to-be

kangaroo_mothers.description:
“The program ‘madre canguro’ or 'kangaroo care' gave the children with low weight, the opportunity of being close to their mothers, and away of death and abandonment”. 
It is an approach method, that humanizes the treatment for the newborns with low weight. The babies develop emotional boundaries, as they spent the hole time with the parents, or with close relatives.
kangaroo_mothers.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: And by the way - not only for the child of course, but it has some truly remarkable effects also on the mother, physiological as well as psychological, ranging from stimulating the milk production, regulating body temperatures, etc, to bonding and reducing risk of post-natal depressions. And as a low-cost incubator method - the father can also contribute of course. Lovely stuff.

This is very inspirational - and illustrates just how powerful beautiful amazing mechanisms the human body is capable of. Just as a side note - this method is very appropriate also for children with "normal" birth-weight and carried full-term :)

yes, have the same purpose,but this dont have aditional cost becouse the "incubator" is the skin contact between mother, father,or another family integrant and the infant.http://www.kangaroomothercare.org/index.php?lang=es

this is a fantastic inspiration!... in project "Embrace" a low cost incubator to serve the same purpose- Sarah has shared this inpiration with the community http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/a-low-cost-infant-incubator/

kangaroo_mothers.title: Kangaroo mothers

missed_call_sos_getting_help_when_you_ve.description: I got this idea from community health workers in Karachi, Pakistan. Build on existing habit of "missed" calls to communicate without spending credit. 1 missed call "I need some advice"  -- 5 missed calls "urgent care required"
missed_call_sos_getting_help_when_you_ve.creator: 8fac924254004c7d9240333ca42693c5

comments.text: Thanks Dara, I posted on my Facebook to try and get more feedback, my friend Romain asked "Stupid question, is there any way to make this work in markets where cell phone billing works more like the US (i.e., you pay/use minutes both when making and receiving a call)? Or is the US the only market where it works like this anyway?"  In my experience this is a US-only phenomenon, but I'd be really interested to know other experiences.

Excellent application of local systems/knowledge!  When I worked in Southern Africa people would often "buzz" me so I could call them back - seems like a natural extension that capitalizes on local resources (or lack thereof).
Hi Jess, I like it - great idea for tying in - I know the one you're talking about, can't find the link...do post it if you run across it.

Hi Sarah. Great idea! Here's a possible extension: The mom's cell number could be linked with her medical records, her midwife's cell phone number, and her location in a database. When she gives the emergency number a missed call, it can automatically notify her midwife of the mom's emergency and home address so the midwife can go immediately to her aid. Maybe platforms like the one noted by Meena can do such things?  I suggested a special emergency number so that the mom only has to make 1 missed call and it communicates all the critical info to the people that need to know.

Hi Meena - thanks so much - that's totally awesome - hadn't heard of it at all. Really starts to expand the possibilities.I think there's something out-of-whack with the search function. As I haven't been able to go through all the inspirations, I've been doing searches when I think of new ideas, when I search for "missed call" your inspiration doesn't show up for me...does it show up for you.

Great stuff here, Sarah! Love all the behaviours around missed calls that I notice particularly in Asia. Also thought you might be interested in this: http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/leveraging-missed-calls/ (you can increase your DQ points if you add it the Build Upon section by using the Update button over there on the right of your post)

Mydhili, Justin, thanks very much for the comments.  Mydhili to follow-up on your point, I had the same thought myself about urgency. I saw in one of the inspirations http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/but-what-harms-them a pie chart of the different causes of maternal mortality...I'd be really interested to learn from a doctor or public health specialist about how time sensitive these different events are.One of the things I initially liked was that this idea required minimal/no technical setup - it's just a convention. But I definitely see the merits of a free number - I had 999 / 911 growing up.Interesting point about getting confirmation that help is on the way...I'd thought of this as more connecting you to the midwife/doctor you were already familiar with - but expanding into the more anonymous & traditional emergency services call is a nice build - I'm used to when you are on the line with emergency services they don't hang up until the ambulance arrives. Building in those kind of re-assurances would be good.I'd really like to do a poll in-country of these different ideas, I'm in US at the moment so I'm not sure if I can organize anything, but if people are based somewhere where they can survey folks about this problem, do let me know - just a few questions for feedback.

I think this is a great idea! Leveraging on the fact that it costs nothing to give someone a missed call in countries like India and Pakistan. I especially like the measurement mechanism you are proposing in terms of cost-benefit analysis. I'd think however that mobile operators in these countries have come to terms with this fact because of just the way developing countries have adopted the system. Also like how this addresses the illiteracy issue involved in messaging.Just putting myself in the shoes of the to-be mother and her family during the time when urgent help is required, I would probably wish I had the balance or a toll free number where I could get confirmation that help is on the way as soon as possible. Time is surely a constraint to be able to give 5 missed calls. That said, I think this is a great idea when it comes to seeking advice or help that is not time bound. Perhaps there could be a different number for urgent care?

Simple and strong concept. In England, it normally costs around 50 pence / minute to call a mobile phone from a public phone, but usually it's free to call a public phone from a mobile phone due to the inclusive minutes in a contract. So 'Call-leave a missed call - hang up for money back - and receive an incoming call' method was used on several occasions when I had to contact someone in emergency cases where I didn't have a mobile nor wallet with me.
Nice insight - thanks. I've enjoyed your concepts and comments as I've been wading through all the different concepts - what a lot of great and diverse ideas.

Great idea Sarah!This reminds me of something: in Morocco, one of the mobile operators had this simple idea: when you don't have enough credit, you could still send a pre-defined SMS to any of the numbers of your contact list, asking them to recharge your account for you (it is pretty convenient for example in the case of a mother living in a rural town, asking her son working in the city to send her credit in order to keep calling him).

missed_call_sos_getting_help_when_you_ve.title: Missed Call SOS - Getting help when you've got no credit

visualisation_of_medical_data.description: Your medical chart: it's hard to access, impossible to read -- and full of information that could make you healthier if you just knew how to use it. At TEDMED, Thomas Goetz looks at medical data, making a bold call to redesign it and get more insight from it.
visualisation_of_medical_data.creator: 0144c4a6abd093bd90969d95de047b98

comments.text: The following link contains a TED video (Redesign medical information) by Thomas Goetz. http://historiadelamedicina.wordpress.com/2011/02/16/redisenar-la-informacion-medica-conferencia-ted/

That's right! It could work all over the world, not only in countries mentioned in the challenge. The simplier, the clearer - the better. But for some women it is still a long way before they go to the doctor and get any chart. It could go well with Arjan Tupans inspiration - the first of all the inspirations! ;)

visualisation_of_medical_data.title: Visualisation of medical data

community_micro_funded_baby_booster.description: This concepts seeks to harness a family's (including the father, in-laws, etc.) concern for producing a healthy baby to improve the wellbeing of the unborn child and mother. Through mobile-facilitated group funding, it aims to recruit both financial and social support for the mother’s healthcare needs. And by bundling the financing of important healthcare services with small regular payments for items that people can easily understand and value, it aims to decrease the price tag barrier and thus increase the use of the total package.
community_micro_funded_baby_booster.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Thanks for the support! Also, just found one possibility for what the nutritional supplement could be: http://maternova.net/health-innovations/sprinkles
Great idea Vincent! Very well thought!

Wow Vincent  you're on fire here! I especially like the optional updates feature (eg. "Seera doing well at 28 weeks", "Sera has delivered a healthy baby girl!") to keep folks engaged. Would also possibly drive future contributions if they could see that doing so included them in the loop? Fab mash-up of subscription and resource-matching models!

Great idea about the bracelet Krassimira. I was using a key phrase instead of a code, to make it easier to remember, but a physical reminder may be even better. I could imagine these being bracelets that the mom's could draw/write on themselves (thus it would be personally customized and not require literacy).Also, the contributions would be tied directly to the account/mom associated with the key phrase, sort of like a prepaid insurance/health savings account. Additionally this provides the benefit of creating committed money that's devoted to the health of the mother and baby (it could not be taken away by someone else for other purposes).

another small idea- the key phrase + the phone number could be printed on a bracelet or a necklace that the expecting mom can wear. Thus she doens't have to memorize anything and be able to show to friends/family. This could also encourage other women to join the Baby Booster program.

Vincent, I really like the idea of the involvement of the whole family and the community and connecting this to a kiva-like site- awesome! I'm just wondering- how would the moms get access to the contributions they received from family, friends and the community?

community_micro_funded_baby_booster.title: Community Micro-funded Baby Booster

prenatal_checklist_beta_version.description: Talking with an obstetrician, I began to create a checklist of clinical and laboratory examinations more essential to be completed in the prenatal period.
prenatal_checklist_beta_version.creator: 155a2e9ba2686b27dfccb0ab6b2034ee

comments.text: Tristan, thank you for your contribution. You can be sure that I have followed your posts! They have made me think hard. In my country, the leading cause of death of women is eclampsia, which is related to high blood pressure. So began my quest for the testing methods to predict, especially, high blood pressure. I discovered other important tests, including some that can reduce infections, like laboratory testing of vaginal secretion.So hopefully my post is added to yours, so we can find good solutions in the next phase.Let's keep thinking! There's also the problem of bleeding ... Thanks anyway!

In the spirit of collaboration, I'm going to1.  Take what I think is great about you idea,   2.  Criticise one aspect 3.  Link it to failing in what I have put up. Hope you take this in the right spirit.I think the checklist is really good, but needs some alteration.I just had a post up about what to tackle from the numbers.  Seems during childbirth  is the time and it's bleeding, babies coming out sideways or infection.http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/but-what-harms-them/The other another one saying that we should tackle the low hanging fruit with the most simple solution (singular) possible - this will diffuse wider and has worked for infant mortality.http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/lessons-from-a-successful-intervention-oral-hydration-therapy/The checklist might prove to be this simple solution.So whilst I like the checklist idea I think we should narrow the focus.Checking for every possible thing will prove resource intensive limiting how wide you can implement any interventionIt seems that infection from childbirth is a major issue we can tackle with step by step instructions.  More 'action' checklist.So OUR idea:  A checklist for infection prevention during childbirth.We now need to figure out how phones/telecommunications can help us with this checklist.Thoughts?  Very open to criticism.
That's good, good! Thanks! (I was eager for your contribution...) I've modified the list!Does anyone have any more ideas?

Great list Alessandro  very good coverage! I presume blood grouping would be included in CBC (complete blood count). Thyroid testing would be relevant for women in low-income contexts. Vaginal swabs are important too and a cervical smear if possible. Ultrasound would be desirable at 11 + 18 weeks, if available, to check for foetal abnormality. Before the clinical examination, a detailed medical, family and obstetric history is essential.
Welcome back Alessandro! We're loving your beta attitude : )

prenatal_checklist_beta_version.title: Prenatal checklist (beta version)

midwives_worldwide.description:
Midwifery is the oldest profession of humanity. The midwifery has historically developed valuable techniques that guide its support to women in pregnancy and labor process, overcoming difficulties and preventing circumstances that without help, the woman, the baby or both could die. Nowadays there are many NGOʼs as well as programs in countries all around the world trying to improve maternity health working hand by hand with traditional midwives. International Confederation of midwives (ICM), Nicaragua, Afghanistan, Vietnam and Colombia are some of the most notorious cases.
Two projects are presented, the International Confederation of Midwives and the Home Birth Assistance Guide.
midwives_worldwide.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323
midwives_worldwide.title: Midwives worldwide

extent_the_reach_and_spread_the_message.description: Building a maternity mobile community - this inspiration comes from two mobile products that I have recently learnt about
extent_the_reach_and_spread_the_message.creator: b89daf6dfe9f20380746fc0f23c4bd7f

comments.text: Both really great inspirations Emma. Hoping these  inspire upcoming concepts around connecting health workers, emergency services,mothers, community members, etc!
Nice ideas, and seems to exist with the existing infrastructure.

empowering_communities_to_improve_child_.description:
Child Count+, a platform developed by the Millennium Villages Project (MVP), is designed to empower communities to improve child survival and maternal health. By using SMS, Community Healthcare Workers are able to register patients and report their health status to a centralized dashboard that provides a real-time view of the communities health. The platform also allows for two-way communication between community health workers, and uses algorithms to guide community health workers on patient diagnosis and treatment based on data entered.  

Already, in Sauri, Kenya, Child Count+ is being used by over 100 Community Health Workers to monitor over 9,500 children. These efforts are being expanded across Africa into other MVP sites, and the technology is being continually advanced to better meet community needs. ICT Director, Matt Berg, was recently named one of TIME's 100 Most Influential People in the World.
empowering_communities_to_improve_child_.creator: d1c2fb5cd9198b8a7f8007676bf635be

comments.text: Some great thoughts there Ed! We look forward to seeing some of these manifest in our Concepting Phase.

great concept :) i would extend this idea to be an educational/awareness platform for expectant mothers too. 1) the text push can also send messages about nutrition, healthy behaviors, and other activities the expectant mother can read every day (can be any interval) - not just a reminder for a check up.upon registration, the app/profile would know the age of the mother and the age of the fetus. during key milestones of the baby's development, the mom should visit the health services.  however, in between those checkups, pushed messages about specific nutrition/diet, excercise, dental care, etc. is important - constant reinforcement of positive behaviors2) texting is interactive, so this app/profile could also receive questions from the expectant mother to a queue (monitored by a group of health services professionals).  this would make healthcare more accessible - at her fingertips. she can also text to get an automated profile of her personal progress vs. a standard profile of what a typical mother of her age and situation should be (mother's weight, fetus size, etc.). the questions & answers can be saved in her profile for future analytics.the main challenge i can think of is literacy - i don't know what the adult literacy rate is for any given community. So, this solution is highly dependent on a literate user.
Here's a great list of examples of using SMS to improve children's health:http://www.mobileactive.org/issue-categories/childrens-health
It is a great example. The simpler the better, and there is no need for smart-phones to connect patients and doctors. Thanks for sharing!

empowering_communities_to_improve_child_.title: Empowering communities to improve child survival and maternal health

awareness_and_education_programs_to_buil.description:
In low-income countries, maternal health is not an isolate issue, it can involve: lack of education, self-careless, bad nutrition, poor abilities to communicate and low accessibility to health system. So, the core of the solution could be awareness and education in order that moms-to-be, midwives, health system and the whole community work together to improve their condition. 

This proposal  is kind of wrap-up from different concepts proposed before that can work together and focused on rural areas.
awareness_and_education_programs_to_buil.creator: 916229a8d4ef288e7f4880ad356800aa

comments.text: I thought point 3 (credit to Sara and Tania) was great and something that is happening in some developing countries already in some capacity-  doctors and interns as part of training are required to go into villages to do checkups but also provide supplies and education. They have more of a cultural context also.
Fantastic mash-up Tania! Great to see where the decentralized system had been taken :)

Thanks Meena!Yes Mokeira, I think an ethnographical approach is essential in this case. Every community has different needs and we have to understand them. I believe it is better to work together with people so they can learn how to organize themselves in a more practical way. Of course, as you said, they can sell/buy products from other communities.

Recognition of the need for research to understand the needs of the the local communities is good because often when trying to deliver solutions many fall into the top-down approach trap wanting to dictate what will work best instead of enabling the communities to solve their own problems.  Also tapping into existing rural structures and resources is good like the midwives.  Sustainability is key and I see potential for this as some of the components can be commercialised hence benefit the local community.
Really excited about the mash-ups that are evolving on OpenIDEO  and the visualised concepts. Great stuff Tania!

The tag could be held inside an amulet cover (based on the parent's religious preference) to enhance the protective effect!
This is a fantastic idea!

Nice inspiration Saskia. RFID tags seem like a very efficient & low-cost (especially as RFID prices continue to decrease) way to track and record patients, both in high-volume settings where transcription errors can be common and for emergencies where time is critical.

biolite_stove_have_your_dinner_cooked_an.description:
Smoke from wood fire is one of the WHO’s top 10 threats to human health. In a rural household the traditional method of cooking- a pile of stones heated by an open wood- or cow-dung-burning fire- poses a serious health hazard: indoor air pollution resulting from the burning of biomass fuels is a leading cause of respiratory diseases.  

Who is mostly at risk?- Women and children, as they are more likely to cook or to be confined in the home while cooking is done. India alone accounts for 25 percent of such deaths. 

Additionally, as many in the community, pointed out there is no easy access to charge a mobile phone, unless you walk to the local internet kiosk....
biolite_stove_have_your_dinner_cooked_an.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Great Inspiration Krassimira! Here is another solution for indoor pollution - received '09 index award. Although they didn't have the cell phone charging component.http://www.indexaward.dk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81&Itemid=63

It was good to remind of this matter. The smoke is really one of the biggest killers of women and children. I know that the challenge involves the Nokia, then you thought of a stove powered by the mobile phone battery. Ok! However, there are dozens of models that do not require electricity and are very therefore cheaper, and they are all highly effective in eliminating the smoke.In my opinion, this is the best website on the subject: http://www.bioenergylists.org/
This is a great inspiration. Review the following link (Mobile phone powered with solar energy). http://www.lg.com/uk/mobile-phones/mobile-phones/LG-touch-screen-phones-GD510.jsp
Great find Krassimira!

lifespring_hospitals_a_chain_of_communit.description:
"...it looks pretty dirty here...", "Madam, this place is for the poor peoples." This is what Jacqueline Novogratz, CEO of Acumen Fund, experienced in a public hospital and shared in an interview. 
LifeSpring Hospitals (a joint venture between Acumen Fund and an Indian Government company) are low-cost maternity centers where impoverished women can safely deliver babies. The network of hospitals provides:
- high quality 

- low cost services (a noraml delivery Rs 4000 ~ $80)

- transparent pricing  (which is quite importnat as often women and their families have to bribe doctors to be attended; public hospitals are often corrupt)

LifeSpring Hospitals have also outreach workers who go to the slums and neighboring villages. They find out who are the pregnant women, talk to them about the importance of prenatal care, try to convince them and the mother-in-law to come to the hospital and deliver the baby there.
lifespring_hospitals_a_chain_of_communit.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: agree, Meena! The idea and the execution (from what I read) is great! Hope the can scale and reach out to more women.
Loving the LifeSpring model. Like this, right? http://bit.ly/eZpyed

lifespring_hospitals_a_chain_of_communit.title: LifeSpring Hospitals: a chain of community hospitals that bring maternity care to the working poor in India
