healthcare_through_mobility.description: "Remote villages, coupled with a lack of transportation, isolate patients from the growing availability of health care. Health care is then useless because it does not reach those in need. Without care and education, the disease is rampant, leaving a wake of sorrow, hopelessness, and economic devastation." -- World Bicycle Relief
healthcare_through_mobility.creator: c21692874e7108cf3046ba29b139499d

comments.text: Thanks Radhika. Leveraging an existing program (World Bicycle Relief), in conjunction with our mobile solution, could be very effective in connecting resources to the problem. (It saves some logistical legwork in figuring out how to weave bicycles---a crucial component for any mobile solution---into the picture)
Great solution! It leverages the basic and most common mode of transport in low income countries.

Estudio 6, thanks for the catch. My mistake! And yes, the idea is highly practical. Some of the inspirations on here may offer some ideas regarding the contents of the backpack, like: http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/birth-emergency-kit/http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/non-pneumatic-anti-shock-garment-nasg/http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/condom-device-to-stop-hemorrhage-Jordan thanks for the link for the Copenhagen wheel...I suppose that it would depend on cost. Nonetheless, any tool that can assist the midwives and HCW's in reaching these rural areas should be strongly considered.

Kirk Soderstrom, there's a mistake, the aid backpack concept was developed by estudio 6. It's nice to know that our concept was useful to you! :)http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/the-aid-backpacker

I like the concept quite a lot.  One thing to consider is the terrain in some of these places.  Ii would imagine while some places are flat and relatively easy to traverse, there are others which may be quite hilly or where distances between villages is long.  In the latter scenarios, midwives may have trouble trekking on a nonpower assisted bike, but as you said motorcycles are too expensive.  MIT has created a new bicycle wheel technology, the "Copenhagen Wheel" which stores energy every time the biker brakes, and then utilizes that power in tougher terrain to give an extra boost.  Especially when every minute may count to save a life, that extra boost could be crucial. Check it out at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2009/ratti-copenhagen-1216.html .  Perhaps, World Bicycle Relief could partner up with this project to create a more cost effective, but more powerful bicycle.
Nice one Kirk! I'm a big fan of mobile enterprise in low-income contexts:http://bit.ly/mobile_ent

Thanks Sarah and Vincent.This story is inspiring, regarding World Bicycle Relief: http://worldblog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2007/10/30/4376967-hope-loss-and-bicycles-in-zambiaIt really helped me visualize some of the challenges, and where mobile technologies can fit in...an excellent source for idea generation.
Yes, good thought on how the bike could provide both aid worker transport and power generation for medical tools.
Great mash-up Kirk!

healthcare_through_mobility.title: Healthcare through Mobility

text_for_your_closest_health_worker.description: Send a text to get the location of your closest hospital, healthcare worker, pharmacy. The mobile tower can know your rough location and give you context-based information.

comments.text: Great idea. In my experience of community-based health structures, it is the health worker's responsibility to seek out the pregnant women in need of services, but rarely can the pregnant women identify themselves and request services first.  This puts the power back where it should be, and ensures that no one is overlooked.

This is a great idea. We are trying to create a similar platform using rural BPO's for people living in rural areas to know the details of  nearest hospital, specialty doctors, emergency treatment procedures and more.

Great idea. You asked "What other information would you want to know that is location-based and related to health issues?" If there is any sort of community network such as a mom-to-mom network or some other idea that comes from this overall brainstorm, it seems like that would be great to add to the list. Are there nutrition educators near by? Etc.
Simple, and efficient!

Nice one IDEO London! Really opens up the possibilities of what smart use of mobile location information can do for maternal healthcare. Also quite synergistic with other concepts such as http://bit.ly/gibLXQ , http://bit.ly/fVZSKb , http://bit.ly/fw9efW

This concept came about from a brainstorm we ran in the IDEO London studio. We'll be uploading a number of these ideas over the coming days, so stay tuned. Also run your own brainstorms using our brainstorm-in-a-box kit: http://documents.openideo.net/brainstorm_in_a_box.pdf

openideo_targeted_collaboration_project.description: Let's create a specifically maternal health and targetted collaboration project. Let's work with a handful of communities and bring them on board the collaboration process. Let's create products that the community want.
openideo_targeted_collaboration_project.creator: 85074382e341e8db951d7cd36aa9244a

comments.text: Hi SusanI've been away so only just picked up your comment. Thanks for your thoughts! I like the idea of getting people from different organisations involved on the ground. I think different skill sets and knowledge could really valuable. If the criteria for this was based around asking "will it help to empower the community and can it help bring about different soultions" then I'd say the more the merrier!

Ian,I think that that thinking, ethos and overall concept here is wonderful. My admiration and respect for creating a concept which is more of a project process framework than a finished idea. I think it's great that you involve partners such as Nokia and Skype in contributing to the project through online collaboration, but Im wondering if these organisations could also get out on the ground and join the local project teams? Having someone there with that wider NGO and technical knowledge could be invaluable in be part of what would then become a multi-disciplinary team to create solutions together. I'd still keep the online collaboration element, because I do believe that the expertise, many viewpoints and outsider viewpoint would be crucial to making these solutions even better, and applicable right across the world.In terms of the 5 villages, its great to look for varying geographic factors and cultures, and Im wondering could you add an extra dimensio. Look for villages with different attributes such as rural, remote, urban, nomadic, with/without established telecommunications, with varying literacy levels, etc. I think this would make the outcomes even richer in the long run.Again, my congratulations on a rich and promising concept!

Ian, great question about whether this is separate project or implementation phase of  this or other project.  I think it can work as both but feel real value is in "field testing" assumptions of a project in early phase to bolster and refine project components.I'd also like to add that with an SMS piece in the equation local radio stations and programming may be pulled in to support and promote awareness and involvement.As part of the collaboration process local health workers could visit local radio stations and have on air discussion of maternal health.  During the program a SMS short code could be promoted and listeners encourage to register their phone and send questions to the radio station.  Some of the questions could then be read on air but also questions could be logged to a portal where local, regional, national or international collaborators could review the questions and even send updates directly to the listener using web-to-SMS text messaging.I believe a lot of this collaborative work could be done in an open and transparent manner where mother/listener identity is shielded but their questions and data is openly published and mother could be directly contacted using text messaging.This would reduce the complexity and head ache of administering a more closed system.

I hope no one thinks there was something underhand about me getting one in here. I think that this can be a great way of involving this excellent community in really helping the poorest people  which as a campaigner for Oxfam, thats a really cool thing to think about! A couple of points for refinement, is this a separate project or could it be used in the implementation phase of this project? What do you think? To address some comments below:Crystal  -I definitely would want to do a proper piece of work to identify where we could carry this out. Oxfam does have a global reach and works in all the areas you mention. I think the two things I would want are to have a broad range of different communities and then of course practicality. We'd need the buy in of the Oxfam (and their partner organisations) in country to make this idea work effctively. And that brings me on to Robyn's point - I see this buy in as essential to removing the web as a barrier as the teams who facilitate in country can find creative ways of getting the messages and ideas on to the web (blogs, short films, podcasts etc).Dara - spot on (don't know what more to add)

I think this is a wonderful idea that will also help to build capacity in these areas, something that is often missing from international social change initiatives. I will recommend that you consider an Eastern European country. The usual suspects are African, Asian and Central and South American countries; however, many nations in Eastern Europe/Central Asia are just as in need and just as underdeveloped as their counterparts the other regions. You  may want to pick one country in Central/South America, one in Africa, one in Asia and one in Eastern Europe. I also think it would be interesting to test how this model can work in an environment in which web access is not widespread. How can we build collaborative networking tools/sites with limited technology so that people in rural villages can implement this process and effect positive change? What tools are they currently using for mass communication that can be harnessed for this process?

Essential idea - thanks Ian!One of the things to keep in mind is how to target stakeholders beyond 'the usual suspects.'  My experience working in community development (both in Canada and abroad), suggests that often it is the same voices at the table.  Unfortunately these voices are not always representative of the entire community.Targeting specialized focus groups (e.g. youth, women, religious minorities etc.) may provide a more comfortable and therefore forthcoming environment for initial contributions.  Another factor to consider would be helping various stakeholder groups overcome barriers that would prevent them from participating (e.g. free childcare for mothers).

I'd say one of the key things for this project would be to ensure that internet access isn't a barrier. I've worked to implement a number of eLearning initiatives in Africa-- and the reality is that internet is spotty at best in many cities, not to mention rural areas. Getting out into the community, gathering information, digging deep into the needs of women and families will surely illuminate the needs-- but this shouldn't be dependent on someone's access to the web! I like that there are so many volunteers willing to help below-- perhaps people can help facilitate community-level conversations and then report information back to the group? That being said, there are some online collaboration tools that you could consider using (elluminate is one: http://www.elluminate.com/) that, if people have access to, could help in the development process.

I like that - South Africaa would be a must, Ghana and Kenya too - then you have a West Africa, Southern and Eastern. You could then maybe go for an Asian country like Thailand as a fifth - just to get a seperate one...
Hi Ian, In Africa I am thinking similar countries to Nigeria as far as telecom infrastructure to be Ghana, Kenya and of course So Africa, maybe Tanzania too
Thanks Brian -  what other countries do you think could work as test cases. I my head I'm thinking 5 communities (just because that is a good cross section and manageable)....

Welcome back Ian.  FYI, Nigeria offers number of benefits including cross platform "soup to nuts" test bed that could facilitate tmultiple entry to data, including sms, automated voice service and even web apps in efficient and cost effective manner.  In my opinion you are right it makes excellent choice to push envelope in crowd-sourcing.  Excellent suggestions.

Wow! Just got back from a trip to Nigeria and seen all these comments. feel quite chuffed that the community liked this idea. There are lots of ways that this could work but in Nigeria there was a vibrant community of digital savvy youngsters in the cities. They could be a good way "in" to the more rural areas and help to engage those communities - and even get the ear of the powerful. If that's true for Nigeria then there must be plenty of countries that would be in a position to take part in this.
Yes! It's so important to involve the community. Thanks for pointing this out. Probably most of the communities we are trying to help can't easily access a platform like OpenIDEO.

GREAT IDEAI was recently hugely inspired for the design for change contest in Pakistan, where thousands of school kids came up with and in many cases implemented ideas for social change.  The contest runs in many countries, and goes to show that accumulating hundreds of home grown solutions is possible (although I know it is a huge undertaking for organizing teams).http://www.designforchangecontest.com/Also relates to Krassimira's post on lessons from mHealth http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/lessons-from-m-health-projects-the-tech-is-the-easy-part/
Good Point Ian! A project like this happened in 2009 in Ghana and it will happen again this year: www.iddsummit.org ...
It's also very instructive to just listen to the queries on the Lokarpit Database:http://dsh.cs.washington.edu/info/lv_database.htmlLet me know if you need to translate a specific item from Hindi.

Paul Polak also offers some great advice on this topic. His talk at PopTech: http://www.poptech.org/popcasts/paul_polak__poptech_2007One of my favorite quotes from his book demonstrates a way that we can begin to apply a collaborative posture: "If you havent had good conversations with your eyes open, with at least 25 poor people before you start [designing], don't bother."

And noting the article which Krassimira referenced yesterday from another concept: http://bit.ly/h9uWoP in which MobileActive.org discusses lessons from mHealth projects: "Talk With Beneficiaries From The Beginning: Make sure that your project jives with what the community wants and needs.  Never assume that you know best.... Creating buy-in among local users early on is crucial to the success of an m-Health project, so users need to know that theyre an integral part of the process."
good that you mention that, Sarah! I will be travelling to India in the beginning of April, is there any way I could contribute from there?

I am visiting next week to Morocco, which is certainly not the poorest place in Africa, but I will be visiting the village where my family is from, Ait Ourir (http://bit.ly/gts59p). Despite only having a very basic hospital (that's actually more of a dispensary), most of the people there actually own a mobile phone (with pretty good service). Is there any way I could contribute from there?

This topic is something dear to my heart! As Meena and Haiyan have both articulated, this is a significant aspect to any process where one is designing outside one's own borders/contexts. To add an example to this discussion, I'll include my experience in Rwanda where language and technology were not shared. This supposed "lack" posed an interesting possibility to explore the less obvious ideas that communities may have and yet might not be discovered through our regular conversations. My experience holds one example of how you can be present to those you are "designing for" and turn it into an opportunity to "design with" (a video of a co-design drawing session I engaged with a rural community in order to design the logo for their business: http://vimeo.com/19073511). Because mobile technology wasn't a readily available resource at the time, we looked at solutions that could be helpful for this scenario. In this case, it had to start as a more analog process (drawing/sketching) before we could entertain anything mobile (More on this work here: http://cargocollective.com/karapecknold).I look forward to hear other stories of this kind of application.

Loving the notion of what you're suggesting here Ian  it goes to the heart of the popular Agenda Concept from our i20 Challenge which asked in what ways can we innovate *with, not for* communities: http://bit.ly/dORL6X. This provocation was presented to global innovation leaders at the White House by OpenIDEO earlier this year. I'm sure there will be many ideas from the OpenIDEO team  but like Haiyan... I'm also keen to hear from OpenIDEATORS on how they envison the various ways that this kind of idea could play out.

Ian, great work for thinking outside the box about how a realisation step for this project might take place! Would love to hear from the community about more ideas around prototyping with real villagers, how we might connect and build on ideas together with those affected by the issues we're tackling.
YES! Asking questions, listening and then helping to build capacity is a best practice in community-based work.
Bringing ethnography into use and the end-users makes for greater human centred design

I think this is a great idea!  I would be interested in participating with the group via any communication method mentioned here.  Further, I would be happy to coordinate use of Next2.us SMS solution to solicit direct input from villagers, if one or more villages in Kenya would qualify as appropriate for inclusion.  Villagers could send text message with ideas via local SMS short code that is available through out Kenya.  Likewise anyone in world could communicate directly with villagers (or each other) by using Next2.us mobile interface messaging features.  Messages sent from the mobile UI are delivered as incoming text message in Kenya.  Recipient in Kenya can respond by text message with messaging being routed back to author via the mobile UI.There is no charge to send or receive a message from mobile UI.There is no charge to receive a sms text message in KenyaThere is a small charge of 5 cents to send a text message using SMS in Kenya.  (Hoping next month to reduce this cost to standard messaging rates in Kenya which are currently about 1 cent).The text solution in Kenya is currently being translated into Swahili so Villagers can use Next2.us SMS solution via English or Swahili.Next2.us is currently accessing via SMS in USA and Kenya and via mobile UI -- worldwide.  Its not a mobile app users enter http://m.next2.us in a mobile or computer browser to use the service.Brian PuckettEmail: help@hungrygarden.comLocate or text me at: http://m.next2.us/bripBlog: http://hungrygarden.typepad.comTwitter: @hungrygardenPhone:540.338.3584Skype: next2us
Ian, I think this is a great approach and I believe this a great way we can find out what the real needs are...

An article has just been published on "Improving Maternal Health by Addressing the Intersections Between Mobile Health and Mobile Finance". It's a great read: http://www.undispatch.com/improving-maternal-health-by-addressing-the-intersections-between-mobile-health-and-mobile-finance

natural_helpers.description: Social support and social networks have proven to ameliorate health problems in a variety of neighborhoods and communities around the world. Many public health interventions have used the basis of social support and social network theory to solve complex health problems at the community level. One effective strategy includes finding "natural helpers" in the community, or members embedded in a community that members naturally go to for help. What if we tweaked this a little, and trained young adolescent girls to be the natural helpers? Mobile technology can bring these natural helpers together quickly and connect them to expectant mothers, community health workers, and midwives.
natural_helpers.creator: e49018931fa504c179727f4559713e9a

comments.text: What's the electricity access in these tiny villages?  Anyone know?  Should there be charging stations or cheap portable battery packs avail for free?  How to keep communication devices up and running?  Any problem with care of device?  Wet, sand, dirt impacting workability?  Most live (many live) in relatively open homes. Thoughts? Maybe your idea parallels the Phone Mayor (like 4Square) !

I really like this idea. These adolescent girls are also likely to become mothers, and might benefit a lot from this training, not only as "helpers" per se, but even through their family and community, their sisters, mothers, aunts, nieces and daughters, etc.
Great thoughts Alison! We look forward to hearing more about this idea during our Concepting Phase too.
Community support and empowerment keeps popping up in a lot of inspirations...it seems like it would bra really important aspect orb a maternal health program.

I think this is a great idea!  As the founder of Next2.us, this is exactly the kind of project I built Next2.us to help facilitate.  I could see Natural Helpers being local Next2.us "nodes" in a community to assist expectant mothers in using social network like Next2.us.  The Natural Helper could be trained in how to use Next2.us text match technology.  Their mobile phone could act like a local kiosk in a community where they could send and receive text messages on behalf of community members.  Natural members could also run it as a small business and earn a modest fee from each community member that wants to query the Next2.us text match system.  Natural Helper could include the community member name in the text message so when a match is made they will know for whom the information is intended.  Great idea!Brian PuckettEmail: help@hungrygarden.comLocate or text me at: http://m.next2.us/bripBlog: http://hungrygarden.typepad.comTwitter: @hungrygardenPhone:540.338.3584Skype: next2us

star_shea_network_transforming_lives_in_.description:
The SHEA initiative uses education, technology and mircofinance to improve the incomes and living conditions of women in Northern Ghana, who pick shea nuts and proces them into shea butter.
How is technology helping these women?
Women form village groups and have one group owned mobile phone. They are sent sms via a software tool which enables them to take orders from buyers who want to purchase shea butter. Women also receive information about the current market price of shea nuts/shea butter.
star_shea_network_transforming_lives_in_.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

On another note: I like that this inititiative makes women feel proud of what they do and see a correlation between the effort they put into work and the income they earned. And this gives a sense of dignity, which I think is great.I see a potential of thsi idea for maternity health: poor women/families would be willing to pay an affordable amount, but be guaranteed the survival of their baby as compared to be left unattended in an overcrowded "free" delivery station. the_aid_backpacker.description:
One of the main problems related to maternal health is the lack of healthcare workers in rural areas and therefore inexistence of prenatal control which elevates the risk of complications at giving birth. So what can we do to connect healthcare personnel residing in urban areas with pregnant women in rural ones?

Inspired by Smartphones and their diverse applications we came up with the idea of an aid backpacker; that bring a service that allows having a remote register and prenatal control of pregnant women living in rural areas without medical assistance.
the_aid_backpacker.creator: a4cf0ad4029907e20eadd91838e28323

comments.text: In the state of Bihar, India, the local government started distributing bikes for the girls to go to school. After this initiative started, the % of girls who started going to school increased and now, Bihar, which is the poorest state in India, moved from the bottom of the list. This is a  great way to overcome the problems remote regions are facing. Now, the state of Rajasthan in India, in which >50% of the girls don't go to school starts distribiuting bikes....

Hola, Estudio 6 and congratulations on being selected as an honorable concept to my concept "Free Maternity Camps". Here are some suggestions how to incorporate some of the Aid Backpacker ideas in my concept: 1) the aid backpackers talk to the community to find where pregnant women live. They go door-to-door to personally talk to the women and their family members to convince them to join the free maternity camp. The aid backpackers should have a fairly good idea how many people to expect during such a camp, so that proper place could be found and proper preparation could be done. 2) the aid backpackers help together with midwives and HCWs registering the women during the camp, perform vital size measurements. (In my original concept I suggest using Nokia Data Gathering for collecting the data, you suggest a smart phone app.  3) Once the camp is over (my idea is a one-day camp), the aid backpackers work together with the midwives from the community on the follow-ups- revisits, finding emergencies, notifying midwives for upcoming deliveries in the community. Prerequisite for this concept to work is that the aid backpackers and the midwives are eqiupped with mobiel phones. Please let me know your thoughts....Muchisimas gracias!
We upload a possible project development process (PDF). We would like to know your opinions and comments about it.

@krassimira very well executed concept!!, we also thought about midwives/ hcw as the potential "aid backpackers" but then we realize that there are no enough of them to provide this service and train new ones will rise the cost of it. But either way we would like to see this concept working ;)

I think it's a great idea, which may be extended to other sectors those communities that are affected by disease or other problems and that backpacker can help treat to seek solutions assisted distance

I agree with you that the role of the healthcare workers/midwives is essential...leveraging the network of HCW/midwives could be a solution ot our challenge. Check this concept out and let me know what you think....http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/caregiver-solution-for-midwives/

comments.text: Cheers for swinging by Ken! Very generous inspiration links  to be sure they'll be much appreciated by the whole community.

Hi Christine, Ashley, allGreat to see so many people inspired by the potential of FrontlineSMS here! The software is being increasingly used to power a range of SMS-based projects by non-profits of all sizes around the world. If you're interested in developing something yourself, then I've written a few posts on designing mobile applications and services which might be of help/interest. They can be applied to any kind of mobile project.http://www.kiwanja.net/blog/2010/01/mobile-design-sans-frontieres/http://www.kiwanja.net/blog/2008/11/mobile-applications-development-observations/And there's a short video which sums up most of this, here:http://www.kiwanja.net/blog/2009/06/building-for-mobile-at-the-margins/Best of luck with all of this! KenFounder, FrontlineSMS and kiwanja.net

I'm so glad that you brought up FrontlineSMS, Christine. I had the opportunity to hear from Ken Banks, founder of Kiwanja.net and a key contributor to FrontlineSMS, at a conference about a year ago. Ken's work is fascinating - I hope everyone checks out the site - and it even looks like Nokia (one of this challenge's sponsors) supports him! Small world....

To supplement my applause, I want to call attention to the Haiti Earthquake Relief effort dubbed 'Mission 4636';  SMS is truly the tool for global mobile health, and Frontline SMS served as a pivotal cog in a tremendous endeavor! While an earthquake entails urgent disaster relief, I believe the overall workflow adapts to promoting maternal health in low-income nations.  Check it out! (No affiliation...I was just blown away by Josh Nesbit's presentation about this awesome feat at Stanford Mobile health 2010.)Read: http://www.mission4636.org/history/ Watch: http://www.poptech.org/popcasts/patrick_meier__josh_nesbit_the_haiti_4636_story

I really like this for all the reasons stated. First of all, it doesn't require Internet connection, only simple SMS; second, you can use it on multiple devices; and third, it allows knowledge to be passed around...maybe knowledge collected via FrontlineSMS can be aggregated to an online/offline platform so that Q&A topics related to maternity can be shared, and become collective knowledge. - like the online Quora platform  http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quora
This works very well, since many developing countries have various companies providing service at various signals. Not needing internet is a plus too. Way to go keep people connected :)
That's really interesting and straight away my brain is starting to go "hhhhmmmm" with the possibilities!

Excellent example! One of FrontlineSMS' sister organisations is Medic Mobile (formerly know as FrontlineSMS:Medic), focusing on mHealth solutions (esp. in terms of helping health workers coordinate and/or providing diagnostics from/to the doctors).
internet via sms - love it!

doctors_nurses_on_motorcycles.description:
"The best tools in the world don’t make a bit of difference if they don’t get out to where they’re needed." Nils Daulaire - Former CEO and President, Global Health Council.

This is an amazing solution to dealing with health logistics problem. This organization "Riders for Health" trains health workers (as doctors, nurses etc) to hide and repair motorcycles and four-wheeled vehicles. This assures that health workers have trustful transportation to reach remote areas. 

The health workers are trained to repair each moth their vehicles and it never breakedown.
doctors_nurses_on_motorcycles.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751

comments.text: Taking the idea of uisng a motorcycle one step further is the eRanger Motorcycle Ambulance - It's not just an idea, it's happening now - helping save lives each and every day.Celebrate Solutions: Motorcycle Ambulances for Mothershttp://www.womendeliver.org/updates/entry/celebrate-solutions-motorcycle-ambulances-for-mothe/
Thanks Ian for the information. It's a very important thing to know for how long u can ride without major repairs. This simplifies the job a lot!

Great inspiration Diogo!  Being a dirtbike fanatic I really liked this idea.  No better way to get out to rural areas.  And that honda in the picture is virtually bulletproof!  Besides regular maintenance (oil, air filter), you could ride that thing for years without any major repairs.
Thanks for all your comments. Every new comment gives me more ideas to make more inspirations! :-)

Great inspiration Diogo! The AID village clinic has built an excellent community outreach program using this "Riders for health" service. This is really fascinating!Here is the post:http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/21st-century-healhcare-in-the-midle-of-nowhere- Here is their site:http://www.aidvillageclinics.org/html/OurClinic4.html

Great thoughts here Diogo! I also really liked this related post we had on an earlier challenge: http://bit.ly/gfgjRz Indeed, access is such a big issue on this challenge.

comments.text: I was just mulling over my own question, and thought about how video games can be used to help with scenario building. There was a recent TED Talk about this from  Jane McGonigal. Here is an interview on wired: http://www.wired.com/epicenter/2010/02/jane-mcgonigal/

Thanks for the post. I'd also recommend Paul Polak's Out of Poverty. Although he's focused on farmers, I think his lessons translate across all sectors. http://www.paulpolak.com/html/media_video_8min.htmlI think there's real value in the article that was posted and the research that was done. However, I also think that many of these are common sense. Just because they're common sense doesn't mean they're not worth writing down (Paul's book is also about common sense lessons but is an excellent and though provoking read). The question that springs to mind is how do we turn this into **actionable knowledge**. Having had a project fail myself, when I looked back I realized that everything that I'd done wrong I knew in abstract terms before I started. But that didn't mean that, in the moment, surrounded by the specific problem I could realize that I needed a specific principle now and how to apply those lessons. Does anyone have suggestions, examples of how to help project leaders learn, digest, and apply?From my perspective I know that painful experience is a good teacher. Any more?

Great list of lessons learned.

postnatal_care_package_improved_stove_sa.description: Having your first baby brings about a lot of change. It could be a good opportunity to introduce healthier behaviors. Moms who go get prenatal check-ups will be entered into a lottery to win an improved cook stove and water filter. All moms going to prenatal clinics can buy the stove and filter for a discounted price. The chance for 1 out of 20 moms to win these products for free may encourage moms to seek care from clinicians or midwives when they otherwise may only see them at delivery. Regular check ups before delivery can improve care for mom and baby. The motivation to care for a new baby may encourage mom to treat her family's water and use a smokeless stove.
postnatal_care_package_improved_stove_sa.creator: 986367cab041526c6231636304ad25ce

comments.text: correction* objects not being free is important but discounted, but I guess if its a lottery that makes for less jealousy in the area.

This is great.  This is what I was suggesting for the bone marrow project.  There's nothing people like more than receiving free stuff.  So if you can offer rewards like this for doing good things like prenatal checkups people will be interested even if its not 100% about understanding the medical implications of doing so.  Expand the community buy in!!!!

I think this is a good idea, I would suggest perhaps allowing the needs of the people in question dictate what the incentive is (maybe other incentives might appeal more to certain communities). But good thinking!

Safe water is essential for good health, I think filters could be a good project to develop. Actually, each family should be provided with a water filter. On the other hand, I am wondering how the stoves will work? In some rural areas people do not even have electricity and fuel supplies might be very difficult to get. That's maybe why they still use traditional fire stoves.

make_it_a_game.description: Design a game where community members gain points for actions that help bring healthy babies into the world (with healthy moms). Winners can be designated as community heros and offered mobile phones, minutes or other sponsor-driven incentives.
make_it_a_game.creator: 216c82031847415d58281b8bdca2e273

comments.text: I really like the idea of games.  Games can be quite culturally specific - some people might not know the rules etc - so in further developing games, I would further research games local to that community/culture and see how that might be adapted. Could be traditional games or common games people already drawn to.  Example they might really be into card based games in a location, and that might inspire a form

Yen, I totally agree. That's why it would be helpful to work with locals, after identifying the top behaviors we seek to encourage, to craft games that are a natural draw for people. Thanks for your comment.

I like the general idea of using a game to incentivize behavior change. However, I am concerned that the game might be divisive to the community. For instance, offering an expensive cell phone as a reward could create jealousy and resentment among community residents directed towards the game winner. Is there a way to develop games so that all participants are winners to some degree? Another way of tackling this issue would be to offer rewards that are still considered good and desirable (e.g., cell phone minutes or less expensive baby care items), but not excessively fancy or luxurious (e.g., a smartphone).

I like the general idea of using a game to incentivize behavior change. However, I am concerned that the game might be divisive to the community. For instance, offering an expensive cell phone as a reward could create jealousy and resentment among community residents directed towards the game winner. Is there a way to develop games so that all participants are winners to some degree? Another way of tackling this issue would be to offer rewards that are still considered good and desirable (e.g., cell phone minutes or less expensive baby care items), but not excessively fancy or luxurious (e.g., a smartphone).
Thanks for your feedback and ideas Ian, Marc, Jeff and Laura. I'm working on a more fleshed out idea, and I really appreciate your help. Thanks!!!

I like the incentivisation in this as it makes this concept  a bit different. I do agree with Marc's comments as it is a fine line with rewards between incentivising to take part and denying people things that they need. After all, most people and especially pregnant women do care about their own health.Having said that, I think that this could be improved if you think about the content and key messages that you want to get across through the game. Laura has certainly added some detail to the project idea!

It seems like there are two elements that would strengthen this concept considerably:  1) Address the concern that the reward structure of a game creates too much of an external or extrinsic reward rather than primarily provoking an internal or instrinsic motivation. If people have uneasiness about this idea it will be because it could "make light" of such a serious responsibility or motivate people for the "wrong" reasons (or, possibly, reward those who are already model citizens more than convert others).   2) The broad idea of "game" is compelling but do certain kinds of game playing make more sense than others? Are there certain elements of a game (multi-player collaboration or even competition) using a game asd a device to provoke new learning or internalization of concepts, that are especially important?

From Creative Instigators member Laura:The project you posted caught my attention.  Thanks for postingit.  I needed a brain teaser on a "sick day."I hope that these suggestions help enrich the proposal.  I loveOxfam and would be delighted to contribute in some way withoutthe standard personal check.Sincerely,Laura (Ell) WeinbergThe Oxfam project objective led me to look into:*  what are intervention opportunities*  what are critical factors in maternal prenatal health*  what outcomes are hoped for from interventionThe range of cultures and economic levels that Oxfam mighttarget is vast, so I'm focusing on rural and poor marginally-industrial areas where cell phone subscriptions are scarce.NOTE:  In these areas one cell phone is generally used by many people but passed around, sort of like until the 1950s Americans had "party lines" into their homes.General maternal health is cited as a goal of programs of thistype, particularly when there is not a local source of medicalcare such as a scarcity of doctors, clinics, and even ruralmidwives.  Other risk factors include exposure (narcotics,tobacco, or alcohol), physical abuse, multiple pregnancies(large numbers increase risk), and previous troubles inpregnancy.Education:One game could involve educating women by passing aroundinformation in text messages to groups of cell phone users.Respondents could use some sort of identifying informationabout who has heard the text message.  Messages could go viraland potentially be tracked.  People who started a message wouldadd an identifying tag that used the last few characters of aforwarded message.  Then replies could be tracked.  If yourteam, tribe, village, family, or friends generated the mostreplies, your group could win unlimited texting for a period oftime, for example.  A sample message could read:  No amount ofalcohol is really safe for an unborn baby to drink in thewomb.  Or: When you smoke, the tiny thing inside you is smokingwith you and imagine what that's doing.  Or: Eating dark greenvegetables can help unborn babies be healthier newborns.Rural Health Care:Another game could involve arranging transportation for ruralvillagers to come to more centrally located clinics.  A "ride"service might be arranged, but taking care for safetyconsiderations and mores regarding women traveling alone invarious regions.  If the pregnant woman is tracked as making itto a clinic, from where the health care provider sends a codedtext on his own cell phone to verify the visit, then all thepeople who texted along the way as helping get a reward.Patient Identification:There could be rewards for people/cellphone user groups whohelp the program identify pregnant women and help track themthrough labor to delivery.  This could leverage the user groupsand village dynamics that otherwise might not put as mucheffort into helping a pregnant woman.  Users would be sentperiodic message about what benefits pregnant women and askedto text back responses, such as what the woman needs or how thepregnancy is progressing.  As self-reporting, this programdoesn't lend itself to rewards.Patient Followup:Questions about progress of a patient can be sent to thecellphone that identified her.   Photos and video captured oncellphones is now increasingly possible to use intelemedicine.  If there are issues that may be helped withphotos and the cell phone is enabled for photography, thesender of the photograph of the woman might get several freephoto text messages as a reward or compensation.Mothers Supporting Mothers:Cellphone identification and self-identification of pregnantmothers can be used to help establish support groups - virtualor phone-based.  New mothers or mothers with a history ofproblem pregnancy might benefit most from such support.Who are the different users in this system?* communal/shared cell phone users* cell phone users who are neighbors, friends, coworkers, andof course family of pregnant women* pregnant women and new mothers themselvesWhat are the different moments in the game?* when a woman is first aware of being pregnant* when cell phone users share information about improvingmaternal health in the community or with a specific woman* when pregnant women, or possibly women with prior problempregnancies (putting their next pregnancy in the risky class)who are expecting to become pregnant, find each other anddevelop mutual support* when a pregnant woman is able to enlist help in getting to aclinic* when rewards are issued by cell carriers or NGOs toparticipants

The Harlem Children's Zone could be a great partner here. They've done a lot of research and intervention in communities in NYC to help mothers navigate pregnancy well, ensuring quality of life for both kids and moms. http://www.hcz.org/

Hi Loretta, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of bringing gaming into the mix to motivate others in assisting women during pregnancy.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some thought what these tasks could be. Who would set the tasks and who would award the points?Could the mothers themselves set their own tasks and ask the community to support her?Who are the different users in this system and what are the different moments in the game?When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields: - Concept Builds - Here you can list additional builds on your concept - Virtual Team - Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept. Cheers! OpenIDEO

delivery_care_studed_models_for_public_i.description:
This article has a very interesting information about kinds of approach to decrease the number of maternal mortality on delivery models.
They collected a lot of countries data about their models and their maternal mortality and they concluded some interesting and non trivial things.

Here is the descriptions of the 4 different models analyzed:
"In Model 1, deliveries are conducted at home by a community member who has received brief training. In Model 2, delivery takes place at home but is performed by a professional. In Model 3, delivery is performed by a professional in a basic essential obstetric care facility, and in Model 4 all women give birth in a comprehensive essential obstetric care facility with the help of professionals."
delivery_care_studed_models_for_public_i.creator: ad14a38b87a927eb3dfdf03f24430751

comments.text: No body liked this one? I though that I founded a very strong information about kinds of public strategies to achieve a good health system. May be they are so trivial. It's ok! May be it too big? If is too big I recommend reading it...:-)

free_maternity_camps.description: The idea is to send medical teams from a base hospital to remote areas where moms-to-be will be examined by doctors. The concept of the maternity camps is inspired by Aravind's free eye camps in India.
free_maternity_camps.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: Hi Krassimira - cool concept + congrats! Your shout-out to Aravind caught my eye. Dr. V was a visionary - a charismatic hero who managed to inspire hundreds + hundreds of volunteers to make the eye camps a success. I'd love to hear more about how you envision the leadership in this enterprise. Will there be a core leadership team driving/coordinating the decentralized camps? Will you offer incentives to your community midwives? How will you motivate your volunteers? Keep up the great work!
Hey Krassimira, I like the practicality and feasibility of the concept; it is easy for me to envision, as it does not assume literacy (including technological). Well done.
Thanks, Kirk!

I really like this concept! During my field experience with Soluciones Comunitarias in various locations in Guatemala, when the villagers learned of an upcoming campaign, offering free eye exams and essential products available for purchase, talk flooded through the town. I can just imagine the feedback seen if midwives/ aid backpackers were on their way!  To generate some more income maybe the midwives/aid backpackers could bring a few essential items needed during pregnancy or sanitary items needed at the birth that the villagers could purchase for a reasonable price.  The moms-to-be could pitch in a small amount each to purchase something for the community or use little extra money they have on hand for a personal purchase. Maybe the midwives/aid backpackers could receive these goods through something like Micro-Consignment so they would have little risk as well as want to reach out to as many communities as they can because they could have large potential benefits.  Also, this may inspire moms-to-be that have gone through the program to get educated to become a midwife/ aid backpacker to receive more income for her family and to have the ability to reach out to more women in her community as well as in surrounding communities. To get technology involved (if needed) the aid backpackers could keep track of their product inventory (as this was a hard concept seen also in my field experience) just like how they entered mothers' health data. Instead of sending it to a health center they could send it to where they initially received their products. Just a suggestion but I feel this program could really work and touch the lives of many moms-to-be! Kudos!
Stacy, thanks so much for sharing your experience! This is a great incentive for the aid-backpackers/midwives and could turn into a self sustaining business for them!
Thank you, everyone for the support and the brilliant ideas that shaped the concept and made it much sounder!

Rachel, thanks for the great idea and for sharing your experience! I can imagine a for of incentive for the aid-backpackers as extra airtime...The incentive could be based i.e. on the number of births in the community where the backpackers helped.
Hi Estudio 6, I uploaded the diagram in the concept!

Hi there guys, Great concept! Something that might be interesting for you to consider is working an income-generation aspect into the model. If aid backpackers are paid for the work, the program will be more sustainable and also have positive spill-over effects in the communities in which they operate, since jobs are being created.Since accurate demographic information for the rural poor is often spotty and hard to come by, many international development organizations have a serious interest in finding ways to collect better, more accurate information about the rural poor. The information that the aid backpackers collect could then also be used for development agencies, governments, and the private sector looking to better tailor their services/projects for these populations.A really interesting org that is doing this type of work (in favelas in Rio de Janeiro) is Mobile Metrix (http://www.mobilemetrix.org/). They've gotten contracts from the World Bank and private companies, and have used the funds to train "community mobile agents" from the favelas to use mobile devices to collect demographic info. The mobile agents are paid for their work, and so they are building skills and earning income through the information collection.
Please check the last file uploaded in our concept (To: Free maternity camps concept). The *diagram complements our suggestions.
Please check the last file uploaded in our concept (To: Free maternity camps concept). The scheme complements our suggestions.

Hi Radhika, great ideas! I like the idea of turning this into a game for the boys...I believe this has to be wrapped in sort of a educational/training program for them (they need to learn how to use the mobile, how to capture the data, etc.). I will put some thoughts, too and will update the concept tomorrow! Thanks for your creativity!

Hi Krassimira,I had some additional thoughts that build on the idea of signing up local boys as aid backpackers. I feel it could become a huge motivation for the boys if it was framed as a game for them. Each month new challenges are announced. Each challenge charges them with a particular task in a particular role, for which they compete or collaborate, earn points and are rewarded. Besides that they also benefit from gaining practical experiences in certain areas and fields which could have educational value for them. Mobile phone technologies could be used to participate in challenges and track progress in challenges.For example, in the Scouter Challenge, the boys step into the role of scouters challenged to find as many new pregnant women as they can within a particular area. Benefits - This data can be used to organize Maternity Camps (details as per what Estudio 6 suggested). The boys get an opportunity to plan and strategize on how to find information quickly within the community. It could also be a collaborative challenge in which all the boys within a particular area have to collaborate and work together in order to reach a goal which will earn their community benefits such as extra funds for lunches, baby supplies for new mothers, extra minutes or mobile phones.

Estudio 6, thanks a lot for your feedback! I totally like the idea to remove the data gathering session from the camp and leave it to the aid backpackers before the camp. I believe it will be extremely beneficial as 1) the camp can be better planned as we'll know how many women have registered-better planning for the community and for the base hospital 2) the actual camp will concentrate only on educational session and examination session. I adjusted the flow diagram and I used a pciture from your concept (hope this is OK with you). Thanks a lot!!

Kyle, as we're talking about people who live below the poverty line and have less or no access to health care and many of them don't proactively seek health care, do you think that introducing a fee will motivate the expectant moms and thier families to join the camp? Let me know your thoughts....

Krassimira,I love the idea! Building in some kind of food/nutrition education as Radhika suggests would be a great addition. I would like to push her suggestion to charge a small amount of money a little bit farther. There is evidence in all kinds of development work that free interventions (products and services both) are not valued in the same way as those that must be paid for. Think to examples in your own life: how much of a priority is a free lecture on a subject that interests you versus a talk/conference for which you paid $20 to register? Or a free cup from Jamba Juice versus a plastic cup that you bought from IKEA? For this reason, I think the camps would be more successful if there were a nominal fee charged. Maybe the fee could then be used to incentivized doctors or buy healthy lunches...

Hi Krassimira, Congratulations for being one the finalists, we have been thinking about your ideas on how can the aid backpacker be incorporated to your concept and we came up with the following suggestions.1) The aid backpackers besides talking to the community to find out who is pregnant and going door-to door; open a virtual clinical chart of the pregnant women and convince them and their families to register into the maternal camps.2) The aid backpackers send the files to a base hospital where all the data will be process and classified. this allow them to know in advance not only how many people to expect but who they are and whats their condition. Therefore they could be prepared on how many specialist, health workers, equipments, they will require. This will replace the data gathering session which will lead to an increase of time in the other two sessions.3) In the maternity camp the mothers to be will be attended in the examination session by needs (i.e. risk pregnancies, age, trimester, etc) which will direct to a more efficient medical care and will make the most of all the resources.Hope you find this useful to your concept, we will be more than happy to contribuite more with anything that we can. Keep us posted. Gracias!! :)
Radhika, thansk for the comment. Concept is updated:-)

I think it's a good idea and would work well to collect a small amount from all pregnant women and then use it to buy necessary materials for the lunch!! Another option could be that part financing is obtained through an external program that raises funds from the global community for this purpose. Or possibly a special food fund that all earning members of the local community contribute to on a regular basis to support the nutrition needs of all pregnant women of the community.

Radhika, I was wondering how could we finance the rotating lunchs? Every pregnant woman part of the rotating lunches puts some money and with the collected money the necessary products are purchased. Next time, money is collected again...What do you think? Women who cannot attend the preparation of the lunches as they have to work in the fields, can have it delivered by the aid backpackers.
Radhika, love this idea!

Hi Krassimira,I really like the idea to include an Eat Well Be Well!! session as part of the maternity camp that would educate on healthy food preparation, provide a nutritious meal and engage women from the local community to prepare nutritious meals for pregnant women. One of the challenges I see is that they get to eat a nutritious meal only on that particular day and the rest of the days due to lack of funds or time might revert of old eating habits. One possible way to sustain healthy eating might be to use the free maternity camp as a place to sign up a sub group of women in the local community to continue providing nutritious meals to pregnant women on a daily basis. This sub group could assemble on rotation at the home of one of the pregnant women to prepare food in bulk quantity for all pregnant women in the area. This way the pregnant woman gets to learn and practice hygiene and healthy food prep and the boys of the community recruited as aid backpackers could deliver these lunch boxes to the homes of all the pregnant women in the area.

Hi Radhika, here my proposal for integrating some of your ideas: As part of the educational session, I can imagine a session during the maternity camp called "Eat Well, Be Well". The expecting moms and the family members will be explained what food to prepare (spinach, beans, peas, lentils, eggs, etc.) and why. The local community that helps organising the camp, will engage some women from the community to prepare a nutritious lunch that will be served during that day to the expecting moms. They will be given some tips what to cook and how to cook.Let me know your thoughts. As soon as I have your feedback, I will update the concept.

Im a big fan of the decentralised ideas and getting professionals to where they are needed. With these ideas I do think the trick is making them sustainable? Due to capcity, funding and other such issues. However, I think those are key issues that our conepts can tackle.And as a campaigner I'd love it if the concepts can be worked up so that we can collect info to target government's, leaders and companies to change policies and practices that prevent people accessing the care they need. (that became a bit ranty - sorry!)
Hi Krassmira...congratulations on being one of the top 20 finalists. I'd be happy to collaborate with you to incorporate some of my ideas from the Eat Well Be Well concept:)

@Mokeira: thanks for the ideas and I will re-work the concept to include some of the ideas of the "Eat Well, Be Well" concept!@OpenIDEO: I will definitely go through the concepts and incorporate some of their great features in my concept. Thanks for your support!

This concept could work really well if combined with food hubs (eat well be well concept).  Think of this as an incentive to draw the mothers to actually come for the maternity camp.  Good food and good nutrition is a real need that can give a lot of motivation for people to come. This has been seen to work with school feeding programmes as more children attend school if this is available, even more when the families also get something for allowing their children to go like cooking oil for the mothers.  Maybe there is something here for the dads to motivate them to alloww their wives to go and even to get them to attend!

Hi Krassimira, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of bringing healthcare and knowledge to remote areas. We encourage you to also look at these two concepts and think about how nutrition information and individual healthcare workers could also be a component in this concept:The Aid Backpacker - http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/the-aid-backpacker/Eat Well Be Well! - http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/eat-well-be-well/Thanks for already making use of our new fields: Concept Builds and Virtual Team.Cheers,OpenIDEO

I'm a big fan of street drama-- everyone likes a good street drama :) I don't know if I would eliminate the 10--12 age group, because I think this is a really important group of people to reach. Youth need to have a platform for voicing their concerns, defining issues, and developing solutions as well; and in terms of reproductive health, reaching youth at an early age will promote health and engender communication about somewhat taboo topics. I just think it is a matter of how you frame the concept. Maybe instead of being mom camps, they can be family camps, or youth camps, etc I cant up with a great name, but hopefully my point is coming across! Including other members of the community (men, mothers-in-law, etc) can be helpful for identifying opportunities and barriers, but remember that cultural differences will dictate how these groups interact. It might be good to separate by gender or age, or it may make more sense to bring the entire community together, depending on the context.

Robyn, thanks a lot for your feedback! I think you're bringing great points. I agree with you that the community shall play an essential role in such maternity camps. Based on your feedback, I'm wondering if the maternity camps would be the right forum for involving girls aged 10-12....maybe not....so, I adjsuted the concept.I think the educational session where not only moms-to-be, but mothers-in-law and possibly husbands participate, could address some of the cultural issues, marginalization, family planning and reproductive health. The puppet show/performance could reinforce some of these issues. Let me know your thoughts.

Hey Krassimira, I really like the general idea of your concept, but I would be careful about your language, especially given your various target audiences. It concerns me that 10-12 year olds would be put in a "mom-to-be" camp as I fear it may imply that their worth is based on their ability to have children (which is often the case in many communities). I'm guessing you would include more than just health messaging about being a mother (i.e. reproductive health, family planning, etc...), so I think the concept is still a good one, but I'd like to see it framed in a different way to take into account social norms, cultural barriers, stigma, power imbalances, and the marginalization of women. One way to mitigate these issues would to make sure that you use community-based participatory approaches (such as community engagement and mobilization strategies) to build awareness, define the issues, and create educational content.
I really like that this concept is adopting the popular art idea. Great job Krassimira!

Kirk, I really believe that once youopne the horizon of young boys and girls, who are smart, enthusiastic and eager to explore the world, great things can happen. Having two target groups, point taken- you're absolutely right!...I adjusted the concept to reflect this. Thanks for the input!:-)

It is funny that you mention that... one of the more moving stories that I read quoted a young boy who, after learning about the world beyond his own through a mobile device, declared that he wanted to become a doctor!I found that dividing women into 2 groups (young girls and women of child-bearing age) helps me think about the approach more holistically, from a long-term perspective. I'm afraid that if a proposal only addresses women who are currently pregnant, the pattern will continue.

Kirk, I like how you addressed the two different issues in your concept- 1) the education of the young girls and 2) the mortality related problems. I think you're right- it is so important to involve young girls and teach them early enough about pregnancy, birth control, etc.  I think this might turn to be a challenging task in some communities around the world. Young girls, members of the community could attend the maternity camps and learn. I can even imagine some of them saying " I want to become a doctor and save lives."

(The following comment is simply a suggestion of how mobile technologies can be embedded in maternity camps, coming from a slightly different angle. I hope this is okay!) The other day I did some research on a program called "one laptop per child" (OLPC) and posted some observations on http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/one-laptop-per-child-wisdom-from-a-precedent-study/   It was not until after I read about the OLPC program that I perceived the wisdom of maternal camps... and then thought about how mobile technology could enhance such a program.I wish there was a way to evangelize the lessons from the OLPC program; there are so many. Perhaps the main take away is the profound impact that a simple mobile device can have on young children in the poorest, most remote regions of the world. This educational program has literally shaped the future of these countries.Also, it made me wonder if these camps could or should target young girls who are not yet moms? Shaping young minds through education would likely alter both the deeply embedded cultural cycles and life decisions.

Tristan, good point. The concept for the free maternity camps is based on the Aravind's free eye camps in India, that seem quite efficient.Some statistics:- 22,000 obsetricians for 27 million births in India, which makes 1 obstetrician for 1,200 births (Source: http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/87/12/08-060228/en/)- 1 ophthalmologist per 100,000 people in India (Source: http://archopht.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/extract/118/10/1431)If Aravind's eye clinic can make these camps with much lower number of specialsts, why couldn't maternal hopsitals do this?For this concept to work, I think this will be crucial to work with private hospitals, who are dedicated and start the camps with specialsist from there (i.e. Lifespring hospitals).Additionally, in Aravind's camps most of the preparation work is done by nurses, who optimize doctors' or surgeons' time. In our case that could be health care workers and midwives, who do most of the data gathering and follow ups. Every year Aravind's clinics recruit 100 girls from villages who are educated for most of the routine patients' exams; this has a huge impact and seems a scalable solution.

This idea takes the reverse approach of mine: high cost but hight effectiveness per mother.  Clearly it's well thought out. But I do like to improve on ideas by pointing to the tough questions.  Any idea how you'll get enough doctors involved?  Seems a key issue that I'm not sure you can solve.However, I think you take both our ideas and wack them together, you'd get a better outcome.  Maybe have a look and tell me what you think.

Sarah, thanks for the brilliant add-on! The small non-financial incentives turned out to almost double the number of immunized kids and reduce the cost per immunized kid...I will definitely update my concept with a similar idea!

Great idea, love the Groupon addition. This JPAL study also showed that "small, non-financial incentives" can greatly enhance, in this case immunization rates, but perhaps the same would apply for your maternity camps: http://www.povertyactionlab.org/evaluation/improving-immunization-rates-through-regular-camps-and-incentives-india
thanks, Meena:-)
Fab discussion guys! And hat-tip on the comprehensive thinking Krassimira.

Haiyan, Vincent, great idea! I'm tinking the HCW/midwives could play an important role signing up moms and contacting the base hospital to organise a date for a camp. Additionally, as the midwives/HCWs have mobile phones, and are linked in a network, they could inform HCWs even in different part of the country via sms about such camps.

Groupon spin...I love that add! Interested moms will naturally seek out and persuade other moms in their community to attend, spreading out awareness of and participation in these camps exponentially.

Great idea Krassimira.I can also imagine this adopting a Groupon model, where mothers-to-be can petition for the Maternity Camp to come to their local area. Once enough mothers are signed up, the camp will put them on the list of destinations.

comments.text: Folate is of course present in some foods - leafy greens, egg yolks, legumes and some seeds. Does not have to be fortified foods :) Also many fruits contain folate..but perhaps not in large quantities? Dietary advice could be part of a solution for disseminating information to mothers-to-be.

Folic acid (Folate) to expectant mothers in an effort to reduce chances of spina bifida, a neural tube defect, in babies. Most studies show ~ 70% reduction in spina bifida when women take ~400 micrograms of folic acid daily during pregnancy.
The essential micro-nutrients could be delivered via yogurt for Moms in Grameen Danone fashion.

Great point about the importance of certain nutrients for maternal health. I wonder what delivery mechanisms (fortified food/drink, mobile prompts?) could make it easy or automatic for pregnant women to get their iron and folic acid.

groupme_micro_health_networks.description: GroupMe is a mobile app and service that allows individuals to group together by using a generated cell phone number as a central hub to which members in the "group" can send texts. In turn, when one person sends a text, it goes to all subscribed group members. It's in the US, and has been growing fast. You can create all sorts of groups. It's simple, straight forward and works on any type of phone. I have several groups. For example, I have a group with co-workers (we use it to communicate about last minute announcements, get opinions on ideas, coordinate meetings, etc.); I have another group with just my neighborhood family and friends so we can quickly coordinate lunch, or let people know bits of information/news.
groupme_micro_health_networks.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: Wow, this is great Sina - definitely repost this in the Concepting Phase.
TJ: groupme works with simple SMS - no app needed! Can't wait until concept stage; I think this is totally doable as a pilot!

This is fantastic.  I think it is important to note that the solution cannot be APP driven.  In other words, anything driven by simple SMS will have a huge benefit in the next rounds for both affordability and accessibility of the technology.  Smartphones are much less accessible in a third world environment.   Your idea does a nice job of leveraging social networking which (as we see here on openIDEO) can be a very powerful and efficient way to communicate.  We need to be careful that moms receive the RIGHT information though!  (groups monitored by health care professionals)
Great! And it's free! When we get to the concepting stage, it'll be interesting to think about what makes sense for various communications needs: community vs. one on one, remote vs. in-person, etc.
Nice one Sina! Although, as you mention, we're only in the Inspiration Phase  we think this sparks ideas for a range of concepts in the next round. And we're loving your mocked-up graphic!
