comments.text: Thanks Brian for your comment! I am not sure I understood the question well, I am guessing you're talking about a very specific point, which is data entry of medical information.  The idea is that the local health worker inputs directly to the mobile (not transferred from paper).  Once the data is entered, I am imagining a tracking/data collecting system where the information is consolidated while also maintaining privacy (still some issues around the feasibility of this). This data collection could help reduce errors in transmission of information by cross-referencing and double-checking the input with the history already available.I am not sure I responded to your interrogations, but I do agree with what I think is your main point: the best systems will leverage data entry to improve the entire operation.

I like the approach but I have a hard time understanding the actual data architecture design for such as system.  It appears you have number of populations that need to access data (ie regional and local doctors and nurses not to mention village helpers and mothers) but where are the actual entry points were data is inputted into the network and then how is that data intelligently routed to various users, keeping in mind respect for privacy, if any.Typically, best system optimizes data entry as it plays such significant role in error checking and directly impacts useful/uselessness quotient.  Typically, less data entry closer to source is best; but, in this situation is it technically feasible and at what cost?So it is matter getting the data and intelligently routing cross users either by a) need access to do job or provide service or b) provide value added analysis which then raising questions or who needs to uses analysis and in what form is it delivered.

Here is an example of a "bike ambulance", designed by one of our OpenIDEATORS, Jessica: http://cadlab6.mit.edu/bike.ambulance/index.htmlFrom what I understood, it looks pretty simple and efficient, and can be locally produced from common steel and bicycle components.

Hi Alan,Welcome on board!I think you can find many answers to your questions in one of Tristan's earlier inspirations: http://bit.ly/egkCsR The graph is pretty self explanatory, and the links are really useful!

Hi, I'm am just getting started with this challenge.  I have yet to completely review the content on this site, but do we have answers as to:1.  Why is it that 1,000 women die every day in pregnancy and childbirth  adding up to more than 350,000 deaths each year?  Aside from the mothers/ parents having lack of information to take care of themselves, what are the actual medical reasons for the death?  In the brief it is implied that over 90% are preventable.  So are the medical causes of death related to poor nutrition or etc.?It would be great if someone can comment on this.Thanks,Alan

Sarah, thanks for sharing the article! Regarding 1a) I beleive there are technologies which are locally made and can be implemented for as low as 1500 USD . As far as 2b) goes, this is a fantastic point and I beleive there is a great potential in this idea.  I tried to address these two in a concept that I rencently posted- http://bit.ly/hZ49OH

This is a recently published article about a case in India where telemedicine clinics were taken to scale: http://www.nextbillion.net/blog/2011/03/04/technology-to-the-people-There are two big challenges as far as taking this model to scale is concerned:1. Gathering sufficient capital investments to acquire the technology needed, esp. because tariffs are high on imported technology. This could go in favor of: A. a model where technology is locally made/assembled, and/or B. where connectivity is key, as economies of scale can be more effective.2. Sufficient volumes of revenue, that could be achieved: A. with government support for expanding infrastructure (although this doesn't converge with Albert's opinion), B. by creating bundled shared services that utilize the same infrastructure (esp. with boosting revenues services like dental services, dermatolog, etc.).
Wow, thank you Albert for the valuable insights. I very much like the idea of tapping from the community resources. Thank you so much for sharing your experience!

Sarah, I am very impressed with your concept. I have unfortunately become a bit cynical after working in the rural clinics in South Africa, and although I find some of the concepts compelling and brilliant, your concept of organizational decentralization is definitely a fundamental issue when it comes to implementation of any idea. Considerations of inevitable complexities, without over-complicating an already difficult matter, requires great wisdom. I'm also excited, because this concepts forms a great umbrella / network under which any of the other concepts can be better utilized and distributed. Well done!I've only worked in South Africa's governmental system in the rural community, and based only on my personal experience, I'd suggest a way to avoid governmental obstacles as far as possible, one could consider 1) piloting the project through a privately funded NGO.2) tapping from the resources of the community: who will be much more motivated to make the concept succeed than government-employees. (Employing mothers, training up local men to do the motorcycling, etc.)3) Stringent control and methods to keep motivation and morale high in the bigger, city-hub.@ the other comments: My personal, biggest frustration in our setup, was mostly ADMINISTRATIVE. Funding, stock-outs, etc. was - in my opinion - mostly secondary to decentralization of administration, in stead of decentralization of resources.Centralize administration, decentralize resources.

This is a key part of the challenge! Having worked most directly in Rwanda with CHWs/Nutrition Desks and attempting to navigate all related sectors, I appreciate the systems approach here, Sarah. It is complex but a needed investigation (and holds much possibility for solutions that include mobile tools). Getting government on board will be key (and may vary in each location), but I believe it is possible. In Rwanda, CHWs are being given phones, which demonstrates that a systems approach can be pursued through this particular technology!
I think my idea fits into your idea! Nice!

Thanks Ian and Vincent for this very interesting conversation.  I am thinking that having community workers located at the very bottom level could help a lot in forecasting how many medicines will be needed in each area. Mobile technology could help a lot in terms of collecting, grouping and gathering all these little pieces of information and ensuring they are up-to-date. It could also enable a "history" tracking system that, if made public, will allow citizens to held health care systems accountable for their supply chain / distribution management.

@vincent - that'a really interesting question. The cop-out answer is that all the things that you highlight play a role in this. Have a look at this website for a bit more about how the supply chain in developing countries is vulnerable to stock outs: http://stopstockouts.org/stop-stock-outs-campaign/what-are-stock-outs/The focus of the campaign in Malawi was on ensuring that the government was committed to providing the funds so that local public clinics could afford the medecine's. However, using their power to sort out the supply chains was also an important ask.therefore, how could this data help to demonstrate where there are blockages in supply chains or distribution and is there a way to make sure that citizen's can use this info to demand their rights?

Thanks for bringing up the stock outs issue Ian. From your experience, what would you see as the key causes of this that we should focus on addressing: inadequate funds, central supply shortage, inaccurate forecasting, low buffer margin, inefficient distribution, poor local record-keeping, slow communication, something else?

I love this idea. Is there more that we can get out of it. For instance, last year Oxfam took part in a "Stop the Stock outs" campaign in Malawi - where running out of drugs in health centre's became a major election issue. How could the information that would be passed around in this idea be used to provide practical solutions to things like stock outs, recurring illnesses in areas etc?

Thanks everyone! Vincent, I definitely agree that the roadmap is highly sensitive to the context, the regulatory framework (in the Health care sector, as well as labour laws, etc.), the "technical" environment (availability of mobile technologies and certain of these affordable tools). It's a very complex system, but mobile technology could intervene as a facilitator at many levels (health care financing, human resources, etc.).
Love this concept Sarah!

Excellent Sarah! You've created a strong systems framework, drawing together many inspirations. Agreed about the importance of a roadmap Haiyan, or even several roadmaps, as this may develop differently depending on what maternal healthcare infrastructure currently exists.
Great stuff Sarah  after seeing how you rocked the house in the Inspiration Phase, it's fab to see you dive in straight off the bat for the Concepting Phase!
Thanks Halyan! I agree with your idea on the implementation, and a roadmap is much needed indeed.
Love your sketches too :)

Sarah, what great systems and service thinking! Kudos for tackling the broader healthcare system.I would love to see a roadmap for how governments could implement this, as it might be key to convincing them to buy into the bigger network. Perhaps there can be some initial trials with elements of the system, followed by a holistic adoption.

decentralized_mobile_health_care_system.title: Decentralized mobile health care system

mobile_banking_for_women_s_association_m.description: Building on the concept of the "village phone lady" and the growth of micro-insurance in the field of micro-finance, I propose a micro-insurance program focused on maternal health. Woman can form an association and pool their savings in order to create a cooperative savings/micro insurance scheme that they can all call on collectively as need arises.
mobile_banking_for_women_s_association_m.creator: 4f108661da113ee32ab34e5608b0d72e

comments.text: M-PESA is an innovative mobile transfer solution that enables customers to transfer money - http://www.safaricom.co.ke/index.php?id=250Thought it would be worth checking out in relation to this concept.

Nice idea! Building on the example Meena posted about slums in Mumbai, I think mobile technologies would help greatly in making information transparent about how much money is available in the emergency fund at any given time with real time updates via sms.

RE: VincentThe Association would likely be formed as a cooperative, with the members have equal ownership of the entity. The disbursement of funds would be democratic, with guidelines laid out in a charter (eg all cesarian section operations are covered).

Nice one Galen! Certainly lots of room to mash up micro-finance and community building. I've covered a particularly resilient example from the slums of Mumbai here that you might find interesting: http://www.randomspecific.com/women-together-incentivising-savings

With respect to banking and mobile technology for low-income segments of the population, you may want to look at what Banco Itau did in Brazil, and browse through this article: http://www.uncdf.org/english/microfinance/pubs/newsletter/pages/jan_2005/news_Mauricio.php One of the key challenges is providing proof of income, particularly since women have limited rights in Zambia. I think the idea has a lot of potential, as it addresses a number of challenges.Perhaps governments, NGO's and/or even companies like NOKIA (through a program like "cause marketing," a concept I developed on here) could guarantee enough collateral to propel this credit market by reducing risk exposure to both parties? Not sure if this model has been tested before but I'll check into it.
Interesting concept Galen. Could you explain a little more about the process for deciding/controlling when funds are withdrawn?

mobile_banking_for_women_s_association_m.title: Mobile Banking for Women's Association Micro-Insurance

sim_card_library_.description:
Sim card which has essential information pre-installed as contacts and text messages, turning a mobile phone into a learning device. 

Universal fit to most of the existing mobile phones regardless of their brand and age.
sim_card_library_.creator: 5cc82464bdb542c1a936d824806ed1b6

comments.text: Hi Justin. Thought you might be interested in Medic Mobile starting to make SIM apps: http://groups.google.com/group/ict4chw/browse_thread/thread/e56295ddce917c45

SIM cards can programe phones as well. this could be applied to our concept "NON-VULNERABLE SEASON" in order to give recognition to mothers and let them know they are in our programme, as a tangible object to them.we are now actually looking for communication channels on our project (audio, visuals) and would appreciate your collaboration  as part of our virtual team :)looking forward to read your ideas :D brilliant work by the way !
ideas like this are fantastic. i think in combination with "donate your old cell phone" this would be a powerful punch!

Great idea Justin, and interesting comments all. I like this idea because it enables education that is private. The SIM card can be inserted, reviewed by a user and then easily stored out of sight if the user is in an environment where sexual and reproductive health education is discouraged or accompanied by stigmatization. Also, unlike radio and television, this enables the user to access the information when the time is right for him or her to do so.
Krassimira, that is a great idea, and it will definitely save sim cards from being lost or stolen. thanks for providing very valid cultural input

Justin, I was thinking we can offer an amulet on a cotton or silver chain that looks like a jewellery piece. The sim card could be stored safely in the amulet and as it will be always on the mom-to-be's neck, the chance of it getting lost/stolen is getting reduced. In many countries like India and Bangladesh women carry their jewellery most of the time on them. Your thoughts?

This idea was solely born from reading other's contributions, so thanks to you all, open ideaers.Virada /  I agree with you that this concept has potential to be used in other fields.  I'm also thinking that this SIM card could be inserted onto any finished / not-used-any-more / unwanted old phones and turning them into once again useful 'information provider' or 'learning device' in certain communities. Sarah / your and your husbands's input regarding 'sim card copier' made this concept more viable. Also, micro SD for little bit more pricey model makes a total sense, Thanks!Meena / thanks for encouragement, Many of your wonderful contributions to open ideo inspire many, including myself.Lalli and Farah / you brought up issues where this concept should be developed into, in terms of who's in charge(authority) and technology issue. thanks!Marie / Thanks for encouragement!

what i love about this concept is that the knowledge is still accessible in the event the network or signals might not be the most reliable in remote or rural settings. in the very least, the community health worker would have a device, if one cannot be provided per household. the use of a SIM for data storage other than contacts has immense potential in more areas than health care. nice justin!

Was juts telling my husband about this and he had a good point - you can now buy sim card copiers really cheaply (just google/ebay "sim card copier") - just adding to the fact that this would be really cheap to implement and disseminate - love it!
Should we just call you Justin-the-genius?? Loving this idea for it's simplicity yet far reaching potential impact!

What a great idea! I love the fact that this will work on all and any phones. There maybe a possibility to extend to also having microSD cards with pictures, audio, video on - this would work on nokia's costing ~$70 up e.g. nokia 2700c - so maybe for midwife's or people who are being issued phones - probably not for most people. Once again, absolutely love this - ingeniously simple!

This is a great idea, Justin. It's fairly easy to use and implement. There may need to be some sort of index or instructions of when to follow the instructions and a critical period during which a mother should borrow the SIM card, e.g pregnancy between 1-3 months.
This is a really awesome idea - and so scalable.  Kudos!

Hello Justin, these phones do support the major Indian languages. I've used the Hindi and Kannada ones in India. I just wish there was some way to have an audio library instead of text only. Problem is literacy rates. Also an audio library on a speaker phone setting would allow a group of people to listen to info too.

Hello Farah, Krassimira and Vincent, thanks for your feedbacks.Farah : You are correct, the display on basic phones are very small, especially when compared with screens of modern smart phones. However, they are still big enough to display standard 160 characters, and information could be divided into several message, or in the form of MMS (possibly with some basic images as well) which then can be scrolled down. Also, I found a link of basic Nokia 1100 which is used in India. It says it supports Hindi and Pilipino, and the size of fonts seems quite big. Please see the link below.http://www.flickr.com/photos/65729589@N00/237769865Krassimira : Very valid point, and I love your concept of cloudphone and Movirtu. I especially liked the idea that expectant mums could gain extra income by doing something beneficial to the society as they would need extra fund during and after their pregnancy. The size of SIM card makes it easy to be shipped,but rather vulnerable against being lost or stolen as you mentioned. One of the options to raise self responsibility to look after the card is to introduce some form of deposit system.(doesn't have to be money, but anything that a person could afford according to their environment) In this way, the users will feel more 'ownership' to the cards than if they were distributed for free, just like the Grameen bank. Thanks for bringing up the issue.Vinvent : Thanks for summing up nicely!
Hi Justin, I like the idea. The one concern I have is the tiny display of those basic phones can make reading a lot of info a bit tedious. What do you think?

Justin, this is a great idea! The sim card could definitely serve as educational library. One potential danger that I see with sim cards that they can be lost and/or stolen easily. Very often families share one phone, so an expectant mom might need to borrow her husband's phone or a neighbour's phone or go to the village operator to borrow a phone and insert the sim card. I came across a company, called Movirtu (http://www.movirtu.com/), which addresses the sim card issues and introduces the concept of a "cloudphone". I posted a concept trying to leverage the idea of the cloudphone- http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/i-will-call-you-from-the-cloud/.Let me know your thoughts.

Great idea Justin! By providing a standard, widely-compatible, pre-loaded information package, you minimize the cost of over the air transfers, while also reaching areas where wireless coverage may be nonexistent or unreliable.

micro_health_insurance.creator: e42683996625a90919063543481b8f3b

comments.text: @Meena - speaking to people, I've also heard the same - anecdotes of folks coming back at the end of the year who didn't get sick and asking for their insurance premium back. In my experience in Pakistan, people love mobile addons from free jokes to religious passages. If they're relatively cheap for the mobile carrier to provide. Perhaps they can be donated by a mobile carrier if a user subscribes to health insurance. Lots of practical challenges with this idea - who owns the phone etc. - just a thought.

This is actually in lock-step with some practices already embedded in many African communities. I've heard it referred to as a dolo (I think that's right) and it is highly effective because of the commitment to the community and the high value placed on respect and standing in one's community. To merge this with the new technology available on smartphones where you can wave your phone across a POS and money is deducted from your bank/credit union account automatically. There is another concept for this challenge that involves donations being sent via SMS, called Make A Gift, Send A Smile, which is also in line with your health care vouchers concept. Perhaps there're connections?

And I wonder what incentives could be added-on to this to motivate sign-up. An issue I've found in the field  mainly research in slums at Mumbai's Dharavi: http://bit.ly/dharavi  is that folks can be unresponsive to initiatives which don't have immediate upsides. As one can imagine in the contexts of poverty  living day to day is often a reality. What could be added here to motivate people to insure themselves? Would love to see exploration of how this could be mashed-up into other concepts/inspirations... anyone got thoughts? Brainstorm away!

when_you_don_t_know_who_to_ask_i_d_ask_m.description: Having a baby is the biggest step I ever took.  After I was good and committed I had a lot of questions that I just knew my mother was not equipped to answer in a modern day fashion....Luckily for me I had a neighbor, Mary,  who had gone through pregnancy three times in five years and was having her third child simultaneously with me..... Number one she made it so much less scary secondly, she was a confident and confidential source of advice for me when I had a real concern.

comments.text: Will be great to see how this concept might be built on by others to explore how it would integrate with input by doctors & community health workers. Nice one Vibhu.
Haiyan,Thanks for your comments.It can be accomplished through an old phone also,touch on the screen can be replaced with a pressing of any key.-- vibhu

It is possible, Haiyan. Imagine that a mother could send an SMS to a number by adding after the time of contraction, for example, 0800 1230 (time of contraction: 12:30 pm) 0800 1430 (14:30) etc ... The mobile operator could also simply tell the exact time at which the SMS was sent ...This SMS would be received by a computer program that could automatically assess the condition of the mother and calculate an expected time for delivery.
Love this idea. Could become a series of lo-fi mobile apps that measure kicks and even contractions. Would be great to see what we can do on an old phone without the rich interface of the iPhone.

comments.text: Hey Sarah  perhaps you might post all 4 separately (if you can spare the time)  and have them build onto this post so folks can refer back? You can always add a link pointing them back as well if you like. So much great stuff here  we'd love to see others spark off the various ideas you've raised... which they may do with more gusto on specific posts. Just a thought  proceed as you think's best!
Sarah, thanks a bunch for the note and for the links!

Thank you guys!Krassimira, from the point of view of the user, first you need to open a "bank" account (or an electronic wallet, depending on the business model -bank-led or non bank-led), the customer goes to a bank branch or an agent accredited by the bank/the MNO where he/she is properly identified as required by law. He/she fills out a form, where she supplies her name, address, and mobile phone number, and she presents an acceptable form of identification. Or, if he/she already has a bank account, he/she can register for mobile banking through a mobile phone by sending a text message to a particular number. Once the account is opened, the bank/MNO transmits the mobile banking application wirelessly to the customers phone. Now the customer registers her phone number and selects her personal identification number (PIN). She finds the mobile banking application, which will appear on the main menu of her phone. Again, it depends on the business model, you can find a lot more information in CGAP's publications, especially: http://bit.ly/aPAjSu and http://bit.ly/h0vz9H.Meena, how should I proceed? Should I update this concept into one of the 4 ideas, then add the 3 others?
Comprehensive Sarah! Would be fab to see some of these posted as individual concepts so that together we might start to tease out what opportunities, add-ons, builds, etc exist around each.
Sarah, wonderful compilation! As most of the people in the rural areas don't have a bank account- how exaclty mBanking would work? Does the mobile phone require a special application?

Based on what is available locally, the list can tell mothers what to produce to buy to support their nutrition needs at different stages of pregnancy. Mobile messages can provide latest info based on location and time-of-year.

comments.text: I agree with Dianna - the local cultural adaptation of this concept is really strong. Mechanisms to gather the information could be done through SMS surveys - What do other women do to keep themselves and their babies healthy? What has worked well? What hasnt? - and collected into a central database. Furthermore, any work that's being done by NGOs or other grassroots groups to bring nutritionally enhanced products or food into the area can be added to the database.

I think this is one of the best ideas presented in the challenge.  It's simple, straightforward, and combines the expertise of each of the partners involved.  This concept could also include brief messages on why certain foods are so good for fetal health to help encourage moms to adopt the suggestions.

I love this idea. I think in addition to nutrition there could be tips on sanitation. A huge number of infant deaths are due to improper sanitation - using water tainted with sewage, not washing hands, etc. These things are easy to teach, but need to be repeated until they catch hold.

I like the simplicity of this concept!  I wonder if it could be combined with a monthly 'community kitchen' event where women meet up to learn a new recipe.  This would also provide an opportunity for pregnant women to connect and share resources, thereby adding an opportunity to build social capital.

This is actually the combination of 2 people's ideas from the brainstorm: James (http://openideo.com/profiles/james/) & Graeme (http://openideo.com/profiles/underscore/)We built their ideas into one!
This is brilliant James! (and fellow IDEO brainstormers ;^)I like the local aspect which would totally raise the relevance of messages.
I really like this one...simple...but could have a strong impact on nutrition.  Well done!

3_year_health_insurance_for_3_million_pe.description: Dr. Devi Shetty, who was Mother Teresa's cardiac surgeon, worked with the government of Karnataka, India to develop a health insurance for poor farmers that only costs them $3/year. ~3 million people are covered by this insurance. This model is enabled through high volume that drives economies of scale/high utilization/bulk purchasing (his hospital charges an average of ~$2K for open-heart surgery vs. $20K-$100K in the US), a large risk pool, need-based pricing to subsidize poorer patients, specialization (a surgeon gains experience focusing on a particular procedure, thus actually increasing both efficiency and quality: for example, even before adjusting for the greater risk factors, the 30-day mortality rate on coronary artery bypass graft surgery at his hospital is only 1.4% vs. 1.9% in the US), telemedicine, etc. In fact, the cost & quality is so attractive, that medical tourists from around the world are coming to receive treatment at his hospital, which achieve a sustainable profit margin.
3_year_health_insurance_for_3_million_pe.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Vincent, I came across the story about LifeSpring Hospitals that are trying to introduce a model that wil serve those who cannot afford even modest charges:http://abcnews.go.com/Health/lifespring-hospitals-bringing-maternity-care-poor-mothers-india/story?id=12459083&page=1Maybe the low-cost insurance could be a possible solution?
Dr. Shetty addresses a major problem and his vision about having a health center with thousands of bed is simply mindboggling
Scale is definitely one of the key success metrics in my opinion as far as reaching low-income populations is concerned. This sounds like an interesting example to look further into!

3_year_health_insurance_for_3_million_pe.title: $3/year health insurance for 3 million people

True innovation starts with talk from the people in need.
insights_drive_innovation_ask_the_people.creator: b83a4fb93e64e6e58d4f5c7786aec381

comments.text: Welcome Lisa! You can also add thoughts on the challenges, platform, etc over in the Feature Requests section of our Support Forums: http://openideo.zendesk.com/

In the tiny rural villages I have visited there is no to limited electricity in simple homes/living arrangements.  So the this begs the question:  How do villagers use their phones which need to be charged w/o electrical outlet?  If this be the case, need a battery charger program assuming one doesn't exist to get phone-power-to-the-people.  This is little insight to a broader issue.  To IDEO, presenting current living obstacles, a National Geographic type video on what it's like living in a particular village would be helpful, so thinking can be directed to actual situation vs. bluesky.

@Ian  Please define 'large community'?  Nokia is sponsoring a project -- they are mobile.  That's a good start.  Anything done in utilizing mobile for market research would transfer to global brands - that's incentive to capitalize investment.  Whatever you do to obtain buy-in with any group there must be a win-win-(win) component.  While all like CSR etc there is a bottomline financial incentive - either w creating awareness of brand, positioning, etc.  Identifying the ways to win for each player = key when 'selling' to any community.  But please provide more detail your issues and I'll see if can help direct.

@Russell - "Asking the People' not people like us, but those living and breathing the problems.  Do the people in India in the tiny villages dealing with hour to hour, day to day stife have a voice?  They are the ones who should tell people like us how to think, what to think about.  Their input is essential in solving problems or throwing dust to the wind in some cases.

I think that IDEO is just that - it is the best way to "ask the people".  Take the example from open source projects (even the creation of the web itself).  How do you generate the best and brightest ideas to some of the worlds most pressing problems?  By opening up the conversation to the world!
How do you get a large community buy in to this project?

insights_drive_innovation_ask_the_people.title: Insights Drive Innovation - Ask The People

self_diagnosing_phone_service.creator: 91c731a8ad504c4dde932f79104f992c

comments.text: Thank you for the great comments and links posted by you guys, I'm sorry I haven't answered back to them earlier. I hope Erika can get something out of this when she goes on to refine her concept http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/mbaby-making-information-actionable/Marie, I really think your build (routine check-ups) could fit nicely into Erika's concept. You clearly point out the need for it and scheduled diagnosing doesn't mean people can't call the service whenever they feel the need for it.
Hi Krassimira, Congratulations on this concept being an Honourable Mention in our challenge!
This is a great concept! Particularly that its voice based rather than literacy based!

Hi, building on this you might want check out Health Line from Carnegie Mellon University http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~healthline/ Last I heard it was still a research project, but the results were amazing and I think your concept could leverage their technology findings.  In short they managed to make a system that can really quickly "learn" a new dialect (quickly = a few minutes!). It can't learn the language so you can have a conversation with it, but it can learn it so that you can interact with it in an IVR environment.Jahanzeb (one of my favorite geniuses) explains it here in detail: http://groups.google.com/group/ict4chw/browse_frm/thread/67a8441887d10617 Given what Marie is saying about there only being a handful of problems it seems like the back end logic could be programmed into an IVR system.Great Concept, Great Building Marie.

I had a similar idea and thought it would be more useful to build onto yours than to start a new concept.  I think a mobile diagnostic system would be great.  From my research it appears as though there are 10-15 common problems faced by pregnant women in developing countries, most of which can be easily diagnosed and remedied.  A virtual diagnostic survey would be a perfect solution  low cost and scalable.In addition to the voice system you suggest, I think an SMS system would work, too.  Due to the number of languages spoken in any one developing country (especially in Africa), SMS would allow the women to find someone to translate the questions into the language of their choice  and would also give them more time to understand and answer each one correctly. Additionally, I think the system could work in two ways: either the women call in when they feel like something is wrong or the system calls/SMSs them once a month as a routine mobile checkup.  Personally, I would vote for the latter.  Because health issues are so common in the developing world, many women dont realize they have a problem until its too late.  In fact, a clinic I visited in Kenya told me that many women dont realize theyre pregnant until their second trimester because missed periods and bloated bellies are so common due to malnutrition and stomach bugs.

This is a great concept in it's simplicity and effectiveness.  If the phone call itself did not use minutes or was based on a local toll free number then mothers and families could be encouraged to call early in pregnancy and often.
Excelent concept! It takes out the difficulties to literacy and the need for a smartphone

Absolutely Sarah, point taken! Those long medical terms can be intimidating... I believe both the description of symptoms and the instructions of whether to seek help or not can be made quite straight forward. Great consideration should however be put in how a suggested diagnosis is formulated and presented.

Great findings Sirl! I think that literacy here could not only include the fact that patients are able to read/write or not, but also the fact that the service should use words that are simple to understand (which is not always the case when it comes to the medical jargon).

self_diagnosing_phone_service.title: Self Diagnosing Phone Service

medicine_stock_outs.description:
The concept tries to address the stock-out problem mentioned by Ian Sullivan as a comment to Sarah’s decentralized mobile health care system proposal.
In the core of the concept is placing an order for drugs and medical supplies via sms.  
The sms creates an order, which is sent to an order management and product traceability system in the health centers.
So, we have 1) small pharmacies in the rural areas, 2) Hub of connected health centers and 3) drug/medical supplies vendors. One health center serves many small rural pharmacies. The health centers share a database. One health center can serve many rural pharmacies. One health center could receive drugs and medical supplies from different supplier.
One rural pharmacy can supply around i.e. 5 villages.
medicine_stock_outs.creator: 3661ce58e7cc1c8639f188bf0bc75ead

comments.text: I'm joining this late, but has anyone taken a closer look at logistimo.com?
Hi, do you know how successful is Logistimo? in which countries are they active?

Hi Krassimira  Anup Akkihal here.  I'm with Logistimo.  We can appreciate your Concept (problem description and ideas).  Our product as been used for 18 months now for managing supply chains in low-resource settings  across sectors such as healthcare, agriculture, durable goods, construction, etc.  Over 1000 facilities are currently supported by us in DRC, South Sudan and India.  Our product is quite mature now, supporting multiple platforms and transmission channels (GPRS, SMS, Offline Mode, etc.).  Happy to share more as needed.  Thanks!
Really great idea Krassimira! I like that it combines both forecasting and record keeping features.
I'm joining this late, but has anyone taken a closer look at logistimo.com?

This idea makes a lot of sense! The need for an enterprise solution to manage drug inventory and management is needed for broader health system strengthening. However, I think a more thorough understanding of the complexity of supply chains in developing countries is needed. This often differs from country to country, and is largely influenced by the distribution of public and private channels. Unlike developed countries, drugs can often be accessed through a number of channels (pharmacies, grocery stores, depots, doctors, community health workers), and public and private health centers often don't work in concerted efforts. These present challenges for establishing a simplified technical system like the one proposed. Check out SMS for Life - they have conducted a number of pilot projects in Africa utilizing a similar model, but have not achieved scale as of yet.

Hima, thanks for sharing the SMS for Life project...From what I can see on the webpage, they say the results of the pilot project have been really successful. Do you know what were the challenges they were facing? What could we learn from them?

Vincent, do you mean prompting the pharmacist with a message like this..."our records show you're low on stock on super aspirin. Do you want to renew your order with 10 packs? please answer with Y/N...."? Thanks!

Yes, it'd be awesome to get these concepts out in the real world! BTW, just looking back on my comment on this concept from a month ago about pharmacy level inventory management. I know you've already integrated the bit about order reminders, but wondering what your thoughts were about prompting for optional monthly inventory counting (which would improve forecasting/order reminder accuracy, and also serve as a tangible nudge when the pharmacy realizes for itself that its getting low on stock).
Thanks, Vincent and Susan! I would love to see this concept working!:)

Great job updating this concept Krassimira. It's gotten even stronger (I evaluated it as tops all across)! I particularly appreciate the reorder reminders based on historical records & forecasted demand.

Love the that the concept is doubly useful both for having needed medication on the ground when required but also as a way of gathering information which can illuminate patterns and be a catalyst for even longer term change! Great thinking and using existing proven technology!

this is not only a very good way to show governments how inefficient supply chains in many low income countries are, but also to show a way how these could be improved with the help of the mobile technolgy.
Thanks, Louise!

It is a great way to prevent people walking/travelling miles to a pharmacy to find that they are out of stock. Distance can be a real problem in the areas that this service is aimed at - it could mean that daily collections for a village are done or pharmacies can team up to help each other out. Very simple yet very effective helping the people that need the medicine and the pharmacy.
Cara, thanks for your comment. I believe through the incoming orders that are gathered in a central database such patters can be identified. The information could be channeled to health officials.

I think this idea is really great.  It would also be very helpful to have some of this information centralized for government health officials.  For example, if there is a dramatic increase in the demand for certain drugs in an area, this could alert health officials fo a potential outbreak that needs to be contained, or addressed on an aggregate level before it becomes an epidemic.
I agree this makes a lot more sense: great job!

Sarah, thanks a lot for your comment. I think this is a great idea and already built it in the concept: with a slight modification: midwives, village population, who own a cell phone can send an sms to a free number giving only their location to find out if the a) medication was ordered by the closest pharmacy, b) to find out when a medication they reordered will be available c) ask about a price of a medication that they couldn't find in the local pharmacy. I was thinking it will be difficult to find out the availability of the medicine at the local pharmacy as there is no way to track this. Once the pharmacy orders medicine, this is captured in the data base; the next point of interaction is the next time the pharmacy orders, so the central database will never know what is the stock in a village pharmacy unless it gets notified by the pharmacist per sms.

I understand this could make the system a lot more complex, but a possible build-on could be that any person (mother, dad, midwive, etc.) with a mobile phone could text a certain fixed number to check the availability of medicine (esp. if it's something that has to be taken periodically, so already known by the patient) at a certain point of sale. This could be helpful if the family lives far from the nearest pharmacy, as it would rather know it beforehand.
Robyn, thanks for your comments! Great ideas!

Wow! This is a great idea. I think there are also a lot of additional peices one could add to this type of program: reminders for potential re-orders, forecasting tools for essential medicines, FIFO, and perhaps even updates on new standards in care or warnings about particular drug batches.

This reminds me of a money sharing system in Kenya called MPesa where you can text drop off money at a particular location and text access to it for a friend or relative. Maybe we can use Mpesa as a model somehow?

Great job tackling this important issue that Ian raised Krassimira! There may also be opportunities to address inventory management at the pharmacy level. For example, you could also let pharmacies sign up for SMS reorder reminders on your system, which are sent out when historical order data/forecasting indicates they're likely to be low on stock. More comprehensive inventory management functionality could be provided as well (prompted monthly inventory counting/entry, etc.) , though this may be overkill (not sure how much complexity there is at this level, and what people are currently using).

I really like this. as well as being a great way to improve stocks of medicine (therefore helping communities) it will also be a way of building up information. Over time this history of info could be used to lobby governments to improve supply chains.
Thanks, Meena and Sarah!
Loving how you've added M-PESA in here  building upon mobile driven efficiencies which already exist. Nice one, K!

plug_play_mobile_phone_sensors.description: SquareUp ( http://www.squareup.com ), co-founded by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, is a small credit card reader that can be plugged into a cell phone's audio/mic jack, enabling anyone with a phone to accept credit card payments (SquareUp charges a small transaction processing fee). The reader is powered by the jack, collected data is sent back to the phone as an audio signal, and then sent to a central processor through the cell (or internet) network. The plug-in sensor is low cost enough that it is sent to interested users for free. Although the required software is currently only available for Androids, IPhones, & IPads, theoretically this could work with most phones.
plug_play_mobile_phone_sensors.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

integrated_information_and_networking_sy.description: Pregnant mothers through borrowed cell phones access the integrated information system.  The system’s core is a call-back call centre that schedules information delivery, regular checkups, and networks to the Internet, emergency services and other mothers.  Expectant mothers are introduced to the system via village based community outreach/health professionals or image heavy booklets and radio spots.  Mothers without their own phone are lent one for the duration of their pregnancy and first year of their child’s life.  The centre schedules regular voicemail messages with health information, calls regularly during the pregnancy to check their progress, and has access to the internet for difficult issues.  The centre may ask the outreach worker to visit the mother to make physical examinations, or request more specialized equipment to visit or specialized medicines delivered.  During childbirth, the dad or outreach worker is on hold with the call centre, in case they need advice or emergency services.
integrated_information_and_networking_sy.creator: 0e2cc23df7e37a854499f9d918b0219d
integrated_information_and_networking_sy.title: Integrated information and networking system: call-back call centre, community outreach, networking, borrowed phones.

i agree with @dara about the potential of radio to promote issues and campaigns. I also lke the idea of community radio. 2 questions: How do you ensure sustainability and would it need a professional radio production company - thinking about producing and of coruse the money needed to run it.

I like this idea! I think this could also help overcome taboos related to maternal health within certain communities.
Love how this overcomes literacy limitations.

This concept came about from a brainstorm we ran in the IDEO London studio. We'll be uploading a number of these ideas over the coming days, so stay tuned. Also run your own brainstorms using our brainstorm-in-a-box kit: http://documents.openideo.net/brainstorm_in_a_box.pdf

mum_radio.title: Mum Radio

mom_2_mom_mentor_matching.description: Imagine if a mom to be could simply call or text to choose from a list of qualified, experienced moms in her community for a meet up in a public place (like a market). The mom mentor would share her own personal story & advise on how to have a healthy pregnancy & birth. Future communication can be arranged. And the mom to be, after her own childbirth, could pay it forward by volunteering to be a mom mentor herself. Experienced moms can apply to be mom mentors, and then activated by pre-approved local partners (like medical providers, Oxfam?). Mentors would be trained on important practices (proper nutrition, sterile umbilical cord cutting, etc.), given referral contacts for health providers (midwives, local hospital, etc.), & perhaps even provided with basic handout kits (birthing/emergency, supplements). This would increase access by virally spreading vital maternal health info, tools, & emotional support through trusted community members, independent of ability to pay or proximity to traditional hospitals.
mom_2_mom_mentor_matching.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Simple concept, and a good idea! And yes, it does tie in to Sarah's concept very well.One thing we found very problematic in our clinics, is that patients would often rather listen to the uneducated neighbor who are in their family and their culture, than to the educated doctor who is from a different culture. This can be used to the advantage of the patient, if those members of the community who are less biased, and better educated, are positioned strategically within the community.

Great point!  From my perspective, it also means that we need to find ways to educate more community members -- using messages / messengers that they would readily welcome and believe -- so that they can continue to spread the right messages via word of mouth.I have no experience in this area and would be thrilled to learn a little more from you.  What are the common misconceptions that community members pass on to each other that are dangerous for mothers' health, or what are the messages they should be passing around to each other that they are missing?

Love this idea!  Based on Albert's comment that "patients would often rather listen to the uneducated neighbor who are in their family and their culture, than to the educated doctor who is from a different culture", and the question you posed in the concept build section, [What other ideas do people have for encouraging use of this service by expectant moms and experienced mentors?], here's a suggestion:Maybe the qualified, experienced moms could make periodic visits to doctors' offices to tell new moms about the program and make it feel that it's coming from their own community.  That way, there's more of a personal connection, and their first experience with the program doesn't have to be looking at a static list of names.Maybe there could be a booth so that even when women aren't able to staff the booth (I know moms don't have a lot of time!), new moms would still be able to learn about the service.

Hey there Vincent!Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! We really like your idea of mothers-to-be being able to call, text and meet up with qualified, experienced moms in their communities for a meet up in a public place.As part of this Refine phase, we're urging you to dive deeper in the details of your concept and give some more thought to what might be involved. We encourage you to work with Steph http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/mom-to-midwife/Haiyan http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/concepting/mum-2-mum-chatline/ so you can build a stronger concept together.When you're ready to update your concept, please click the 'Update this' button on the right-hand-side of your concept and fill out our 2 new fields:+ Concept Builds  Here you can list additional builds on your concept+ Virtual Team  Here you can credit others in the community who have contributed to your concept.Cheers from the OpenIDEO Team!

I love this idea. It is simple yet scaleable and mum's can take in as little or as much information as they want. Some may just want to receive a text from an expert/current mum or choose to meet up with them. A text message is a lovely way to make an informal connection with a 'stranger' before committing to becoming more comfortable around them. Some expecting mum's may see it as a security blanket if there are risks of abuse or isolation during pregnancy? Maybe after a trial there could different levels of offering depending on the country/community it is introduced to especially if trust is a cutural issue.

@Mokeira: also added a sentence at the top of the concept & in the Concept Build section to integrate your spot-on suggestion. Your right about this additional list & select step. It increases choice & privacy, and thus comfort & follow-through. Thanks for your thoughtful guidance!

Thanks all for the continuing builds that I'm incorporating in the Concept Build & Virtual Team sections of this concept. Please let me know if I've misunderstood or missed anything. @OpenIDEO (Haiyan):Thanks! I was envisioning that mom mentors would be added/activated by pre-approved local partners (such as medical providers, Oxfam?), though they could apply themselves. Based on your feedback, I have added a sentence near the top of the concept to make this clear. Is that what what you mean by a "stamp", or is it going over my head?

Great idea. It would be great somehow for the expectant mothers to get to chose or decide which mentor they want to be matched with.  They could make the ultimate decision after the most suitable options are presented to them.

Hi Vincent, Congratulations for being one of our top 20 finalists in the Maternal Health challenge! Thanks for being proactive and already building on your concept and virtual team. We wonder if there's room here to also include a Mom Mentor stamp of approval.As Steph Troeth brought up in her concept, mothers who have given birth have a lot of knowledge and could be recognised as such. Could Oxfam create a stamp for women with experience and knowledge which would be a mark of approval for this service?Cheers,Haiyan

This is an incredible and truly innovative way to build on the word-of-mouth way people in developing areas already learn about every aspect of their lives. Perhaps this could be built on by also organizing regular meet-ups for mothers to be in the area or talks by some of the trained mothers. Announcements and reminders for events like this could be sent via text message and provide an opportunity for women to make an in-person connection without having to arrange a one-on-one session right away and could help make them feel more comfortable with the system by being surrounded by others going through the same thing.

This is an incredible and truly innovative way to build on the word-of-mouth way people in developing areas already learn about every aspect of their lives. Perhaps this could be built on by also organizing regular meet-ups for mothers to be in the area or talks by some of the trained mothers. Announcements and reminders for events like this could be sent via text message and provide an opportunity for women to make an in-person connection without having to arrange a one-on-one session right away and could help make them feel more comfortable with the system by being surrounded by others going through the same thing.

I like the personal touch here. The organization I worked for has used this with farmers and called it the "Ask an Expert" application. Farmers can text in questions and get advice from others who have had similar issues. If they have a camera on their phone, they can also send photos, for example of plant diseases to be identified remotely. I wonder how photos could tie into this idea as well.
This is a great idea.  I think tapping into existing parents groups in urban areas would be a great way to test this idea.  Here's a local one near where I live: http://www.pampclub.org/

@ Meena: I'm gradually updating my profile as I find time, but I worked in Kayelitsha Site B clinic, close to Cape Town. It's a very rural community, despite its close proximity to the city. This has often made me ponder reasons for the difficulties these people face. Cultural barriers and traditional beliefs are major issues in this regard. Changing from within, instead of without, could be a better approach.

Thanks for the support!@Albert: great to hear that this could be helpful from someone who's tackled these issues on the ground firsthand.@Sarah: hmm...good point. Could allow the mom-to-be to confirm a given potential match before the meetup is arranged, or search for a new match instead.@Meena: thanks! definitely the community based inspirations I linked on the right helped shape the "pay forward" part of this concept.

I like this idea! And building on top of Albert's comment, I think it could also include an "anonymity" feature for certain cases (eg. women with unwanted pregnancies). For example, the number from which the sms has been sent would be filtered by the matching system, and the person could be matched with someone trustworthy (or from another community).
Great to get these insights Albert! What clinics do you work in and where? Couldn't find any details over on your profile page... I'm sure our community would love to know too.
Loving the 'pay forward' in-kind aspect here. Nice one Vincent!

centralized_maternal_health_information_.description:
Information is constantly distributed to the masses through centralized means; whether it is an airport kiosk, arrival/departure sign, stock tickers, scoreboards, etc.

There could be situations in low-income countries where it is very difficult or not possible to equip each individual with a mobile device that can transmit maternal care information.  In such situations, a more centralized method to info transmission may be more appropriate.
centralized_maternal_health_information_.creator: 89f0fee17250dd3bf28ed7533c51edd1

comments.text: Great inspiration!
Something like the Medscape library could be translated and preloaded on every kiosk:http://emedicine.medscape.com/obstetrics_gynecology
The Kampala kiosk prototype is really cool!
In this case, mobile phones could be used as a "check-in" interface in order to identify their owner (the mom) and target the available information according to her situation/case.
Nice one Dan! You might like the rugged design of this kiosk designed in Kampala http://bit.ly/92rwXH I'm loving the idea that information can be printed out.
Love the idea of access to a centralised stream of well regulated information.
Great inspiration, love the analogy!

I really like where this is going especially with the ability to consistently refresh information as well as allow everyone to get the same information. This seems like a good idea to tie to some incentive/need based activity to encourage visitation by expectant moms.

centralized_maternal_health_information_.title: Centralized maternal health information kiosks

send_your_phone_to_a_mum.description: Pop your unwanted mobiles in an envelope and send it to a mum in need.
send_your_phone_to_a_mum.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: It seems like an amazing opportunity for a company like Apple to be a Hero brand by enabling the disposal of older models and promoting purchase of newer models within its primary markets.
Nice concept.. I wonder about some of the logistics initially though.. i.e. service, quality of the device, disposal...

One note on hope phones, they actually recycle donated phones in the US and use the money to buy phones for community health workers on the ground. This saves international shipping costs, and makes sure you get the chw a phone appropriate for their context.

One note on hope phones, they actually recycle donated phones in the US and use the money to buy phones for community health workers on the ground. This saves international shipping costs, and makes sure you get the chw a phone appropriate for their context.
Very good concept...Look at this article about hope phones (as said by Kara)...It happen in Malawihttp://act.mtv.com/posts/hope-phones-saving-lives-in-malawi/?xrs=share_twitter
this is a thoughtful and very resourceful idea Haiyan. Kara's link to hope phones puts it in to perspective.
Hope Phones could be a catalyst for this idea? They are looking to get old phones to medical clinics and seemingly do the work to prep the phones for other countries? http://hopephones.org

The market for second-hand phones is huge here in India (though obviously most US phones don't work here  platform + band compatibility would be need to be considered on something like this. No point leading folks to believe they've made an impact when their phone doesn't work in the target country ;^) Mobile repair is a flourishing business too http://bit.ly/9Jy7Ms Would help if an initiative like this also sought to share manuals on phones which have not been previously available in that country so that maintenance is also part of the consideration (a missing part of many well intentioned tech interventions!) A few copies tend to spread like wildfire between repair shops.

As far as I know we don't. Although in the UK we did have a partnership with the Co-Op on a recycle scheme, 'Bring-Bring' http://www.oxfam.org.uk/get_involved/recycle/bringbring.htmlThere are lots of precedents for the buy a gift idea - we have Oxfam Unwrapped (or the buy a goat thing as it's known by most people). If we had the correct product you could fundriase for it in this way or through a Bring-Bring way, or both. Not sure on the market for 2nd hand phones in developed countries.

Great comments guy. This could be a great mobile tech donation drive with companies and individuals.By the way, feel free to click 'Build on this' to extend the idea further with your own thoughts. @Ian - does oxfam handle sale of 2nd-hand phones? I think it's important to keep that line-of-sight to what I donate and how it impacts people (ie. I donate a phone and someone gets a phone). Would work if Oxfam+Nokia was an intermediary that sold the phones and then used the money to buy phones at the other end. Am curious as to what the market is for 2nd-hand phones in developed countries. Any ideas?

Most organisations like Oxfam would rather do a scheme where they collect the phones (say in the UK) and then get the cash and use that for their work. You could feasably have a project where you asked people to give phones, collected the money and then used the money to buy phones at the other end.

Haiyan, what about this?- Instead of having single individual send an unused phone, have whole corporations send unused phones? A lot of corporations used to give their sales force/business development folks mobile phones; now they switch to Blackberries/iPhones/iPads. What do you think?

Nokia - "Connecting (-people) Everything"

comments.text: good
Agreed, James. It depends a lot on the time span...

"Mobile phones used to be toys for yuppies. Now, they have become tools for development." Nokia (in the brief)Smartphones are toys for yuppies as are laptops. In India, they are developing a laptop for $20, One laptop per child moves with a similar flow. Smartphones are not going to be expensive in the future, they are expensive for the early adopters, and the early adopters are the entire first world economies. They will become the tools for development.I guess I agree partly as is this about ideas for 2010 not 2025? I'm not sure....

I agree with Anjelika on the fact that most people don't have smartphones in low-income communities... Althought this could be a opportunity for a telco corporation such as Nokia to try to come up with the next extremely affordable smartphone :)

@james - yes, it's incredible how many people have mobile phones now. for developing countries though, we still need to consider uptake of smartphones vs. other types of mobile phones. i think opportunity too will be that mobile phone plug-ins should be phone agnostic so that they could work on any platform. did you check out my post about the smartphone ultrasound? i've love to know what you think: http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/smartphone-ultrasound-mobius/

plugin_health.title: Plugin Health

comments.text: From this chart, I tend to categorize the causes into three stages:1.  Pre-labor: Abortion, Eclampsia, 2.  In-labor: Hemorrhage, Obstructed labor, and Sepsis (infection of blood)3.  Post-labor: This could include SepsisIf we combine In-labor and Post-labor, that means 53% of deaths occur during these stages and 39% occur in the pre-labor stage.  A mobile phone solution seems most helpful for pre-labor.

Thanks for the comments!Think I might really get into this openideo thing.Vincent, will try to find some stuff on child mortality.  If we get a big overlap (in either cause or solution) then that's the heavy hitter.
Well done.

Great inspiration!  I agree we should focus on the areas you mentioned that are causing the most problems.  I had no idea so many mothers died from attempting abortions.  I also agree with Andres, education is always key.
Interesting as it help us keep focus on the where the most impact can be achieved. Although B has a lot to do with education and communication, for which the mobiles are a great tool.

Thanks for researching and sharing your findings Tristan! Helps us understand the magnitude of different maternal mortality causes to see where we can help the most. Would also be interesting to see what the chart looks like for the baby's mortality (during pregnancy, at childbirth, and for the critical early years).

groupme_micro_health_networks_bringing_t.description: What if you could harness the insights of health care professionals and others with experience in your community into the palm of your hand? What if you had local clinic doctors, nurses, or healthcare provider start small groups with women who have cell phones (all using a simple SMS list-serve mode of operation). If the phone numbers were anonymized you could have pregnant women or post-partum mothers ask questions through SMS or even send quick pictures (if their camera has a phone - MMS) to tell or show the doctor something. Perhaps the question could be posed to other mothers who can respond with their experiences and wisdom. You've created "a micro health network" to support mothers. You maintain privacy, but encourage regular communication and communal support of health. The medical personnel part of the group can also send out announcements or friendly tips, etc. All this can be done using the existing technology developed by the free service called GroupMe (http://groupme.com)
groupme_micro_health_networks_bringing_t.creator: 3477f2719c2ec13566dddb41787b8089

comments.text: I think our ideas are very similar. Awesome!
We were excited about this since your Inspiration post. It's so great to see your further developments here for the Concepting Phase. Way to go Sina!

groupme_micro_health_networks_bringing_t.title: GroupMe Micro Health Networks (bringing the community into the palm of your hand)

sharing_best_practices_from_home_deliver.description: In The Netherlands we have a system in place that facilitates pregnant women to deliver their babies at home. This system consists of (mostly) women who are trained to overcome some of the common problems that may occur when giving birth. They act as an extension of the hospital, ensuring only truely critical patients are brought into hospital. However, in their professional life, these professionals have seen many potentially life-threatening situations, and often solved them without any medical tools. I interviewed my neighbour, who has worked in maternity care for about 35 years, assisting in the delivery of about 800 babies. She told me - based on her experience - some of the things everyone  can do in case of a problematic delivery.
sharing_best_practices_from_home_deliver.creator: 8baa47694773254ec694aa18c0ae7137

comments.text: Good point Paul! Thanks for conducting this practitioner interview with your neighbor. I'm guessing that there's much to be learned and disseminated from the experiences of midwives/community health workers in both developed and developing countries, especially those who have particularly outlying high performance (significant number of deliveries with low mortality rates).

sharing_best_practices_from_home_deliver.title: Sharing best practices from home deliveries in developed countries

comments.text: Loving the combination of outreach + centralised networks here. Can imagine GPS location features to be useful too.

The idea of using motorbikes has a very interesting application on this inspiration http://openideo.com/open/maternal-health/inspiration/doctors-nurses-on-motorcycles/May be can help you to construct more!

I like the idea of the networked HCWs/nurses:- there could be an emergency number they could call-the HCW should have a chance to send sms on a free number with a inquiry/consultation/picture describing the problem they face to a central database. The sms is picked by a virtual community of doctors or medical students (similar to the call center agent concept) and the HCW/nurse receives an answer within i.e. 30 mins. Thoughts?
